stars.title: Quick Start Runner

planets.title: Instant Setup
planets.description: Download and install Roblox Studio, open a baseplate, and learn the Play/Stop buttons
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 1.1: Instant Setup

Right now, millions of people are playing games that started exactly where you are about to start: with a blank screen and an idea. Roblox has over 70 million daily players, and every single game they play was built by someone using the same free tool you are about to download. Today, you join the ranks of Roblox developers.

In the next 15 minutes, you will go from having nothing to pressing Play on your very first Roblox project. No experience required. No tricks. Just follow along, and by the end of this mission, you will have a working game environment running on your screen.

Fun Fact: Some of the most popular Roblox games earn their creators millions of dollars per year. Every one of those developers started exactly like you - opening Roblox Studio for the first time and wondering what to click.

Your Mission

Learning Objective: Download and install Roblox Studio, open a baseplate project, and locate the Play/Stop buttons to test your game.

What You Will Accomplish

  • Create a Roblox account (if you do not have one)
  • Download and install Roblox Studio
  • Open the Baseplate template
  • Find and use the Play button to test your game
  • Find and use the Stop button to return to editing

Step-by-Step Instructions

Step 1: Create Your Roblox Account

If you already have a Roblox account, skip to Step 2. Otherwise, let us get you set up.

  1. Open your web browser and go to roblox.com
  2. Click the Sign Up button
  3. Fill in your birthday, username, and password
  4. Complete the verification (you may need to verify your email)
  5. Write down your username and password somewhere safe!

Tip: Choose a username you will be proud of - other players and your classmates will see it! Avoid using your real name for privacy.

Step 2: Download Roblox Studio

Roblox Studio is completely free. It is the official tool that all Roblox games are made with.

  1. Go to roblox.com/create
  2. Click Start Creating
  3. If prompted, log in with your Roblox account
  4. Click Download Studio
  5. Run the installer file that downloads
  6. Wait for the installation to complete (this may take a few minutes)

Note for School Computers: If you get a message saying you cannot install software, raise your hand and let your teacher know. They may need to help you or contact IT.

Step 3: Open Roblox Studio

Once installation finishes, Roblox Studio should open automatically. If it does not:

  • Windows: Search for "Roblox Studio" in the Start menu
  • Mac: Find "Roblox Studio" in your Applications folder

When Studio opens, you will see a home screen with templates and recent projects. This is your launching pad for creating games!

Step 4: Create a New Baseplate Project

A Baseplate is the simplest possible Roblox world - just a flat ground and a place for players to spawn. It is perfect for learning.

  1. On the home screen, look for the New tab or section
  2. Find the template called Baseplate (it looks like a gray flat surface)
  3. Click on Baseplate to create a new project
  4. Wait a moment while your project loads

When it loads, you will see a 3D view of a large gray floor stretching into the distance. Congratulations - you are looking at your first game world!

Explore: Try clicking and dragging in the 3D view. Hold the right mouse button and move your mouse to look around. Use the scroll wheel to zoom in and out. Get comfortable with moving your view - you will do this constantly!

Step 5: Find the Play and Stop Buttons

The most important buttons in Roblox Studio are Play and Stop. They let you instantly test your game.

  1. Look at the top of the screen for the Home tab (it should already be selected)
  2. In the toolbar, find the Play button - it is a blue button with a play triangle
  3. The Stop button is right next to it - it is a red square

Visual Guide: The Play button is in the "Test" section of the Home tab toolbar. It looks like this: a blue circle with a white triangle pointing right (like a video play button).

Step 6: Play Your First Game!

Time for the magic moment. Let us run your game!

  1. Click the Play button
  2. Watch as the view changes - you are now a player in your game!
  3. Use W, A, S, D to walk around
  4. Press Space to jump
  5. Move your mouse to look around
  6. When you are done exploring, click the Stop button to return to editing

Try It!

Walk to the edge of the baseplate and jump off. What happens? (Do not worry, nothing breaks - this is how you discover how Roblox works!)

Important: Always click Stop before trying to build or change anything. If you try to edit while the game is running, your changes might not save properly!

Quick Reference: Essential Controls

Action Control
Move (in Play mode) W, A, S, D
Jump (in Play mode) Space
Look around (in Play mode) Move mouse
Rotate camera (in Edit mode) Right-click + drag
Zoom (in Edit mode) Scroll wheel
Play the game F5 (or click Play)
Stop the game Shift + F5 (or click Stop)

Mission Complete?

Before moving on, verify that you have accomplished everything in this mission:

Completion Checklist

  • I have a Roblox account and can log in
  • Roblox Studio is installed on my computer
  • I created a new Baseplate project
  • I found the Play button and used it to enter my game
  • I walked around and jumped using W, A, S, D and Space
  • I clicked Stop to return to edit mode

You did it! You have taken your first step into game development. The baseplate might look empty now, but in the next mission, you will start building your obstacle course. Everything you create from here on will start exactly like this - pressing Play to test, Stop to build, Play to test again.

What Comes Next

You have the foundation - Roblox Studio is ready, and you know how to test your game. But right now, your world is just an empty floor. That changes in the next mission.

In Mission 1.2: Three-Jump Course, you will add your first parts to the world and build a simple jumping challenge. By the end, you will have something you can actually play - a mini obstacle course with three jumps to complete.

Coming Up: Mission 1.2 Preview

  • Learn how to insert Parts (3D blocks) into your world
  • Use the Move tool to position parts
  • Build a sequence of platforms that require jumping
  • Test whether your jumps are actually possible

Do not close Roblox Studio - keep your baseplate project open and get ready to build!

planets.title: Three-Jump Course
planets.description: Place 4 parts to create your first playable jumping sequence
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 1.2: Three-Jump Course

An empty baseplate is just potential. A baseplate with obstacles is a game. In the next 20 minutes, you are going to transform that flat gray surface into your first playable obstacle course - and you are going to do it by placing just four simple blocks.

Every great Roblox obstacle course - or "obby" as players call them - is built from the same basic element: Parts. Parts are 3D shapes that you can move, resize, color, and arrange into anything you can imagine. Today, you will place your first four parts and create something you can actually play.

Did You Know? The most popular obstacle course games on Roblox have been played billions of times. They all started with someone placing their first part - just like you are about to do right now.

Your Mission

Learning Objective: Place 4 parts in Roblox Studio to create a playable jumping sequence that challenges players to reach the end.

What You Will Build

A simple jumping course with:

  • A starting platform (raised off the ground)
  • Three jumping platforms that get progressively further apart
  • Jumps that are challenging but possible

Step-by-Step Instructions

Step 1: Insert Your First Part

Make sure you are in edit mode (not playing). Let us add your first building block!

  1. Look at the top of the screen and click the Model tab
  2. In the toolbar, find the Part button (it shows a small cube icon)
  3. Click the small arrow next to "Part" to see different shapes
  4. Select Block (the default rectangular shape)

A gray block appears in your world! This is a Part - the most fundamental building element in Roblox.

Keyboard Shortcut: You can also press Ctrl + 1 (Windows) or Cmd + 1 (Mac) to quickly insert a part. Speed matters when you are building!

Step 2: Select and Move the Part

Your part appeared somewhere in the world, but probably not where you want it. Let us move it!

  1. Click on your part to select it (you will see a selection box around it)
  2. In the Model tab, find and click the Move tool (or press Ctrl + 2)
  3. You will see colored arrows appear on the part:
    • Red arrow = X axis (left/right)
    • Green arrow = Y axis (up/down)
    • Blue arrow = Z axis (forward/back)
  4. Click and drag the green arrow to lift the part up
  5. Position it about 5-6 studs above the baseplate

What is a Stud? A stud is Roblox's unit of measurement. The default part is 4x1x2 studs. A player character is about 5 studs tall and can jump approximately 7 studs high.

Try It!

Press Play and try to jump onto your platform. Can you reach it? If it is too high (more than about 7 studs above the ground), go back and lower it. If it is too low (touching the ground), raise it up!

Step 3: Make It a Real Platform

The default part is pretty small. Let us make it bigger so it feels like a proper starting platform.

  1. Select your part
  2. Click the Scale tool in the Model tab (or press Ctrl + 4)
  3. You will see colored spheres on the corners and edges
  4. Drag the spheres to resize:
    • Make the platform about 8 studs wide
    • Keep it 2-4 studs tall
    • Make it about 8 studs deep

Now you have a proper starting platform that players can stand on comfortably!

Step 4: Add Three More Platforms

Now for the fun part - building the jumping sequence!

  1. With your first platform selected, press Ctrl + D (Duplicate)
  2. A copy appears! Use the Move tool to position it:
    • Move it forward (blue arrow) away from the first platform
    • Keep it at roughly the same height
    • Position it about 5-6 studs away - an easy first jump
  3. Duplicate again (Ctrl + D) to create a third platform
  4. Move this one slightly further - about 7 studs from the second
  5. Duplicate once more for your fourth and final platform
  6. Position it at the maximum jump distance - about 8-9 studs away

Jump Distance Rule: Players can jump forward about 8-10 studs maximum when running at full speed. If your platforms are further apart than that, the jump becomes impossible! When in doubt, make jumps slightly easier than you think.

Step 5: Add Some Variety (Optional Challenge)

Want to make it more interesting? Try these variations:

  • Height changes: Make platform 3 slightly higher than platform 2
  • Size changes: Make the later platforms smaller (harder to land on)
  • Angles: Position platforms in a zig-zag instead of a straight line

Design Tip: Good obstacle courses start easy and get harder. Your first jump should be almost automatic, and each one after should require a bit more skill. This teaches players and builds confidence!

Step 6: Test Everything!

The only way to know if your course works is to play it yourself.

  1. Click Play
  2. Walk to your starting platform and jump up onto it
  3. Try to complete all three jumps
  4. If any jump is impossible, click Stop and adjust the platform positions
  5. Repeat until you can complete the course!

Try It!

Complete your course three times in a row. If you fail on the same jump multiple times, it might be too hard. If you never fail, consider making it slightly more challenging!

Quick Reference: Building Tools

Tool Shortcut What It Does
Select Ctrl + 1 Click on parts to select them
Move Ctrl + 2 Drag parts to new positions
Scale Ctrl + 4 Resize parts bigger or smaller
Rotate Ctrl + 3 Spin parts to different angles
Duplicate Ctrl + D Copy the selected part
Delete Delete key Remove the selected part

Mission Complete?

Before moving on, make sure your jumping course meets these requirements:

Completion Checklist

  • I have 4 platforms in my world
  • The first platform is raised above the ground
  • Each platform requires a jump to reach
  • All jumps are possible (I tested them!)
  • The course gets slightly harder as it goes
  • I can complete the entire course in Play mode

Amazing Work! You just built something playable. That gray empty baseplate is now a real obstacle course! But right now, there is no consequence for falling - you just land on the ground and try again. Let us add some danger.

What Comes Next

Your course has platforms and jumps, but it is missing something crucial: stakes. Right now, if you miss a jump, you just land safely on the baseplate and try again. Where is the excitement in that?

In Mission 1.3: Add Danger, you will create your first kill brick - a deadly obstacle that resets players when they touch it. You will write your very first line of code, and your game will go from "jumping practice" to "real challenge."

Coming Up: Mission 1.3 Preview

  • Create a part that kills players on touch
  • Write your first Lua script
  • Learn about the Touched event
  • Add real consequences to your obstacle course

Save your project (Ctrl + S or File > Save to File) and get ready to add some danger to your game!

planets.title: Add Danger
planets.description: Create one kill brick that sends you back to start when touched
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 1.3: Add Danger

What separates a playground from a game? Consequences. Right now, your jumping course is just practice - miss a jump and nothing happens. But in a real game, missing a jump should matter. In this mission, you are going to write your first lines of code and create something that makes players think twice before they leap.

You are about to become a programmer. Not just someone who places blocks, but someone who makes those blocks do things. By the end of this mission, your game will have a deadly kill brick that resets players who touch it. One small script, one huge leap forward.

Programming is Power: Every video game you have ever played runs on code. Code makes enemies chase you, coins disappear when collected, and checkpoints save your progress. Today, you join the ranks of people who write that code.

Your Mission

Learning Objective: Create a kill brick using a simple script that sends players back to the start when touched.

What You Will Create

  • A distinctive red "danger zone" part below your platforms
  • Your first Lua script
  • Code that detects when a player touches the danger zone
  • A consequence: touching the danger resets the player

Step-by-Step Instructions

Step 1: Create the Danger Zone

First, we need a part that represents danger. Let us create a big red zone below your jumping course.

  1. Go to the Model tab and insert a new Part (Block)
  2. Use the Scale tool to make it large - about 50x1x50 studs
  3. Use the Move tool to position it directly below your platforms, about 10 studs down

Now let us make it look dangerous:

  1. With the part selected, look at the Properties panel on the right side of the screen
  2. If you do not see Properties, go to View tab and click Properties
  3. Find the BrickColor property and click on it
  4. Select Bright red or Really red
  5. Find the Name property at the top and change it from "Part" to KillBrick

Naming Matters: Always give your parts descriptive names! When you have hundreds of parts, you will thank yourself for naming them clearly. "KillBrick" is much easier to find than "Part" or "Part47".

Step 2: Add a Script to Your Kill Brick

Parts just sit there until you add code. Let us give your kill brick a brain!

  1. In the Explorer panel (usually on the right), find your KillBrick
  2. Right-click on KillBrick
  3. Hover over Insert Object
  4. Click Script

A new Script appears inside your KillBrick, and a code editor opens! You will see some default text:

print("Hello world!")

This default code just prints a message. We are going to replace it with our kill brick code.

Step 3: Write Your First Real Code

Delete everything in the script and type this code exactly:

local killBrick = script.Parent

local function onTouched(otherPart)
    local humanoid = otherPart.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")
    if humanoid then
        humanoid.Health = 0
    end
end

killBrick.Touched:Connect(onTouched)

Type Carefully! Code must be typed exactly right. Every capital letter, every period, every parenthesis matters. If something does not work, check your spelling and punctuation first!

What Does This Code Do?

Let us break it down line by line:

local killBrick = script.Parent

This stores a reference to the part containing this script (your KillBrick).

local function onTouched(otherPart)

This creates a function named "onTouched" that runs whenever something touches our brick. The "otherPart" is whatever touched us.

local humanoid = otherPart.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")

This checks if the thing that touched us is part of a player character. Players have a "Humanoid" component that controls their health and movement.

if humanoid then

This checks: "Did we actually find a Humanoid?" We only want to kill players, not random parts.

humanoid.Health = 0

This sets the player's health to zero, which eliminates them!

killBrick.Touched:Connect(onTouched)

This connects our function to the brick's Touched event. Now, whenever anything touches the brick, our onTouched function runs.

Step 4: Test Your Kill Brick

Time to see if your code works!

  1. Click Play
  2. Walk off the edge of the baseplate and fall onto your red kill brick
  3. Watch what happens!

If everything worked, you should see your character disappear and respawn at the starting position. Congratulations - your first script works!

Try It!

Jump off from different heights. Try landing on the edge of the kill brick. Does it work every time? Try missing a platform jump and falling - does the kill brick catch you?

Step 5: Troubleshooting (If It Did Not Work)

If your kill brick is not working, here are common problems and fixes:

Nothing happens when I touch it

  • Check that the Script is inside the KillBrick in the Explorer
  • Make sure you typed the code exactly right
  • Check for the red underline in the script editor - this shows errors

Red error messages in the Output

  • Open the View tab and click Output
  • Read the error message - it tells you what line has a problem
  • Common issues: missing parentheses, typos in "Humanoid", wrong capitalization

I fall through the kill brick

  • Make sure the KillBrick's CanCollide property is set to true
  • Check that the brick is not Anchored to false (it should be Anchored = true)

The Output Window is Your Friend: Whenever something is not working, check the Output window (View > Output). Error messages appear there in red and tell you exactly what went wrong and on which line.

Step 6: Fine-Tune the Position

Make sure your kill brick is positioned well:

  • It should be below all your platforms so missing any jump is deadly
  • It should be large enough that players cannot fall past it
  • Consider adding walls around the edges so players cannot escape sideways

Play your course a few times. The danger is real now - every jump matters!

Code Reference: Kill Brick Script

local killBrick = script.Parent

local function onTouched(otherPart)
    local humanoid = otherPart.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")
    if humanoid then
        humanoid.Health = 0
    end
end

killBrick.Touched:Connect(onTouched)

Key Concepts:

  • script.Parent - References the part containing this script
  • Touched - An event that fires when something touches the part
  • :Connect() - Connects a function to an event
  • Humanoid - The component that makes a character a "player"
  • Health = 0 - Setting health to zero defeats the player

Mission Complete?

Verify your kill brick is working properly:

Completion Checklist

  • I created a red part named "KillBrick"
  • The KillBrick has a Script inside it
  • When I touch the KillBrick in Play mode, my character dies
  • After dying, I respawn at the starting position
  • The KillBrick is positioned below all my platforms
  • Missing a jump in my obstacle course leads to the kill brick

You Are Now a Programmer! You just wrote real code that actually does something. The Touched event and Humanoid detection you learned are used in thousands of Roblox games. This is the foundation of everything interactive in your game.

What Comes Next

Your game now has danger - but it does not yet have a goal. Players can jump from platform to platform, but there is nothing telling them "you made it!" when they reach the end.

In Mission 1.4: Victory Part, you will create a finish line that stands out visually and gives players a clear target to reach. A game needs both challenge AND reward - you have the challenge, now let us add the reward!

Coming Up: Mission 1.4 Preview

  • Create a victory platform with a distinctive color
  • Learn about part properties and visual design
  • Understand how color communicates meaning in games
  • Complete the core loop: start, danger, goal

Your first script is working! Save your project and get ready to add the finish line.

planets.title: Victory Part
planets.description: Add a finish line part in a different color to mark completion
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 1.4: Victory Part

Think about the last time you finished a level in a video game. There was probably a door, a flag, a glowing portal, or some kind of finish line that screamed "YOU MADE IT!" That moment of triumph does not happen by accident - game designers create it deliberately. Now you are going to create that moment for your players.

Your obstacle course has platforms to jump on and danger to avoid. But right now, the last platform looks exactly like all the others. How would a player know they won? In this mission, you will learn how visual design communicates meaning in games, and create a victory zone that players will feel proud to reach.

Design Psychology: Colors have meaning. Red often means danger or stop. Green means go or success. Blue feels calm. Gold feels rewarding. Every choice you make communicates something to your players, even if they do not consciously notice it.

Your Mission

Learning Objective: Add a distinctively colored finish line part that marks the completion point of your obstacle course.

What You Will Create

  • A victory platform with a distinctive, rewarding color
  • Visual contrast that makes the goal obvious
  • A complete game loop: start, challenge, danger, goal

Step-by-Step Instructions

Step 1: Identify Your Finish Line Location

Before we add anything, let us think about where the victory part should go.

  • Click Play and complete your obstacle course
  • When you land on the last platform, look around - where should the finish line be?
  • Click Stop and select your last platform

We have two options:

  1. Option A: Turn your last platform INTO the victory zone (change its color)
  2. Option B: Add a NEW part on top of or next to your last platform

For this mission, we will do Option A - transforming your final platform into a victory zone. This keeps things simple and clear.

Step 2: Change the Platform Color

Let us make that final platform stand out!

  1. Select your last platform (the one players reach at the end)
  2. Open the Properties panel (View > Properties if you do not see it)
  3. Find the BrickColor property
  4. Click on it to open the color picker
  5. Choose a color that says "victory!" Some great options:
    • Bright green - Classic "win" color
    • Gold / Bright yellow - Feels rewarding
    • Lime green - Energetic success
    • Cyan - Cool and distinct

Contrast is Key: Your victory color should be completely different from your other platforms. If your regular platforms are gray, almost any bright color works. The goal is that players can see the finish line from the start!

Step 3: Give It a Clear Name

Just like we named the kill brick, let us give this part a descriptive name.

  1. With the victory platform still selected
  2. Look at the Properties panel
  3. At the very top, find the Name property
  4. Change it from "Part" to VictoryPlatform or FinishLine

Why Names Matter: In later missions, you will write scripts that detect when players reach the finish line. Having clear names like "VictoryPlatform" makes your code much easier to write and understand!

Step 4: Add Extra Visual Polish (Optional)

Want to make your victory zone even more special? Here are some properties you can experiment with:

Material

In Properties, find Material and try these options:

  • Neon - Glows brightly (great for victory zones!)
  • SmoothPlastic - Clean, polished look
  • Foil - Shiny metallic surface
  • Glass - Transparent and futuristic

Transparency

Values from 0 (solid) to 1 (invisible). Try 0.3 for a semi-transparent effect.

Reflectance

Values from 0 (matte) to 1 (mirror). Try 0.5 for a shiny surface.

Try It!

Set your victory platform to Material = Neon and see how it glows! Neon material emits light and looks amazing as a finish line. If it is too bright, change the color to a darker shade.

Step 5: Check the Visual Flow

Good game design means players understand what to do just by looking. Let us test that.

  1. Click Play
  2. Look at your course from the starting position
  3. Ask yourself: Can I clearly see where I need to go?
  4. The visual path should be: Gray platforms > Red danger below > Green/Gold victory at the end

Your course should now tell a visual story:

  • Gray = Normal, safe to stand on
  • Red = Danger, do not touch!
  • Green/Gold = Goal, get here to win!

Congratulations! You just applied real game design principles. Professional game designers spend a lot of time thinking about visual communication - what colors mean, what draws the eye, what feels rewarding. You are already doing that work!

Step 6: Consider Size and Position

A few final thoughts on your victory platform:

  • Size: The victory platform can be a bit larger than other platforms - it is the reward, after all! Players should feel like they are landing somewhere special.
  • Height: Consider making it slightly higher than the previous platform, so reaching it feels like an achievement.
  • Visibility: Make sure it is visible from the start. If your course curves, the player should still be able to see that green glow in the distance.

Quick Reference: Part Appearance Properties

Property What It Does Suggested Values
BrickColor The color of the part Bright green, Gold, Lime green
Material The surface texture/look Neon (glows), SmoothPlastic, Foil
Transparency How see-through it is 0 (solid) to 1 (invisible)
Reflectance How shiny/mirrored it is 0 (matte) to 1 (mirror)
CastShadow Whether it creates shadows true/false

Mission Complete?

Let us verify your victory zone is ready:

Completion Checklist

  • My final platform has a distinctive color (not gray)
  • The color suggests "victory" or "goal" (green, gold, etc.)
  • I renamed the part to "VictoryPlatform" or similar
  • The victory platform is visible from the starting position
  • My course has clear visual contrast: normal platforms, danger zone, victory zone

Your Game is Complete! You now have all the core elements of an obstacle course: platforms to jump on, danger to avoid, and a goal to reach. This is a real, playable game. In the next mission, you will do a full playtest and share your creation with your classmates!

What Comes Next

You built it. You coded it. You designed it. Now it is time to play it - really play it, as a player would, and then show it off to your classmates.

In Mission 1.5: Play Your Game, you will do a complete playtest of your obstacle course, note what works and what could be better, and then share your creation. This is the moment where your work becomes real - when other people experience something you made.

Coming Up: Mission 1.5 Preview

  • Complete multiple full playthroughs of your course
  • Identify areas for improvement
  • Learn the playtesting mindset
  • Share your game with classmates
  • Celebrate your first completed game!

Save your project one more time (Ctrl + S). You are about to become a game developer with a finished game to show!

planets.title: Play Your Game
planets.description: Test your mini-course and share your screen with the class
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 1.5: Play Your Game

You are no longer just a student learning software. You are a game developer with a finished game. In the next 15 minutes, you are going to experience your creation as a player, look at it with fresh eyes, and then do something that takes real courage: show it to other people.

Every professional game developer goes through this moment - the transition from building to playing, from creator to critic, from private project to public showcase. Some of the most valuable lessons come not from building, but from watching others play what you built. Today, you join that tradition.

Real Talk: Sharing your work can feel scary. What if someone does not like it? What if they find a bug? Here is the truth: every game has bugs at first, and feedback is how games get better. The developers of your favorite games went through this exact process hundreds of times. You are in good company.

Your Mission

Learning Objective: Test your complete mini-course, make adjustments based on playtesting, and share your creation with classmates.

What You Will Accomplish

  • Play through your entire course multiple times
  • Identify what works well and what could be improved
  • Make at least one adjustment based on playtesting
  • Share your screen and let classmates see your game
  • Celebrate completing your first Roblox game!

Step-by-Step Instructions

Step 1: Do a Complete Playtest

It is time to play your game like you have never seen it before. Try to forget that you built it.

  1. Save your project (Ctrl + S)
  2. Click Play
  3. Start from the spawn point and play through your entire course
  4. Try to reach the victory platform
  5. Complete the course at least 3 times

Playtester Mindset: While playing, ask yourself: Is this fun? Is it too easy? Too hard? Does anything feel unfair? Would a new player understand what to do? These questions are what professional playtesters ask.

Step 2: Take Mental Notes

As you play, notice these things:

Jump Difficulty

  • Did you make every jump on the first try? (Might be too easy)
  • Did you fail the same jump 5+ times? (Might be too hard)
  • Did the difficulty increase gradually? (Good design!)

Visual Clarity

  • Could you always see where to jump next?
  • Was the danger zone clearly visible and avoidable?
  • Did the victory platform stand out as the goal?

Feel and Flow

  • Did the course feel satisfying to complete?
  • Were there any frustrating moments?
  • Did you want to play again after finishing?

Step 3: Make At Least One Improvement

Based on your playtest, make at least one change. Here are common improvements:

If a jump was too hard:

  • Move the platforms slightly closer together
  • Make the landing platform slightly bigger
  • Lower the height difference between platforms

If it was too easy:

  • Increase the distance between platforms
  • Make landing platforms smaller
  • Add height changes to make jumps trickier

If something was confusing:

  • Make the danger zone larger so it is more visible
  • Change the victory platform to a brighter color
  • Reposition platforms so the path is clearer

Your Turn!

Click Stop, make one improvement to your course, then Play again to test your change. Does it feel better? Worse? Keep iterating until you are happy!

Step 4: Understand the Iteration Loop

What you just did has a name in game development: iteration. It is the most important process in making games:

1 Build

Create something

2 Test

Play it yourself

3 Observe

Notice what works and what does not

4 Improve

Make changes

5 Repeat

Go back to step 2

This loop never really ends. Even published games get updates and patches. The best game developers are the ones who are always willing to iterate and improve.

Step 5: Prepare to Share Your Screen

It is time to show your classmates what you built! Here is how to prepare:

  1. Save your project one final time (Ctrl + S)
  2. Make sure you are in Play mode so others can see the game running
  3. Position your character at the start of the course
  4. When your teacher calls on you, share your screen

Presentation Tip: When sharing, give a quick intro: "This is my obstacle course. The goal is to jump across the platforms to reach the green finish line. The red floor is a kill brick - touch it and you restart!" Then play through your course.

Step 6: Share and Learn from Others

Sharing is a two-way street. Here is what to do:

When Showing Your Game:

  • Play through your course while others watch
  • If you fail a jump, that is okay! It shows the game has challenge
  • Point out features you are proud of
  • Be open to feedback - it helps you improve!

When Watching Others:

  • Pay attention to what they did differently than you
  • Notice good ideas you might want to use later
  • Be encouraging! Everyone is learning
  • If you have constructive feedback, share it kindly

Learning from Others: Seeing how your classmates solved the same challenge differently is incredibly valuable. Maybe someone made their kill brick a different shape. Maybe someone's platforms form an interesting pattern. Take mental notes!

Reflection Questions

After sharing, think about these questions:

  1. What was the hardest part of building this game?
  2. What are you most proud of?
  3. What would you do differently next time?
  4. What did you learn from watching your classmates' games?
  5. What feature would you want to add if you had more time?

Mission Complete?

Final checklist for this mission and the entire star:

Completion Checklist

  • I played through my complete course at least 3 times
  • I identified at least one thing that could be improved
  • I made at least one improvement based on playtesting
  • I shared my screen and showed my game to classmates
  • I watched at least one classmate's game

Star 1 Complete! Full Review

Look at everything you accomplished in Star 1:

  • Installed Roblox Studio
  • Created a baseplate project
  • Inserted and positioned parts
  • Built a jumping course with multiple platforms
  • Wrote your first Lua script
  • Created a kill brick that actually works
  • Designed a victory zone with visual meaning
  • Playtested and iterated on your design
  • Shared your creation with others

CONGRATULATIONS! You Are Now a Game Developer!

You started this star knowing nothing about Roblox Studio. Now you have a working, playable game with platforms, danger, and a goal. You wrote real code. You applied game design principles. You playtested and improved your work. You shared your creation with others.

This is not just a tutorial exercise - this is the real process that professional game developers use every single day. You should be proud!

What Comes Next

You have proven you can build an obstacle course. But right now, it is just gray platforms on a baseplate. In Star 2, we are going to make it personal.

In Star 2: Island Vision, you will research your local area using satellite imagery from Google Maps. You will trace the shape of your island or town, identify real landmarks, and plan an obstacle course that tells the story of YOUR place. By the end of this course, you will have a game that represents where you live!

Coming Up: Star 2 Preview

  • Navigate Google Maps to find satellite views of your local area
  • Identify the distinctive shape of your island or town
  • Select real landmarks that will become obstacle stations
  • Create a narrative reason for your runner game

Before You Go

  • Save your project - You will build on this foundation
  • Remember your login - You will need it next session
  • Be proud - You built something real today

See you in Star 2, game developer!

stars.title: Island Vision
stars.description: Research and plan your personalized island runner

planets.title: Satellite Exploration
planets.description: Navigate Google Maps to find the best satellite view of your local area
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 2.1: Satellite Exploration

Imagine you're a pilot flying high above your hometown, looking down at the streets you walk every day. From up here, everything looks different. Your school becomes a tiny rectangle. The park where you hang out transforms into a patch of green. Roads become thin lines connecting it all together. This is the view satellites capture from space, and today, you're going to become an expert at finding and navigating this bird's-eye perspective of your world.

What will your neighborhood look like from space? Let's find out.

Mission Objective

Navigate Google Maps satellite view to locate and capture a clear aerial image of your local area that will become the foundation of your island runner game.

Estimated time: 20 minutes

Your Satellite Mission

Every great game designer starts with research. Before you can build your island runner in Roblox, you need to study the real geography you're recreating. Google Maps satellite view gives you access to the same technology that helps pilots navigate, urban planners design cities, and yes, game developers create realistic environments.

Step 1: Launch Your Satellite View

Open your web browser and navigate to maps.google.com. You'll see the familiar map interface with roads, labels, and colored regions. But we're going to switch to something much cooler.

  1. Look for the Layers button in the bottom-left corner of the map
  2. Click on it and select Satellite from the menu
  3. Watch your map transform from a diagram into a photograph taken from space

Try It: First Impressions

When you first switch to satellite view, take a moment to explore wherever the map is currently showing. Notice how buildings cast shadows. See how you can tell the difference between grass, concrete, and water just by color and texture. This is real photography captured by satellites orbiting Earth.

Step 2: Navigate to Your Territory

Now it's time to find your local area. You have several options for getting there:

Option A: Use the Search Bar

  • Click the search bar at the top of the screen
  • Type your school address, your home address, or a well-known landmark near you
  • Press Enter and watch Google Maps fly you to that location

Option B: Use Your Location

  • Look for the small circular button with a target/crosshair icon (usually on the right side)
  • Click it to center the map on your current location
  • You may need to give your browser permission to access your location

Option C: Manual Navigation

  • Click and drag the map to pan around
  • Use the + and - buttons to zoom in and out
  • Navigate your way to your local area like a true explorer

Navigation Tip

You can also use your mouse wheel or trackpad to zoom in and out. Scroll up to zoom in, scroll down to zoom out. This is much faster than clicking the + and - buttons once you get the hang of it.

Step 3: Find the Perfect View

Now comes the fun part: finding the absolute best satellite view of your area. This isn't just about zooming in randomly. You're looking for a view that tells a story and gives you interesting geography to work with.

What Makes a Great View?

  • Clear boundaries: Can you see where your neighborhood ends? Is there a coastline, a river, a major road, or a park that creates a natural border?
  • Interesting landmarks: Do you see recognizable buildings, parks, sports fields, or unique features?
  • Variety of terrain: The best game maps have different types of areas - maybe you have buildings, green spaces, water, and roads all visible
  • Good scale: Zoom to a level where you can see details but also get a sense of the whole area. Too close and you'll only see one building; too far and everything becomes a blur

Try It: The Goldilocks Zoom

Zoom all the way out until your entire town is just a small dot. Now zoom all the way in until you can see individual cars in a parking lot. The perfect zoom level is somewhere in between - where you can see about 10-20 buildings or city blocks at once. This gives you enough detail to plan with, while showing how everything connects together.

Adjust Your Perspective

Google Maps lets you do more than just zoom. Try these advanced controls:

  • Tilt view: Hold Shift and drag the mouse to tilt the view and see buildings from an angle (works best in urban areas)
  • Rotate: Hold Ctrl (or Cmd on Mac) and drag to rotate the map to face a different direction
  • Street View: Drag the little yellow person icon onto any blue-highlighted road to see a ground-level photo view

For your island runner, you'll want a straight-down overhead view (the default), but it's worth experimenting with these controls to see your area from every angle.

Step 4: Capture Your Satellite Image

Once you've found the perfect view, it's time to save it. You'll need this image later when you start building in Roblox Studio. Taking a screenshot is your mission-critical task here.

How to Take a Screenshot

The exact method depends on your device:

Windows PC:
  • Method 1: Press Windows Key + Shift + S to open the Snipping Tool. Click and drag to select just the map area.
  • Method 2: Press Print Screen to capture the entire screen, then paste into Paint and crop
  • Method 3: Use the Snipping Tool app from the Start menu
Mac:
  • Method 1: Press Command + Shift + 4, then click and drag to select the map area
  • Method 2: Press Command + Shift + 3 to capture the entire screen
  • Screenshots automatically save to your Desktop
Chromebook:
  • Method 1: Press Ctrl + Shift + Show Windows (the key with a rectangle and two lines), then select an area
  • Method 2: Press Ctrl + Show Windows to capture the full screen

Screenshot Success Tips

  • Before taking the screenshot, hide any unnecessary labels or UI elements if Google Maps allows it
  • Make sure the entire area you want is visible on screen
  • Save your screenshot with a clear name like "my_island_satellite.png" so you can find it later
  • Save it in a folder dedicated to your island runner project

What to Capture

Your screenshot should include:

  • An area roughly 0.5 to 2 square kilometers (about 4-16 city blocks)
  • Clear identifiable landmarks you recognize
  • Natural or human-made boundaries that could define your game world's edges
  • A variety of terrain and features to make your game interesting

Try It: Multiple Options

Don't settle for your first screenshot. Take 3-4 different screenshots of your area at different zoom levels or from different locations nearby. You can choose the best one later. Maybe your school area is interesting, but so is the park near your house. Maybe a tight zoom on downtown is cool, but so is a wider view that includes the waterfront. Give yourself options!

Step 5: Study Your Territory

Now that you have your satellite image, take some time to really look at it. You're not just playing with maps - you're doing what real game developers do: location scouting and research.

Questions to Ask Yourself:

  • What's the most interesting feature you can see?
  • Where do you spend time in this area in real life?
  • What paths do people walk or drive through here?
  • What buildings or landmarks would make cool obstacle stations?
  • If you were running through this area in real life, what route would be the most fun?

These questions will help you in the next missions when you start planning your actual game route and identifying landmarks.

Real-World Connection

Game developers use satellite imagery and real-world locations all the time. Games like Grand Theft Auto recreate entire cities from satellite maps. Racing games scan real race tracks. Even fantasy games start with research into real castles, forests, and mountains. You're using the exact same tools and techniques that professional game developers use to create realistic, immersive game worlds.

Mission Check

Before you complete this mission, verify you have:

  • Successfully switched Google Maps to Satellite view
  • Navigated to your local area (school, neighborhood, or town)
  • Found a view that shows interesting landmarks and clear boundaries
  • Adjusted the zoom level to show a good balance of detail and context
  • Taken at least one clear screenshot of your satellite view
  • Saved the screenshot with a clear filename in an accessible location
  • Studied your screenshot and identified at least 2-3 recognizable landmarks

Next Mission: Shape Trace

You've captured your territory from above. Now it's time to identify the unique shape of your island or town. In Mission 2.2, you'll learn to recognize the distinctive outline that will define the boundaries of your game world. Every place has a shape - what's yours?

planets.title: Shape Trace
planets.description: Identify the distinctive outline shape of your island or town boundaries
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 2.2: Shape Trace

Manhattan is a rectangle. San Francisco is a square that got squished and bent. Italy is a boot. Every place has a shape, whether it's carved by ocean waves over millions of years or drawn by city planners with rulers and ambition. Your game world needs boundaries - edges where the playable area ends - and the best boundaries are ones that feel natural and make sense.

What shape is your island? Let's trace it and find out.

Mission Objective

Identify and trace the distinctive outline shape of your local area's natural or human-made boundaries that will define the edges of your island runner game world.

Estimated time: 15 minutes

Understanding Game Boundaries

Every game world has edges. In your island runner, players need to know where they can and can't go. The best boundaries feel natural and make sense in the context of your world. You don't want arbitrary invisible walls - you want logical borders that players understand intuitively.

Step 1: Open Your Satellite Image

Pull up the screenshot you saved from Mission 2.1. Look at it not as a map of places you know, but as a shape puzzle. Imagine you're looking at an island from an airplane, and you need to draw its outline.

Seeing Shapes

Try this visualization trick: Squint your eyes slightly or zoom out from your screen. This blurs the details and helps you see the bigger picture - the overall shape rather than individual buildings and streets. What outline emerges?

Step 2: Identify Boundary Types

Boundaries come in different forms. Some are created by nature, others by human design. Let's explore what kinds of boundaries might define your island's shape.

Natural Boundaries

These are geographic features created by nature:

  • Coastlines: Where land meets ocean, sea, or large lake - the most obvious island boundary
  • Rivers: Flowing water that creates a natural dividing line
  • Mountains or hills: Elevated terrain that creates a barrier
  • Forests or wooded areas: Dense green spaces that separate developed areas
  • Cliffs or elevation changes: Visible as shadows and color changes in satellite view

Human-Made Boundaries

These are borders created by people:

  • Major highways or roads: Thick lines that divide neighborhoods
  • Railway lines: Often run parallel and straight, creating clear divisions
  • Park boundaries: The edge where green park space meets urban development
  • School grounds or campus edges: Defined property lines
  • Neighborhood borders: Where one type of development ends and another begins
  • Bridges: Entry and exit points that could mark your island's connections

Try It: Boundary Hunt

Look at your satellite image and identify at least three different boundaries. Write them down. For each one, note whether it's natural or human-made, and whether it creates a clear visual line in the satellite image. The best boundaries are ones you can easily see from space.

Step 3: Choose Your Island's Edge

Now it's decision time. You need to choose which boundaries will define the edge of your playable game world. You have several options for how to approach this:

Option A: Natural Island

If you live near water, you might have an actual island or peninsula in your satellite image. This is the easiest option - the water creates an obvious boundary. Your game world starts at one shore and ends at another.

  • Pros: Clear, intuitive boundaries; visually striking; easy to understand
  • Cons: Only works if you have water in your area

Option B: Neighborhood "Island"

Even without water, you can create an island effect by choosing a defined neighborhood, school campus, or park area. Major roads or different types of land use become your "shores."

  • Pros: Works anywhere; lets you focus on a specific familiar area
  • Cons: Requires more creative thinking to make boundaries feel natural

Option C: Circuit Route

Choose a circular or loop route through your area. The "island" is everything inside the loop, with major roads or landmarks creating the circular boundary.

  • Pros: Great for creating running/racing routes; naturally loops back to start
  • Cons: May feel arbitrary if the loop doesn't follow clear geographic features

Option D: Bounded Rectangle

Choose four major boundaries (roads, rivers, park edges) that create a rectangular or square area. This is how many cities are actually planned and organized.

  • Pros: Simple and clear; easy to explain; works in grid-planned cities
  • Cons: Can feel less organic than curved or irregular boundaries

Making Your Choice

Ask yourself these questions:

  • What boundaries are most visible in my satellite image?
  • Which boundaries would make sense to a player who doesn't know my local area?
  • What shape would create the most interesting gameplay space?
  • Which option includes the landmarks I find most interesting?

Step 4: Trace Your Shape

Now comes the fun part - actually outlining your island's shape. You can do this digitally or on paper, whichever feels more comfortable.

Digital Tracing Method:

  1. Open your screenshot in any image editing program (Paint, Preview, Photoshop, GIMP, etc.)
  2. Select a bright, contrasting color (like red or yellow) that will show up clearly
  3. Use the pencil, pen, or brush tool to draw along the boundaries you've identified
  4. Don't worry about perfect precision - you're creating a rough outline, not a technical map
  5. Save this marked-up version with a new filename like "my_island_outline.png"

Paper Tracing Method:

  1. Print your satellite image (or display it on screen)
  2. Use a pen or marker to draw the boundary lines
  3. If your image is on screen, you can even hold up a piece of paper to the screen and trace through it
  4. Take a photo of your traced outline to save it digitally

Try It: Describe Your Shape

After you've traced your outline, step back and look at it. What does the shape remind you of? Is it a rectangle? A triangle? An irregular blob? A bent line? A circle? Come up with a one-sentence description of your island's shape. For example: "My island is a rounded rectangle with a bite taken out of the eastern side where the river cuts through."

Step 5: Consider Scale and Proportion

Now that you have your shape traced, let's think about whether it's the right size for your game.

Size Sweet Spot

Your island should be:

  • Big enough to include 5+ interesting landmarks (you'll choose these in the next mission)
  • Small enough that you can recognize most locations within it
  • Detailed enough in the satellite image that you can see individual buildings or features
  • Coherent enough that it feels like one connected area, not random scattered points

As a rough guide, good island runner maps typically cover an area you could walk across in 15-30 minutes in real life. That might be:

  • A school campus and surrounding few blocks
  • A neighborhood of 15-30 buildings
  • A park and adjacent streets
  • A small downtown area
  • An actual small island (if you're lucky enough to have one nearby!)

Too Big or Too Small?

If your traced shape feels too big (you've outlined your entire city), go back to Google Maps and zoom in to find a smaller, more focused area. If it feels too small (you've just outlined one building), zoom out and include more surrounding area. You want a Goldilocks zone - just right.

Step 6: Name Your Shape

This might seem silly, but naming your island shape helps you think about it as a distinct game world. Even if you're using your real neighborhood, giving it a creative name helps transition from "the place where I live" to "the world where my game takes place."

Naming Strategies:

  • Geographic descriptor: "Riverside Loop," "Harbor District," "School Campus Circle"
  • Shape-based: "The Triangle," "Crescent Island," "The Square Mile"
  • Landmark-based: "Parkview Territory," "Downtown Dash Zone," "The Academy Grounds"
  • Creative/Fantasy: "Phoenix Island," "Runner's Paradise," "The Challenge Circuit"

Try It: Three Name Options

Come up with three different possible names for your island. Try different naming strategies. Say each name out loud. Which one sounds best? Which one makes you excited to build this game world? You don't have to commit to one name yet, but brainstorming options helps you think creatively about your project.

Understanding Your Shape's Story

Every shape tells a story about how a place was formed. Is your island stretched along a coastline because that's where ships could dock? Is it a grid because city planners laid it out with efficiency in mind? Is it curved around a river that's been flowing the same path for thousands of years?

Understanding why your shape exists helps you understand your local area's history and geography. It also helps you make creative choices later when you're designing your game. Maybe that river becomes a barrier players have to cross. Maybe that highway becomes a dangerous zone to avoid. The real-world shape informs the game-world story.

Real-World Connection

Game designers call this process "level boundaries" or "playable area definition." In open-world games like Zelda or Grand Theft Auto, designers carefully choose where the game world ends. Sometimes it's water (you can't swim any farther). Sometimes it's mountains (too steep to climb). Sometimes it's just invisible barriers. By using real geographic boundaries from your satellite image, you're creating more believable and natural-feeling level boundaries for your island runner.

Mission Check

Before you complete this mission, verify you have:

  • Examined your satellite image to identify visible boundaries
  • Identified at least 3 different boundary types (natural or human-made)
  • Chosen which boundaries will define your island's edges
  • Traced the outline of your island shape (digitally or on paper)
  • Saved your traced outline image or drawing
  • Described your island's overall shape in a sentence
  • Verified your island is the right size (5+ landmarks possible)
  • Brainstormed at least one name for your island territory

Next Mission: Landmark Hunt

You've defined your island's boundaries. Now it's time to populate it with interesting destinations. In Mission 2.3, you'll select 5 real locations within your island that will become obstacle stations in your game. Time to go treasure hunting in your own backyard.

planets.title: Landmark Hunt
planets.description: Select 5 real locations that will become obstacle stations
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 2.3: Landmark Hunt

Every runner knows that a good course needs checkpoints - destinations that break up the journey and give you something to aim for. In a race, these might be water stations or kilometer markers. In your island runner game, they'll be obstacle stations built at real locations from your local area. That basketball court where you play pickup games? The weird statue in the park? The old church with the tall spire? Each of these could become a challenge point in your game.

Which 5 locations in your island deserve to become legendary obstacle stations? Let's find out.

Mission Objective

Select 5 distinctive real-world locations within your island boundaries that will become obstacle stations in your island runner game, ensuring good spatial distribution and gameplay variety.

Estimated time: 25 minutes

Understanding Obstacle Stations

In your island runner game, obstacle stations are special locations where players must complete a challenge before moving on to the next station. Think of them as mini-levels within your larger world. Each station needs to:

  • Be recognizable in the satellite image
  • Be visually distinctive from other stations
  • Inspire ideas for what kind of obstacle could go there
  • Fit logically into your island's overall geography

Step 1: Study Your Island

Pull up your satellite image with the traced boundary outline from Mission 2.2. You're going to study every detail of what's inside those boundaries, looking for standout locations.

Switch Perspectives

Look at your satellite image in Google Maps, but also toggle between Satellite view and regular Map view. The map view shows building labels, street names, and points of interest that might not be obvious from the satellite photo alone. A building that looks ordinary from above might be labeled as "Community Center" or "Historic Library" - instant landmark potential!

Step 2: Landmark Categories

Good obstacle stations come in many forms. Let's explore the types of landmarks you might find in your island, along with what makes each type special for game design.

Buildings & Structures

  • Schools: Large, rectangular, usually with sports fields - excellent for central hub stations
  • Churches/Temples: Distinctive architecture, often with towers or unique shapes
  • Libraries or Community Centers: Public buildings with cultural significance
  • Shopping Centers or Markets: Large footprints, lots of activity, busy zones
  • Stadiums or Arenas: Circular or oval shapes, massive scale
  • Unique Buildings: Anything with unusual shape, color, or historical significance

Outdoor Spaces

  • Parks: Green spaces visible from satellite, natural gathering places
  • Playgrounds: Small but distinctive, often with equipment visible from above
  • Sports Fields: Soccer fields, baseball diamonds, basketball courts - geometric and colorful
  • Plazas or Squares: Open urban spaces, often at intersections
  • Gardens or Green Spaces: Areas with distinctive landscaping patterns

Transportation & Infrastructure

  • Bridges: Dramatic crossing points over water or roads
  • Train or Bus Stations: Transit hubs where people gather
  • Parking Lots: Large paved areas (could become challenge arenas)
  • Roundabouts or Traffic Circles: Distinctive circular patterns
  • Harbors or Docks: Water-land interfaces with boats and piers

Natural Features

  • Beaches or Shorelines: Where land meets water
  • Hills or Elevated Points: Visible as terrain variation and shadows
  • Rivers or Streams: Flowing water creating linear features
  • Wooded Areas: Clusters of trees, darker green patches
  • Ponds or Lakes: Small bodies of water within your island

Try It: Category Scout

Set a timer for 5 minutes. During this time, identify as many potential landmarks as you can in your island, organizing them by category. Don't judge or filter yet - just find and list everything you can see. Try to find at least 10-15 possibilities. This gives you plenty of options to choose from in the next steps.

Step 3: Selection Criteria

You probably found more than 5 potential landmarks. Now comes the hard part: choosing which ones make the final cut. Use these criteria to evaluate each candidate:

1. Visual Distinctiveness

Can you clearly see and identify this landmark in the satellite image? The best landmarks have:

  • Unique shapes (circles, triangles, unusual geometry)
  • Different colors than surroundings (green park vs. gray buildings)
  • Distinctive patterns (sports field lines, parking lot rows)
  • Notable size (much bigger or smaller than nearby structures)

2. Personal Connection

Do you have a relationship with this place? The best landmarks are ones you know:

  • Places you visit regularly
  • Locations with memories or stories attached
  • Spots your friends would recognize
  • Landmarks that mean something to your community

3. Obstacle Potential

Can you imagine what kind of obstacle course could exist here? Think about:

  • What the space offers (open area, vertical structure, water nearby?)
  • What activities happen here in real life
  • What challenges fit the location's character
  • How the real-world function could inspire game mechanics

4. Spatial Distribution

Where is this landmark relative to others? Good station placement means:

  • Stations spread across your island, not all clustered together
  • Roughly even distances between consecutive stations
  • Coverage of different areas and terrain types
  • Natural flow from one station to the next

The Magic Number: Why 5?

Five stations is the sweet spot for your first island runner. It's enough to create a real journey with variety, but not so many that you'll spend forever building. Five stations also creates good pacing - start, three middle challenges, and a finale. As you gain experience, you can always add more stations later, but start with five to keep your project manageable and achievable.

Step 4: The Selection Process

Now let's systematically narrow down your list of potential landmarks to the final five.

Round 1: Must-Haves

Look at your list of potential landmarks. Are there any that are absolute must-haves? These might be:

  • The most iconic or recognizable landmark in your area
  • A place with deep personal significance
  • The most visually striking feature in your satellite image
  • A location that perfectly captures what your island is about

Mark 1-2 landmarks as definite selections. These are your anchors - the rest of your stations will be chosen to work well with these.

Round 2: Spatial Balance

Open an image editor or grab a pen and your printed satellite image. Mark the locations of your must-have landmarks. Now divide your island into rough zones (north/south/east/west, or quadrants, or however makes sense for your shape).

Look for landmarks that fill in the gaps:

  • If your must-haves are in the north, choose stations in the south
  • If you have east and west covered, find something central
  • Aim for a distribution where stations feel spread out, not clumped

Round 3: Variety Check

Look at the landmarks you've selected so far. Do you have variety in types? Ideally, your five stations should include different categories:

  • Mix buildings with outdoor spaces
  • Include both large and small landmarks
  • Combine natural features with human-made structures
  • Balance public spaces with distinctive architecture

Variety keeps your game interesting and showcases different aspects of your island.

Round 4: Final Picks

If you're down to exactly 5 landmarks, great! If you still have more, make your final cuts based on:

  • Which ones you're most excited to build
  • Which ones create the best route flow (we'll explore this in Mission 2.4)
  • Which ones you can most clearly see in your satellite image
  • Which ones feel most essential to representing your island

Try It: The Elevator Pitch

For each of your 5 selected landmarks, write a one-sentence description that captures what makes it special. For example: "The old brick library with the copper dome where the city was founded." Or: "The basketball court behind the school where everyone plays after class." These sentences help you articulate why each landmark deserves its spot in your game.

Step 5: Mark Your Stations

Now make your selections visible and concrete.

Digital Marking Method:

  1. Open your satellite image with the traced boundary in an image editor
  2. Choose a bright, easily visible color (different from your boundary line)
  3. Place numbered markers (1, 2, 3, 4, 5) at each landmark location
  4. The numbers don't have to represent route order yet - just label them for reference
  5. Make the markers big enough to see clearly
  6. Save this version as "my_island_landmarks.png" or similar

Paper Marking Method:

  1. Print your satellite image or use your previously marked version
  2. Use stickers, stars, or numbered circles to mark each landmark
  3. Write the landmark name next to each marker
  4. Take a photo of the marked-up map to save it digitally

Backup Choices

Keep your list of runner-up landmarks somewhere safe. If you discover later that one of your five stations doesn't work well (maybe it's too close to another, or you can't think of a good obstacle for it), you'll want backup options ready to swap in. Don't delete that brainstorming list!

Step 6: Create Your Landmark Registry

Professional game designers keep detailed documentation of all important locations in their game worlds. Let's create a simple registry for your landmarks.

Open a text document, note-taking app, or piece of paper and create entries for each landmark with this information:

Landmark Registry Template:

LANDMARK #1: [Name]
Type: [Building/Outdoor Space/Natural Feature/Infrastructure]
Description: [One sentence capturing what it is]
Why I chose it: [Personal connection or visual appeal]
Satellite characteristics: [What makes it visible from above]
Obstacle ideas: [Initial thoughts - can be vague for now]

LANDMARK #2: [Name]
[Repeat for all 5 landmarks]

This registry serves multiple purposes:

  • Documents your design decisions
  • Helps you remember why you chose each location
  • Creates a reference guide for when you start building
  • Gives you a place to brainstorm obstacle ideas

Try It: Stranger's Perspective

Imagine someone who has never visited your island is looking at your satellite image with the 5 landmarks marked. Based only on what they can see from above, would they understand why you chose each landmark? If not, think about what makes each location special beyond what's visible in the satellite image. This hidden context will enrich your game design and might inspire obstacle ideas later.

What Makes a Landmark Legendary?

The best landmarks in games aren't just visually interesting - they tell stories and create memories. Think about iconic game locations you remember:

  • The first castle in Super Mario Bros - simple but unforgettable
  • Hyrule Castle in Zelda - visible from anywhere, drawing you toward it
  • The lighthouse in BioShock - a beginning and an ending point

Your landmarks have the advantage of being real places with real history and significance. A game location based on the park where your community gathers for festivals has built-in meaning. The school where generations of students have learned carries weight. The bridge that connects two neighborhoods tells a story of connection.

Don't underestimate the power of local significance. To someone from across the world, your landmarks might seem ordinary. But to you and your community, they're special - and that specialness will shine through in how you design and build them.

Real-World Connection

Game developers call these kinds of memorable locations "POIs" - Points of Interest. In open-world games, POIs serve as navigation waypoints, quest locations, and memorable setpieces that make the game world feel rich and explorable. By selecting your 5 landmarks, you're doing exactly what developers at companies like Nintendo, Rockstar, and Ubisoft do when designing game worlds: identifying the locations that will anchor the player's experience and create a sense of place.

Mission Check

Before you complete this mission, verify you have:

  • Studied your satellite image to identify potential landmarks
  • Listed at least 10-15 possible landmark locations
  • Evaluated candidates using selection criteria (visual, personal, spatial, variety)
  • Selected exactly 5 landmarks for your obstacle stations
  • Ensured good spatial distribution across your island
  • Included variety in landmark types and categories
  • Marked all 5 landmarks on your satellite image (numbered or labeled)
  • Created a Landmark Registry with details for each location
  • Written at least one sentence explaining what makes each landmark special
  • Saved your marked-up satellite image showing all landmarks

Next Mission: Story Your Route

You have your island boundaries. You have your 5 landmark stations. But right now they're just disconnected dots on a map. In Mission 2.4, you'll connect these landmarks into a meaningful route and create a narrative reason for why a runner would travel through them. Every great game has a story - what will yours be?

planets.title: Story Your Route
planets.description: Create a narrative reason for running through these landmarks
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 2.4: Story Your Route

A race without a purpose is just running in circles. But give that race a story - a treasure hunt, a rescue mission, a festival tour, a challenge from a rival - and suddenly every step matters. The difference between a forgettable game and a memorable one often comes down to one question: Why am I doing this? In this mission, you'll answer that question for your island runner.

Why would someone run through your five landmarks? What's the story that connects them? Let's create it.

Mission Objective

Create a narrative context and logical route progression that connects your 5 landmarks into a cohesive running journey with clear motivation, sequence, and story arc.

Estimated time: 25 minutes

Understanding Game Narrative

Story in games doesn't always mean complex plots with dialogue and cutscenes. Sometimes the story is simple: "Race to the finish." "Find all the stars." "Escape before time runs out." Even these simple premises give players motivation and make their actions feel meaningful.

Your island runner needs a narrative hook - a reason for the journey. This mission will help you craft that hook and arrange your landmarks into a route that supports your story.

Step 1: Choose Your Story Type

Let's start by exploring different narrative frameworks that could work for your island runner. Each type creates different player motivation and suggests different route structures.

Story Type A: The Tour

Premise: The player is taking a tour of the island's most important or interesting locations.

Examples: "Welcome to Island - Visit the 5 Wonders," "New Student Orientation Tour," "The Historic Landmarks Trail"

Best for: Islands with diverse landmark types that showcase different aspects of your area

Route logic: Order landmarks to create a natural touring sequence, perhaps starting with an introduction point and ending at a vista or gathering place

Story Type B: The Challenge

Premise: Someone has issued a challenge - complete obstacle courses at 5 locations to prove yourself.

Examples: "The Ultimate Island Challenge," "Parkour Master Trial," "Beat the Island Record"

Best for: Islands with athletic spaces (parks, fields, courts) that suggest physical challenges

Route logic: Order landmarks by increasing difficulty, or create a circuit that tests different skills at each station

Story Type C: The Quest

Premise: The player is searching for something, and each landmark provides a clue or piece leading to the next location.

Examples: "The Island Treasure Hunt," "Solving the Mystery," "Finding the Lost Artifact"

Best for: Islands with landmarks that have interesting history or unique characteristics

Route logic: Create a sequence where each location logically leads to the next, building toward a climactic final location

Story Type D: The Race

Premise: A competitive race through checkpoints across the island, possibly against time or other runners.

Examples: "Island Marathon Challenge," "The Great Race," "Beat the Clock Circuit"

Best for: Islands with clear paths between landmarks and good geographic flow

Route logic: Minimize backtracking, create efficient paths, consider distance between checkpoints

Story Type E: The Journey

Premise: The player is traveling from one end of the island to the other, experiencing different neighborhoods or zones along the way.

Examples: "From Shore to Shore," "East to West Adventure," "The Island Crossing"

Best for: Islands with clear geographic progression (coastline to inland, downtown to residential, etc.)

Route logic: Start at one edge or corner, end at the opposite, with landmarks distributed along the path between

Story Type F: The Festival/Event

Premise: There's a special event happening, and participants must visit 5 festival stations across the island.

Examples: "Island Festival Challenge," "Carnival Circuit," "Community Celebration Run"

Best for: Islands with public gathering spaces and community landmarks

Route logic: Visit locations in any logical order, or create a circuit that returns to the starting festival grounds

Try It: Story Brainstorm

Look at your 5 landmarks. Which story type feels like the most natural fit? Write down 2-3 specific story ideas using different types. For example: "The Historic Downtown Tour" (Type A), "The Parkside Challenge" (Type B), or "The Lost Mascot Mystery" (Type C). Don't commit yet - just brainstorm possibilities.

Step 2: Order Your Landmarks

Now that you have some story ideas brewing, it's time to decide the order in which players will visit your 5 landmarks. This is your route sequence.

Choosing Your Start Point (Station 1)

The first landmark players visit sets the tone for the entire journey. Good starting points are:

  • Welcoming and open: A park, plaza, or entrance point that feels like a natural beginning
  • Clearly defined: Easy to recognize and locate in the satellite image
  • Positioned well: Located so that it can lead naturally toward other landmarks
  • Story-appropriate: Fits your narrative (a tour starts at an information point, a race starts at a start line, etc.)

Choosing Your End Point (Station 5)

The final landmark should feel like a destination and provide a sense of completion:

  • Climactic: Something special or impressive that feels like an achievement to reach
  • Conclusive: A location that provides natural closure (high point, special building, return to start)
  • Memorable: Players should feel satisfied when they arrive here
  • Story-appropriate: Completes your narrative arc

Ordering the Middle Stations (2, 3, 4)

The three middle landmarks create the journey between start and finish. Consider:

  • Geographic flow: Does the route make sense on the map, or does it require confusing backtracking?
  • Distance variation: Mix shorter and longer distances between stations to create pacing variety
  • Terrain diversity: If possible, vary the types of landmarks (building, park, field, etc.) as players progress
  • Narrative rhythm: Build tension, provide variety, or create a pattern that supports your story

The Route Line Test

Pull up your satellite image with marked landmarks. Using a different color from your previous markings, draw lines connecting your landmarks in your proposed order: 12345. Does the route look reasonable? Or does it zigzag all over the place? A good route has clear direction and flow, though some doubling back can add interest.

Common Route Patterns

  • Linear: Straight progression across the island (A B C D E)
  • Circular/Loop: End point returns to or near start point (creates a circuit)
  • Star Pattern: Hub in center with spokes to outer landmarks
  • Spiral: Gradually work inward or outward from center
  • Figure-8 or S-curve: Weaving pattern across island

None of these patterns is inherently better than others - the best pattern is the one that serves your story and makes geographic sense for your specific landmarks.

Try It: Three Different Routes

Using your 5 landmarks, create three completely different route sequences. Maybe one goes clockwise around your island, another goes straight across, and a third spirals inward. Draw all three on your map (use different colors or labels). Which route feels best? Which tells the most interesting story? Which flows most naturally?

Step 3: Develop Your Narrative

You have your story type and your route order. Now let's flesh out the narrative details that will make your island runner feel purposeful and engaging.

Create Your Story Hook

Write a 2-3 sentence "story hook" that explains what the player is doing and why. This is what would appear in your game's introduction or menu screen.

Example hooks:

  • "Welcome to Harbor Island! To become an official Island Guide, you must complete the 5-Point Tour, visiting every major landmark and proving your knowledge of our home."
  • "The Island Challenge has been issued! Only those who complete obstacle courses at all 5 legendary training grounds can claim the title of Island Champion."
  • "The Island Festival trophy has been hidden somewhere on the island. Follow the clues at 5 festival stations to discover its location!"

Your Story Hook

Write your story hook now. Remember:

  • Keep it simple and clear
  • Explain the goal (visit 5 landmarks)
  • Provide motivation (why does the player care?)
  • Set the tone (adventurous, competitive, exploratory, etc.)
  • Use your island's actual characteristics and landmarks

Name Each Station

Beyond just "Landmark 1" or "The Park," give each station a name that ties into your narrative and makes it feel special.

Examples:

  • If your story is a challenge: "The Park Parkour Course," "The Library Climb," "The Bridge Sprint"
  • If your story is a tour: "Welcome Plaza - The Starting Point," "Historic Library - Culture Stop," "Harbor View - Final Vista"
  • If your story is a quest: "First Clue - The Old Oak," "Second Trial - The Stone Bridge," "The Final Answer - Summit Point"

These names serve multiple purposes:

  • Make each location memorable and distinct
  • Reinforce your story theme
  • Give you clear labels to use when building in Roblox later
  • Help players understand each location's role in the journey

Write Station Descriptions

For each of your 5 stations (in route order), write a short description (2-3 sentences) that includes:

  • What the location is in the real world
  • What it represents in your game story
  • What the player will do there (even if you don't know exactly what obstacle yet)

Example:

Station 1: Memorial Park - Journey's Beginning
This peaceful park in the heart of downtown marks the traditional starting point for all Island Challenges. Here, runners warm up with basic parkour training among the old oak trees. Complete the introductory obstacle course to prove you're ready for the journey ahead.

Consistency is Key

Make sure your station descriptions all support the same story. If Station 1 talks about "ancient island traditions" but Station 3 mentions "modern competitive racing," your narrative feels disjointed. Keep the tone, vocabulary, and premise consistent across all five stations.

Step 4: Map Your Route

Now let's create the final, definitive route map that shows your complete island runner journey.

Creating Your Route Map
