  1. Open your satellite image (the one with landmarks marked from Mission 2.3)
  2. If you experimented with multiple route orders, choose your final sequence now
  3. Relabel your landmarks with their final route numbers and story names:
    • Station 1: [Story Name]
    • Station 2: [Story Name]
    • Station 3: [Story Name]
    • Station 4: [Story Name]
    • Station 5: [Story Name]
  4. Draw route lines connecting the stations in sequence: 12233445
  5. Use arrows to show direction of travel
  6. Make the route path visually distinct (thick line, bright color, etc.)

Your final route map should clearly show:

  • Your island boundary from Mission 2.2
  • All 5 stations with numbers and names
  • The path connecting them in sequence
  • Direction arrows showing route flow

Add a Title and Legend

Make your map official by adding:

  • A title at the top: "[Your Island Name] - [Your Story Name]"
  • A simple legend explaining what the markings mean
  • Your name as the designer
  • The date you created it

This might seem like extra work, but documentation is crucial in game development. Future you (when you're building in Roblox) will appreciate having a clear, labeled map to reference.

Step 5: Consider Travel Between Stations

Your route isn't just about the stations themselves - it's also about the journey between them. Let's think about what players experience while traveling from station to station.

Distance and Pacing

Look at your route map. Estimate the distance between each pair of consecutive stations:

  • Station 1 Station 2: [Short/Medium/Long distance]
  • Station 2 Station 3: [Short/Medium/Long distance]
  • Station 3 Station 4: [Short/Medium/Long distance]
  • Station 4 Station 5: [Short/Medium/Long distance]

Ideally, you want variety in these distances. A route where every segment is exactly the same length can feel monotonous. Mix it up when possible.

Terrain and Obstacles

What lies between your stations? Look at your satellite image along each route segment:

  • Are there roads to cross?
  • Open parks to run through?
  • Buildings to navigate around?
  • Water to potentially bridge?

These environmental features will become part of your game world later. For now, just note them. They'll influence how you build your island in Roblox Studio.

Try It: Imagine the Journey

Close your eyes and imagine actually running your route in real life. Start at Station 1. What do you see as you travel to Station 2? What landmarks pass by? What does the environment change to? Walk through the entire route mentally, noting interesting features along the way. These observations will enrich your later building work.

Step 6: Compile Your Design Document

You've done tremendous planning work. Now let's organize it all into a clear design document that you'll reference throughout the building phase.

Your Island Runner Design Document

Create a document (digital or paper) with the following sections:

1. Project Overview
  • Island name
  • Story type
  • Story hook (2-3 sentence premise)
  • Design date
  • Your name as designer
2. Island Map
  • Your complete satellite image showing boundary, stations, and route
  • Title and legend included
3. Station Guide

For each station in route order:

  • Station number and story name
  • Real-world landmark name and type
  • Story description (2-3 sentences)
  • Why you chose this location
  • Initial obstacle ideas (even if vague)
4. Route Notes
  • Total number of stations: 5
  • Route pattern (linear, loop, etc.)
  • Start point justification
  • End point justification
  • Special environmental features along route
5. Future Ideas
  • Potential obstacles for each station
  • Environmental details you want to include
  • Extra landmarks for possible future expansion
  • Any other creative ideas that came up during planning

Save Everything

Your design document is your game's blueprint. Save it somewhere safe and accessible. When you start building in Roblox Studio (in the next Star), this document will guide every decision you make. Professional game developers create documents like this for every project - you're learning real industry practice.

The Power of Story in Games

Why does story matter so much in a game about running and obstacles? Because story creates meaning. Without a story, your island runner is just "go to these five places." With a story, it becomes "complete the Island Challenge" or "discover the hidden treasure" or "explore your hometown's wonders."

Story also helps you make design decisions. When you're building in Roblox later and you're not sure what color to make something or which obstacle fits better, you can ask: "What serves the story?" The story becomes your guide.

Even simple stories create player investment. When players understand why they're running through your island, they care about completing the journey. And when players care, they remember the experience.

Real-World Connection

Narrative designers in game companies do exactly what you just did: they create story frameworks that give players motivation and direction. They sequence levels to create story arcs. They name locations to reinforce themes. They write descriptions that make players care about virtual places. The design document you created is the same kind of document that professionals use to communicate vision and keep development teams aligned. You've just completed genuine narrative design work.

Celebrate Your Planning

You've completed all four missions in the Island Vision star. Look at what you've accomplished:

  • Captured satellite imagery of your real local area
  • Identified the distinctive shape of your island territory
  • Selected 5 meaningful landmarks for obstacle stations
  • Created a story that connects them into a purposeful journey
  • Designed a complete route with clear sequence and flow
  • Documented everything in a professional design document

This is no small feat. Many game projects fail because developers skip the planning phase and jump straight to building. You've done the smart thing: you've researched, designed, and documented before touching any building tools. This foundation will make the actual construction process smoother, faster, and more focused.

Take a moment to appreciate your design. Share it with friends, family, or classmates if you want. Show them your route map and explain your story. Their reactions will tell you if your narrative is clear and compelling.

And get excited - because in the next star, you'll start bringing this plan to life in Roblox Studio.

Mission Check

Before you complete this mission, verify you have:

  • Reviewed all story type options and chosen one that fits your island
  • Selected a starting landmark (Station 1) with clear justification
  • Selected an ending landmark (Station 5) that provides closure
  • Ordered all 5 landmarks into a logical route sequence
  • Drawn the complete route on your satellite map with directional arrows
  • Created a story hook (2-3 sentences) explaining the premise
  • Given each station a story-appropriate name
  • Written a description for each station explaining its role
  • Verified your route makes geographic sense and flows well
  • Compiled a complete design document with all planning elements
  • Saved your final route map with title, legend, and labels
  • Noted interesting environmental features along your route

Congratulations - Star 2 Complete!

You've finished Island Vision! You've researched your local area from a satellite perspective, identified meaningful locations, and crafted them into a story-driven route. Your island runner exists now as a complete design - it just needs to be built.

Next Star: World Building Round 1

In the next star, you'll open Roblox Studio and begin the actual construction process. You'll import your satellite image as a reference, create the basic terrain and shape of your island, and start placing the foundations for your 5 stations. Your research and planning are about to become a playable 3D world.

Before moving on, make sure you have:

  • Your satellite image saved and accessible
  • Your route map with all 5 stations labeled
  • Your design document completed
  • Roblox Studio installed and ready

Take a break, celebrate your planning work, and get ready to build. The real fun is about to begin!

stars.title: World Building Round 1
stars.description: Expand your course into an island-shaped world

planets.title: Reference Image Setup
planets.description: Import your satellite screenshot as a decal in the world to guide building
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 3.1: Reference Image Setup

Remember that satellite screenshot you saved in Star 2? It's time to bring it into your world. Not as a second screen or a printout on your desk, but as an actual object in your 3D workspace. Professional game developers use reference images like this all the timethey place them right in the scene so they can build around them, checking proportions and shapes as they work.

You're about to learn a crucial workflow technique: using decals as building guides. By the end of this mission, your satellite image will be lying flat on the ground in Roblox Studio, ready to serve as your blueprint for island construction.

Mission Objective

Import your satellite screenshot as a decal placed flat on the ground in your Roblox world to guide your island building process.

Success Criteria: Your satellite image appears as a decal on a horizontal part in your workspace, clearly showing your island's shape and landmarks.

Why Reference Images Matter

Building 3D environments from memory or imagination alone is difficult. Professional 3D artists and level designers use reference images constantlythey import photos, sketches, and maps directly into their 3D software to guide their work. This technique ensures accuracy, saves time, and helps you stay focused on your original vision.

In our case, your satellite screenshot contains all the information you need: the island's overall shape, the location of landmarks, how paths connect different areas, and the scale relationships between features. By placing this image in your world, you can literally build on top of it.

Step 1: Prepare Your Reference Platform

Before you can add a decal, you need a surface to place it on. We'll create a large, flat part that will hold your satellite image.

Create the base part:

  1. In the Home tab, click the Part button to insert a new part
  2. With the part selected, look at the Properties panel
  3. Find the Size property
  4. Change the size to 200, 1, 200 (this creates a large, thin platform)
  5. In the Position property, set it to 0, 0.5, 0 to place it at ground level

Understanding Part Dimensions

Roblox parts use Size values in the format X, Y, Z where X is width, Y is height, and Z is depth. Our setting of 200, 1, 200 creates a very wide, very flat, square platformperfect for displaying an image.

Step 2: Organize Your Workspace

Before importing your image, let's organize this part properly so your workspace doesn't get messy as your project grows.

  1. Right-click on the part in the Explorer panel
  2. Select Rename
  3. Name it ReferenceImagePlatform
  4. In the Properties panel, find Anchored and check the box (this prevents it from falling or moving during testing)

Step 3: Import Your Satellite Screenshot

Now comes the exciting partbringing your satellite image into Roblox Studio.

Upload your image:

  1. In the Explorer, make sure your ReferenceImagePlatform is selected
  2. In the Home tab, find the Insert section
  3. Click Decal (this inserts a decal as a child of your selected part)
  4. Look in the Exploreryou should see "Decal" nested under your platform part
  5. With the Decal selected, look at the Properties panel
  6. Find the Texture property
  7. Click the small icon next to the Texture field
  8. In the Asset Manager that opens, click Add Image
  9. Navigate to where you saved your satellite screenshot from Star 2
  10. Select the image and click Open
  11. Wait for the image to upload (you'll see a progress indicator)
  12. Once uploaded, click the image thumbnail to apply it to your decal

Image Upload Requirements

Roblox accepts common image formats like PNG, JPG, and BMP. The upload may take a few moments depending on your internet connection. Once uploaded, the image is stored in your account and can be reused in any project.

Step 4: Orient the Decal Correctly

By default, the decal might appear on the wrong face of your part. We want it lying flat on the top surface so you can look down at it like a map.

  1. With the Decal selected in the Explorer, look at Properties
  2. Find the Face property
  3. Change it to Top
  4. Your satellite image should now be visible on the top surface of the platform

Try It: Adjust Your View

Press F on your keyboard to focus the camera on your reference platform. Then hold the right mouse button and use WASD keys to fly above it and look straight down. You should see your satellite image clearly displayed, showing your island's shape and features. This bird's-eye view is how you'll work as you build.

Step 5: Fine-Tune the Reference Setup

Let's make a few final adjustments to make this reference as useful as possible.

Optimize your reference platform:

  1. Select your ReferenceImagePlatform in the Explorer
  2. In Properties, find Transparency
  3. Set it to 0.3 (this makes the part slightly transparent so you can see if you accidentally build inside it)
  4. Find the CanCollide property
  5. Uncheck it (this prevents the platform from blocking your character during testing)
  6. Find Color and set it to white or a light gray (this ensures the color doesn't tint your satellite image)

Creating a Reference Folder

For better organization, you can create a folder in the Workspace called "BuildingReferences" and move your platform into it. Right-click in the Explorer, select Insert Object, choose Folder, rename it, then drag your reference platform into that folder. This keeps your main workspace clean as you add terrain and structures.

Understanding Your New Workflow

What you've just created is a professional-level workflow tool. As you build your island in the next missions, you'll constantly refer back to this image. You'll match the outline of your terrain to the coastline in the photo. You'll position landmarks where they appear in the satellite view. You'll create paths that follow the routes visible in your reference.

This isn't "cheating"it's exactly how real game developers work. They gather references, import them into their tools, and use them to guide accurate, thoughtful construction.

Try It: Test Your Reference Scale

Insert a new part into your workspace (don't worry about being precisejust drop one in). Move it around above your reference image. Notice how you can use the satellite photo to judge where things should go? That's the power of in-world references. You can always see your plan while you work.

Common Issues and Solutions

Issue: My decal isn't showing up at all.

Solution: Check that the Decal object is a child of your platform part in the Explorer. Also verify the Face property is set to "Top" and the Texture property shows your uploaded image.

Issue: The image looks stretched or distorted.

Solution: Your satellite screenshot might not be square. Try adjusting your platform's size to match your image's proportions. If your image is wider than it is tall, make the X value larger than the Z value (e.g., 250, 1, 200).

Issue: I can't find my saved satellite image.

Solution: Go back to Star 2 and take a new screenshot. Make sure to save it somewhere memorable like your Desktop or Documents folder. You can also create a "Roblox Project Assets" folder to keep all your game development files organized.

Mission Check

Before moving forward, verify you've completed these requirements:

  • Created a large, flat platform part (200x1x200 or similar)
  • Uploaded your satellite screenshot from Star 2 to Roblox
  • Applied the image as a decal on the TOP face of your platform
  • Set the platform to be anchored, non-collidable, and slightly transparent
  • Can clearly see your island's shape and landmarks in the reference image
  • Can navigate your camera to view the reference from directly above

If you can check all these boxes, you're ready to start building actual terrain.

Next Mission Preview

Your reference is in place. Your satellite image is now a physical object in your 3D world, ready to guide your work. In Mission 3.2, you'll use this reference to create the actual terrain foundations of your islandbuilding the rough landmass shape that matches what you see in your satellite photo. You'll learn about terrain tools and part-based building techniques to bring your island from 2D image to 3D reality.

Coming up: Terrain Foundationscreating the base shape of your island world.

planets.title: Terrain Foundations
planets.description: Use parts or terrain to create the rough shape of your island from the reference
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 3.2: Terrain Foundations

Your satellite reference is lying on the ground, showing you exactly what your island should look like. Now comes one of the most satisfying moments in game development: taking that flat 2D image and building it up into a three-dimensional world.

This is where your island starts to feel real. You're not just planning anymoreyou're constructing. Every game world starts this way: with rough foundations that capture the basic shape before details get added. Think of yourself as a sculptor working with digital clay, building up the landmass that will eventually become your complete island runner course.

Mission Objective

Create the rough shape of your island using parts or terrain tools, matching the outline and basic form shown in your satellite reference image.

Success Criteria: Your island's landmass roughly matches your reference image's shape when viewed from above, with basic elevation changes in place.

Choosing Your Building Method

Roblox gives you two main approaches for creating terrain: using basic parts (blocks) or using the terrain system. Each has advantages, and we'll explore both so you can choose what works best for your project.

Parts Method

Pros: Easier to control, simple to adjust, great for beginners, works well for stylized/blocky islands

Cons: Less organic-looking, requires more pieces for complex shapes

Terrain Method

Pros: Natural-looking results, good for organic shapes, powerful sculpting tools

Cons: Steeper learning curve, harder to make precise changes

For this mission, we'll focus on the parts method because it's more beginner-friendly and gives you direct control. You can always enhance with terrain later.

Step 1: Analyze Your Reference

Before building, take a moment to really study your satellite reference. Understanding what you're building makes the process much easier.

Look for these key features:

  1. Press F while your reference platform is selected to focus on it
  2. Position your camera directly above, looking straight down
  3. Identify the overall shape of your islandis it circular? Elongated? Irregular?
  4. Notice where the land appears higher or lower (shadows often indicate hills)
  5. Spot major features like beaches, forests, or developed areas
  6. Estimate rough proportionsis one side wider than the other?

Thinking in Shapes

Complex shapes are made of simple ones. Does your island look like a circle with a peninsula attached? An oval with a bite taken out? Breaking your island down into basic geometric shapes makes it much easier to build.

Step 2: Create Your Base Island Structure

Start with a single large part that captures the very basic footprint of your island.

Build the main landmass:

  1. In the Home tab, click Part to insert a new part
  2. In Properties, rename it to IslandBase
  3. Move the part above your reference image (you should be able to see both)
  4. Adjust the part's Size to roughly match your island's overall dimensions
  5. Start with something like 150, 10, 120 and adjust based on your reference
  6. Set Anchored to checked
  7. Set Position Y value to 5 so the bottom sits at ground level

Try It: Toggle Reference Visibility

Select your reference platform in the Explorer and look at Properties. Check and uncheck the Transparency value between 0 and 1 to hide and show your reference. This helps you see how your terrain looks on its own versus compared to the reference.

Step 3: Refine the Outline

Your island probably isn't a perfect rectangle. Now we'll add more parts to capture the actual shape.

Add additional parts to match your outline:

  1. Look at your referencewhere does your island extend beyond your base part?
  2. Insert additional parts and position them to fill in those areas
  3. Where your island is smaller than the base, we'll address that in a moment
  4. Use the Move and Scale tools to position parts precisely
  5. Make sure all terrain parts have Anchored checked
  6. Name each part descriptively: IslandNorthSection, IslandPeninsula, etc.

Working with Overlapping Parts

It's perfectly fine for your terrain parts to overlap each other. In fact, this is often easier than trying to make them fit together perfectly. The important thing is the overall silhouette when viewed from above matches your reference.

Step 4: Add Basic Elevation

Real islands aren't flat. Let's create some basic height variation to make your island more interesting.

Create hills or elevated areas:

  1. Study your reference for areas that appear darker or show shadows (these are often higher ground)
  2. Insert new parts where you want elevated areas
  3. Make these parts smaller in X and Z dimensions but taller in Y
  4. Position them on top of your base terrain
  5. Example: 60, 20, 60 creates a hill-sized elevation
  6. Name these parts clearly: CentralHill, NorthRidge, etc.

Create lower areas (beaches or shores):

  1. Beaches appear lighter in satellite images (sand reflects more light)
  2. Insert thin, flat parts around your island's edges
  3. Example size: 40, 1, 20 creates a beach-like strip
  4. Position them just above or at water level (Y position around 1-2)
  5. These will serve as your coastal zones

Step 5: Organize Your Terrain

As you add parts, your Explorer panel gets messy. Let's keep things organized.

  1. In the Explorer, right-click in the Workspace
  2. Select Insert Object and choose Folder
  3. Name it IslandTerrain
  4. Drag all your island parts into this folder
  5. Your reference platform should stay separate (in a different folder or loose in Workspace)

Step 6: Compare and Iterate

The key to good reference-based building is constant comparison. Let's develop that workflow.

Check your work:

  1. Position your camera directly above your island, looking down
  2. Zoom out until you can see your whole island and most of the reference
  3. Look for areas where your terrain doesn't match the reference outline
  4. Ask yourself: Is the general shape right? Are the proportions similar?
  5. Make adjustments: move parts, resize them, add new ones, or delete ones that aren't working

Perfect vs. Good Enough

At this stage, you're creating foundations, not final terrain. Your island doesn't need to match your reference perfectlyit needs to match roughly. You'll add details and refinements throughout the rest of this Star. Right now, aim for "clearly recognizable as the same island" rather than "exactly identical."

Understanding Scale in Game Development

One challenge you might face is scale. Your reference image represents a real place that might be hundreds of meters across. But in your game, you need it to be playablebig enough to feel like an island but small enough that players can traverse it in a reasonable time.

Here's a useful guideline: Roblox characters are about 5 studs tall. A part that's 100 studs across takes about 10 seconds to run across. Use this to judge your island size. For a runner game, you probably want your island to be 200-500 studs acrosslarge enough for an interesting course but not so huge that it takes minutes to traverse.

Try It: Test the Scale

Press the Play button in the Test section of the Home tab. When your character spawns, run around on your island terrain. Does it feel too big? Too small? Stop the test (press the Stop button) and adjust your terrain part sizes accordingly. This trial-and-error process is normal and important.

Bonus: Introduction to Terrain Tools

If you're feeling adventurous, you can experiment with Roblox's built-in terrain system alongside or instead of parts.

Access terrain tools:

  1. In the Home tab, find the Terrain section
  2. Click Generate to create an initial terrain area, or use Add to manually sculpt
  3. The Add tool lets you paint terrain material (grass, sand, rock) directly into your world
  4. Adjust the brush size and strength in the Terrain Editor panel
  5. Use your reference image to guide where you paint land versus leaving empty space (which becomes water)

Terrain Tips for Beginners

Start with a large brush size to quickly block out the general shape, then switch to smaller brushes for details. The Grow tool is useful for expanding terrain areas, while Erode smooths out blocky edges. Don't worry about making it perfectterrain sculpting is an art that improves with practice.

Common Building Challenges

Challenge: My parts keep falling when I test the game.

Solution: Make sure every terrain part has Anchored checked in Properties. Anchored parts ignore gravity and stay exactly where you place them.

Challenge: I can't see my reference image anymore under all my terrain parts.

Solution: Select all your terrain parts (click one, then hold Ctrl and click others) and in Properties, adjust Transparency to something like 0.3-0.5. This makes them semi-transparent so you can see through to your reference below.

Challenge: My island shape doesn't match my reference well.

Solution: This is normal in early stages. Focus on getting the general proportions right first. Also, take a screenshot of your reference and draw over it in a simple paint program to outline the basic geometric shapes you seethis makes it easier to recreate in 3D.

Mission Check

Verify your island foundations are ready before continuing:

  • Created a base landmass that roughly matches your island's footprint
  • Added additional parts to capture the overall shape of your island
  • Included at least one elevated area (hill) and one lower area (beach/shore)
  • All terrain parts are anchored and organized in a folder
  • When viewed from above, your terrain clearly resembles your reference image's outline
  • Tested scale by running around on your islandit feels appropriately sized

Your island doesn't need to be perfect, but it should be recognizable as the place in your satellite photo.

Next Mission Preview

You've built the bones of your islandthe basic landmass is in place. But right now it probably looks pretty bland: gray blocks sitting on the ground. In Mission 3.3, you'll learn about part properties like materials, colors, and transparency. You'll transform those dull gray blocks into grass-covered hills, sandy beaches, and rocky cliffs. Your island is about to start looking like an actual place.

Coming up: Part Properties Deep Diveadding visual variety and realism to your terrain.

planets.title: Part Properties Deep Dive
planets.description: Explore materials, colors, and transparency for variety
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 3.3: Part Properties Deep Dive

Look at your island right now. If you're like most beginners, it's a collection of gray blocks roughly shaped like your satellite reference. It's functional, but it doesn't look like a real place yet. This is where the magic happens.

Professional environment artists use a technique called "material definition"using surface properties to tell players what things are made of and how they should feel. A sandy beach doesn't just look different from a grassy hill because of color; it has different texture, reflectivity, and visual character. You're about to learn how to create that distinction in Roblox, turning your gray prototype into a vibrant, believable world.

Mission Objective

Apply appropriate materials, colors, and transparency settings to your island terrain parts to create distinct visual zones that communicate what each area represents.

Success Criteria: Your island has clear visual variety with at least 3 different materials applied, colors that feel natural, and appropriate use of properties to create environmental atmosphere.

Understanding Materials in Roblox

Every part in Roblox has a Material property that controls how its surface looks. Materials aren't just about colorthey define texture, how light reflects, and the overall visual character of an object.

Roblox provides dozens of materials, but for natural environments, these are the most useful:

  • Grass: Perfect for fields, hills, and natural areas
  • Sand: Beaches, desert areas, sandy paths
  • Ground: Dirt paths, exposed earth, brown terrain
  • Rock: Cliffs, boulders, mountain areas
  • Slate: Refined stone, paved areas, urban zones
  • Concrete: Modern structures, pathways, developed areas
  • Wood: Bridges, platforms, wooden structures
  • Leafy Grass: Lush vegetation, forest floors

Step 1: Apply Materials to Base Terrain

Let's start by defining what your main terrain areas are made of.

Add materials to your island base:

  1. Select your IslandBase part (or whatever you named your main landmass)
  2. In the Properties panel, scroll to find Material
  3. Click the dropdown and select Grass
  4. Notice how the part immediately changesit now has a grass texture instead of smooth gray
  5. Rotate your camera around the part to see how the material looks from different angles

Material Visual Characteristics

Each material has its own texture pattern that repeats across the surface. The pattern scale is automatic based on the part's size. Very large parts will show the texture pattern more clearly, while small parts might only show a portion of the pattern.

Step 2: Create Environmental Zones

Now let's use different materials to create distinct areas on your island, based on what you see in your reference image.

Identify and material-ize your zones:

  1. Look at your satellite referenceidentify different terrain types
  2. Coastal areas: Select beach/shore parts and apply Sand material
  3. Elevated areas: Select hill parts and try Grass or Rock depending on what your reference shows
  4. Forest/dark areas: Use Leafy Grass or darker Ground material
  5. Developed areas: If your island has buildings or roads, use Concrete or Slate

Try It: Material Experimentation

Select one of your terrain parts and rapidly switch between different materials using the Material dropdown. Notice how dramatically the part's character changes? Cobblestone feels medieval, Concrete feels modern, Glacier feels cold and remote. Materials communicate feeling, not just appearance.

Step 3: Apply Color for Atmosphere

Materials provide texture, but color adds life and specificity. Let's learn to use color thoughtfully.

Add color to your terrain:

  1. Select a grass-material part
  2. In Properties, find Color (sometimes labeled as BrickColor)
  3. Click on the color swatch to open the color picker
  4. Choose a natural greennot too bright, not too dark
  5. Apply different shades of green to different grass areas for variety
  6. For sand parts, try warm yellows or light tans
  7. For rock areas, use grays, browns, or dark earth tones

Color Theory for Game Environments

Natural environments rarely use pure, saturated colors. Real grass isn't bright lime green; it's a muted, slightly brownish green. Real sand isn't pure yellow; it has gray or orange undertones. When choosing colors, think about what you see in nature. Slightly desaturated colors usually look more realistic than vivid ones.

Step 4: Create Variety Within Zones

Real environments aren't uniform. A forest doesn't have every tree the exact same shade of green. Let's add subtle variation.

Vary your colors:

  1. Select multiple parts in the same zone (hold Ctrl while clicking)
  2. Notice that when multiple parts are selected, Properties shows their shared properties
  3. Change each part's color individually to slightly different shades
  4. For example, make some grass parts more yellow-green, others more blue-green
  5. Keep the variations subtlethey should feel like natural variation, not like different zones

Step 5: Explore Advanced Properties

Beyond material and color, Roblox parts have other properties that affect appearance. Let's experiment with the most useful ones.

Transparency:

  1. Find the Transparency property (value from 0 to 1)
  2. 0 = completely solid (opaque)
  3. 1 = completely invisible (transparent)
  4. Try setting a water part to transparency 0.5 for a glass-like effect
  5. Use slight transparency (0.1-0.2) on distant terrain for atmospheric depth

Reflectance:

  1. Find the Reflectance property (value from 0 to 1)
  2. Controls how mirror-like a surface is
  3. Try setting a rock part to 0.3 for wet-looking stone
  4. Use on water parts for a reflective surface
  5. Most natural terrain should have low reflectance (0-0.2)

When to Use Advanced Properties

Transparency and reflectance are powerful but should be used sparingly. Too much transparency makes your world feel ghostly and undefined. Too much reflectance makes everything look wet or plastic. Use these properties for specific effects: water, glass, wet surfaces, or magical elements.

Step 6: Create Visual Hierarchy

In environment design, important areas should stand out while background areas recede. Let's use properties to create this hierarchy.

Establish focal points:

  1. Identify where your first landmark will be (from Mission 3.4)
  2. Make terrain around that area slightly brighter or more saturated
  3. Use a more interesting materialperhaps Slate instead of plain Ground
  4. For distant background terrain, use more muted colors and simpler materials
  5. This guides players' eyes toward important gameplay areas

Understanding Visual Consistency

While variety is important, so is consistency. Your island should feel like one cohesive place, not a random collection of parts. Here are guidelines for maintaining visual consistency:

  • Color palette: Choose 4-6 main colors and use variations of those throughout
  • Material logic: Use materials that make sense together (grass + sand + rock feels natural; grass + neon + ice feels random)
  • Transition zones: Where two different materials meet, consider adding a transition (ground between grass and sand)
  • Lighting consideration: Remember that Roblox's lighting will affect how your colors looktest in actual gameplay

Try It: The Squint Test

Zoom your camera way out so your entire island is visible. Squint your eyes (or blur your vision slightly). Do you see clear zones of different colors and textures? Or does everything blend together? If it all blends, you need more variety. If it looks chaotic, you need more consistency. This "squint test" is a real technique artists use to check visual hierarchy.

Creating an Environmental Mood

The properties you choose create an overall feeling or mood. Let's think about what mood fits your island.

Tropical paradise: Bright grass colors, light sand, high saturation, clean materials

Mysterious forest: Dark greens, browns, Leafy Grass material, low saturation

Rocky highlands: Grays, browns, Rock and Slate materials, rough textures

Coastal town: Mix of natural (grass, sand) and built (concrete, wood), varied colors

Look at your satellite reference. What mood does that real place have? Use your material and color choices to evoke that same feeling.

Common Design Pitfalls

Pitfall: Using too many different materials (10+ materials on a small island).

Solution: Limit yourself to 4-6 main materials. More materials can make your world feel cluttered and unfocused. Master a small palette before expanding.

Pitfall: Using extremely bright or saturated colors everywhere.

Solution: Bright colors should be accents, not the base. Most of your world should use medium saturation, with pops of brightness in important areas.

Pitfall: Every part being completely opaque and solid.

Solution: Experiment with subtle transparency (0.1-0.3) on some parts to create depth and atmosphere, especially on distant or decorative elements.

Mission Check

Confirm your island has proper visual development:

  • Applied at least 3 different materials to different terrain zones
  • Used colors that feel natural and appropriate to your island type
  • Created subtle color variation within similar zones (not every grass part identical)
  • Experimented with transparency or reflectance on at least one part
  • Your island has visual zones that are distinct but still feel cohesive
  • Tested in play modematerials and colors look good during actual gameplay

Your island should now look significantly more developed and believable than it did at the end of Mission 3.2.

Next Mission Preview

Your island foundations are built and visually defined. Now it's time to add gameplay. In Mission 3.4, you'll take one of the landmarks from your satellite referencemaybe a playground, a building, a rock formation, whatever you identified in Star 2and transform it into an actual obstacle area in your runner game. You'll learn to create structures, arrange them for gameplay flow, and turn a static environment into an interactive challenge.

Coming up: First Landmark Zonebuilding your first gameplay area with obstacles and challenges.

planets.title: First Landmark Zone
planets.description: Transform your first real landmark into an obstacle area
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 3.4: First Landmark Zone

You've built the island. You've made it look believable. Now comes the most exciting part: making it playable. This is where environment building meets game designwhere you stop thinking like a landscape artist and start thinking like a level designer.

Every great platformer has memorable locations. Think about games you've played: the castle level, the forest ruins, the industrial zone. These aren't just decorationsthey're challenges built into recognizable places. You're about to do the same thing with a real location from your own neighborhood. That playground from your satellite image? It's about to become a jumping challenge. That parking lot? Maybe it's now a maze of obstacles. This is where your local island becomes your personal game world.

Mission Objective

Build one landmark from your satellite reference as an interactive obstacle area that players can navigate, jump through, or overcome as part of your runner course.

Success Criteria: A recognizable landmark structure with at least 3 distinct obstacles, tested for playability, that feels fun to navigate.

Choosing Your First Landmark

Back in Star 2, you identified several landmarks on your island. Now you need to pick one to build first. Here's what to consider:

Good first landmarks:

  • Distinct, recognizable structures (playgrounds, buildings, monuments)
  • Areas with natural height variation (hills, structures with levels)
  • Locations that are relatively simple in shape (not too many complex details)
  • Places you remember well or have personal connection to

Landmarks to save for later:

  • Extremely complex architecture (save until you're more experienced)
  • Landmarks that require scripting to function (moving parts, interactive elements)
  • Very small or very large features (harder to balance gameplay)

Select your landmark:

  1. Look at your satellite reference in Roblox Studio
  2. Review the landmarks you identified in Star 2
  3. Choose one that excites you and seems buildable
  4. Take a moment to imagine how players might move through it

Step 1: Position Your Landmark Zone

Before building, decide where on your island this landmark should sit.

  1. Look at your reference image to see where this landmark is located in real life
  2. Find that corresponding area on your 3D island terrain
  3. Insert a single part as a placeholder/marker
  4. Name it LandmarkMarker_[name] (e.g., LandmarkMarker_Playground)
  5. Position it where your landmark will be centered
  6. This helps you maintain accurate placement as you build

Step 2: Break Down the Landmark

Professional level designers don't build everything at once. They break complex structures into simple components. Let's do that.

Analyze your landmark:

  1. If possible, look up additional photos of this landmark online or recall what it looks like in person
  2. Identify the main geometric shapes: rectangles? Cylinders? Wedges?
  3. List the main components (e.g., playground = slide, swing set, climbing structure, platform)
  4. Decide which components are essential and which can be simplified or omitted
  5. Sketch a quick mental map of how these components relate spatially

Simplification is Not Cheating

You don't need to recreate every detail of the real landmark. A building might have 100 windows in real lifein your game, 6-8 windows might be enough to communicate "building." A playground might have 15 different pieces of equipmentyou might build 4-5 key pieces. Game design is about capturing the essence, not replicating every detail.

Step 3: Build the Base Structure

Start with the largest, most fundamental component of your landmark.

Create the foundation:

  1. Identify the main "body" of your landmark (the biggest or most central part)
  2. Insert a part and scale it to roughly match that component's size
  3. Position it near your landmark marker
  4. Apply appropriate material and color (brick for buildings, plastic for playground equipment, etc.)
  5. Make sure it's Anchored
  6. Name it descriptively: Playground_MainPlatform or Building_MainStructure

Step 4: Add Platforming Elements

Now transform your structure from a static object into a gameplay space. This is where level design thinking becomes crucial.

Create your first obstacle:

  1. Insert a new part near your base structure
  2. Size it as a platform: about 8, 1, 8 studs (big enough to land on)
  3. Position it higher than your base structure by about 5-7 studs (this is a comfortable jump height)
  4. Anchor it, apply material/color, and name it Landmark_Platform1
  5. This is your first jumping platform

Jump Height Guidelines

Roblox characters can jump about 7.5 studs high. For comfortable gameplay:

  • Easy jump: 4-5 studs high
  • Medium jump: 6-7 studs high
  • Challenging jump: 7-8 studs high (requires timing)

For horizontal gaps, characters can jump about 10-12 studs forward. Start with gaps of 5-6 studs to be safe.

Add more obstacles:

  1. Create 2-3 more platforms at varying heights
  2. Arrange them so players must jump from one to another in sequence
  3. Think about flow: left to right? Spiral upward? Player's choice of routes?
  4. Use the Move tool to position platforms precisely
  5. Leave gaps between platforms (4-8 studs) that require jumping

Step 5: Add Landmark Character

Right now you have gameplay platforms, but they might not look much like your real landmark. Let's add recognizable details.

Build identifying features:

  1. What makes this landmark distinctive? (A specific shape, color, or structure?)
  2. Add parts that communicate these features
  3. For a building: add walls, windows (using decals or colored parts), a roof shape
  4. For a playground: add slide shapes (wedges), swing chains (cylinders), recognizable equipment
  5. These parts don't all need to be functional obstaclessome can be purely visual
  6. Use materials and colors to reinforce what the landmark is

Balancing Form and Function

Some parts serve gameplay (platforms to jump on). Some parts serve recognition (details that make it look like the real place). The best landmark designs integrate both: a building's windowsills become ledges to jump to, a playground's equipment becomes the obstacle course itself.

Step 6: Test Your Landmark

This is the most important step. A landmark that looks great but plays poorly isn't meeting your goal.

Playtest your creation:

  1. Click the Play button in the Test section
  2. When your character spawns, navigate to your landmark
  3. Try to jump through the obstacles you created
  4. Ask yourself: Is this fun? Is it too easy? Too hard? Frustrating?
  5. Are any jumps impossible? Are any platforms too small to land on?
  6. Can you find the intended path, or is it confusing?
  7. Click Stop when done testing

Iterate based on testing:

  1. If jumps are too hard: lower platforms, move them closer together, or make landing zones bigger
  2. If jumps are too easy: increase height, increase gaps, or make platforms smaller
  3. If the path is confusing: add visual guides (brightly colored parts showing the route)
  4. Make your adjustments, then test again
  5. Repeat this test-adjust cycle until it feels right

The Three-Test Rule

Professional game designers test their levels at least three times before considering them done. First test: identify major issues (impossible jumps). Second test: refine difficulty (too easy or hard). Third test: polish experience (does it feel fun?). Don't skip testingthis is where good levels become great ones.

Step 7: Organize Your Landmark

As you build, your Explorer gets cluttered. Let's keep things organized.

  1. In the Explorer, create a new Folder in Workspace
  2. Name it Landmark_[name] (e.g., Landmark_Playground)
  3. Drag all parts related to this landmark into the folder
  4. You can create sub-folders inside for further organization (Platforms, Decorations, etc.)
  5. Delete your landmark marker partyou don't need it anymore

Adding Variety to Obstacles

Not every obstacle needs to be a simple platform. Let's explore different types of challenges you can create with basic parts.

Moving platforms: For now, just parts to jump acrossyou'll add movement with scripting in Star 4

Narrow ledges: Long, thin parts (like 10, 1, 2) that require careful landing

Spiral paths: Platforms arranged in a circle, ascending around a central structure

Gaps with visual hints: Large gaps with decorative parts showing where to jump

Tiered challenges: An easy route and a hard route, letting players choose difficulty

Try It: Add One Advanced Obstacle

Choose one of the obstacle types above and add it to your landmark. Test it. Does it work? Is it fun? Even if you end up removing it, the practice of experimenting with different obstacle types is valuable. Game design improves through experimentation.

Connecting Landmarks to Environment

Your landmark shouldn't feel like it's floating in spaceit should feel integrated with the island terrain around it.

Integration techniques:

  1. Make sure your landmark sits properly on the terrain (not floating above or sunk below)
  2. Use the same or similar materials as nearby terrain to create visual cohesion
  3. Add a few decorative parts around the landmark (rocks, plants, paths) to blend it in
  4. Ensure the landmark's scale feels appropriate relative to the terrain

Common Landmark Design Mistakes

Mistake: Making every platform the exact same size and shape.

Solution: Vary your platform dimensions. Some can be large and safe, others small and challenging. Some can be round, others rectangular. Variety creates interest.

Mistake: Creating jumps that are only possible with perfect timing.

Solution: Unless you're intentionally creating an expert challenge, make jumps forgiving. Slightly bigger platforms and slightly shorter gaps make gameplay more accessible without feeling too easy.

Mistake: Building the landmark too large or too small relative to the character.

Solution: Test early and often. Run around your landmark with the character. Does it feel like a place a person could actually navigate? Scale issues are easier to fix early than after you've built 50 parts.

Mission Check

Verify your landmark is ready before proceeding:

  • Built a structure recognizable as your chosen real-world landmark
  • Created at least 3 distinct obstacles or platforms that require jumping/navigation
  • Tested the landmark by actually playing through it with your character
  • Adjusted obstacles based on testing (made jumps possible and reasonably fun)
  • Organized all landmark parts into a named folder in the Explorer
  • Landmark feels integrated with the surrounding island terrain
  • You're proud of itit represents both the real place and a fun gameplay challenge

Next Mission Preview

You have a landmark. You have terrain. But right now, they might not connect smoothly. In Mission 3.5, you'll build the crucial element that ties everything together: the path. You'll create a running route from your spawn point to your first landmark, learning how to guide players, create flow, and make navigation feel natural. This is where your island transforms from scattered locations into a cohesive runner course.

Coming up: Connect the Pathbuilding routes that guide players through your island world.

planets.title: Connect the Path
planets.description: Build a running path from spawn to your first landmark
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Mission 3.5: Connect the Path

Imagine playing a runner game where you spawn into the world with no idea where to go. You can see interesting structures in the distance, but there's no clear way to reach them. You wander aimlessly until you get bored and quit. This is what happens when level designers forget to create paths.

Paths aren't just walkwaysthey're silent guides. They're visual communication that says "go this way" without using words or arrows. Professional game designers spend enormous time on path layout because paths control pacing, create flow, and make players feel like they're on a journey rather than wandering randomly. You're about to learn these same techniques, connecting your spawn point to your landmark with a path that feels natural, clear, and exciting to follow.

Mission Objective

Build a clear, visually distinct path from your game's spawn point to your first landmark that naturally guides player movement and feels satisfying to traverse.

Success Criteria: A complete path with visual guidance elements, tested for clarity, that a new player can follow without confusion from spawn to landmark.

Understanding Spawn Points

Before you can build a path, you need to know where it starts. In Roblox, spawn points determine where players appear when they join your game.

By default, Roblox places a SpawnLocation in every new game. This is a special part (usually a gray platform) that marks where players spawn. When a player joins or respawns after falling, they appear standing on this part.

Locate or create your spawn point:

  1. Look in your Workspace Explorer for an object called SpawnLocation
  2. If you don't see one, insert it: Home tab > Gameplay section > Spawn
  3. Position your spawn point at the starting area of your island
  4. This should be away from your landmarkyou want players to travel to reach it
  5. Place it on stable ground, not floating in air or underwater
  6. Set its Position Y value a few studs above terrain (e.g., if terrain is at Y=5, spawn at Y=7)

Configure spawn properties:

  1. Select the SpawnLocation in Explorer
  2. In Properties, ensure Anchored is checked
  3. Find CanCollide and make sure it's checked (players need to stand on it)
  4. Set Transparency to 0.5 (semi-transparent, so it's visible but not obtrusive)
  5. The spawn has a property called Durationthis controls respawn time, keep it at default (10 seconds) for now

Spawn Point Placement Strategy

Place your spawn in a location that gives players a good view of where they should go. If possible, position it so that when they spawn, they're facing toward your landmark or the path entrance. This instant visual communication ("I should go that way") is crucial for good level design.

Step 1: Plan Your Path Route

Don't start building the path immediately. First, plan the route it will take.

Route planning:

  1. Look at your satellite referencedoes a natural path already exist between spawn and landmark?
  2. If yes, try to follow that real-world route (roads, sidewalks, trails)
  3. If no, design a route that feels natural to the terrain
  4. Avoid perfectly straight pathsslight curves feel more organic and interesting
  5. Consider what terrain the path crosses (flat ground? Up a hill? Around obstacles?)
  6. Estimate the path lengthaim for 10-20 seconds of running time

Path Design Principles

  • Clarity: Players should never wonder "where do I go next?"
  • Interest: The path should have some visual variety (not just a long straight hallway)
  • Pacing: The journey should feel purposeful, not tedious
  • Integration: The path should feel like it belongs in the environment, not randomly placed

Step 2: Build the Basic Path

Now let's construct the physical path itself.

Create path segments:

  1. Insert a new part near your spawn point
  2. Scale it to path-like dimensions: roughly 6, 0.5, 20 (wide enough to run on, thin, long)
  3. Position it starting at your spawn, pointing toward your landmark
  4. Apply a path-appropriate material: Concrete, Slate, Ground, or Wood depending on your island's theme
  5. Choose a color that contrasts with the surrounding terrain (so the path stands out)
  6. Anchor the part
  7. Name it Path_01

Extend the path:

  1. Duplicate your first path segment (Ctrl+D on Windows, Cmd+D on Mac)
  2. Move the duplicate to continue the path forward
  3. Overlap segments slightly so there are no gaps players could fall through
  4. Rotate segments as needed to create curves using the Rotate tool
  5. Continue duplicating and positioning until your path reaches the landmark
  6. Name subsequent segments Path_02, Path_03, etc.

Path Width Guidelines

A path width of 6-8 studs is comfortable for runningwide enough that players don't constantly fall off, narrow enough that it feels like a defined route. For challenge sections, you can make narrower paths (3-4 studs) that require more careful movement.

Step 3: Adjust for Terrain

Your path crosses varying terrain elevations. Let's make it conform naturally to the landscape.

Terrain-conform techniques:

  1. Where the path goes uphill, position path segments higher in the Y axis
  2. Create gentle slopes by positioning each segment slightly higher than the last
  3. Avoid sudden height changes (stairs-like jumps between segments)
  4. For steep hills, consider adding actual steps: smaller parts (like 6, 1, 3) arranged in a staircase
  5. Make sure each segment sits just above the terrain surface (0.5-1 studs above)

Try It: The Running Test

Hit Play and spawn into your world. Run along the path you've built so far. Does it feel smooth? Are there any gaps you fall through? Any bumps that stop your movement? Any confusing sections where you're not sure which way to go? Stop the test and fix these issues before continuing.

Step 4: Add Visual Guidance

A physical path is good. A path with clear visual signals is better. Let's add elements that guide the player's eye.

Create path markers:

  1. Insert small parts along the edges of your path
  2. Size them like posts or markers: 1, 3, 1 creates a thin vertical post
  3. Space them evenly along the path (every 15-20 studs)
  4. Apply a bright or contrasting color (if path is brown, make markers white or yellow)
  5. These markers create a visual rhythm that says "follow this route"
  6. Organize them in a folder called PathMarkers

Add directional hints:

  1. At path curves or intersections, add larger markers or differently colored parts
  2. You can use triangular parts (wedges) pointing in the direction players should go
  3. Home tab > Part dropdown > Wedge to insert triangular parts
  4. Rotate wedges to point along the path direction
  5. These subtle arrows guide players without being heavy-handed

The Breadcrumb Technique

Game designers use "breadcrumbing"leaving a trail of visual hints that draw players forward. This can be literal markers (like you just built), or it can be subtle: a line of trees, a color gradient, interesting objects spaced along the route. The key is creating a visual rhythm that pulls the eye forward, making players want to see what's next.

Step 5: Create Interest Along the Path

A path that's just a flat strip of concrete is functional but boring. Let's make the journey itself interesting.

Add path variations:

  1. Width changes: Make some sections wider (safe areas) and some narrower (challenge sections)
  2. Small obstacles: Place parts on the path that players must jump over (size 4, 1, 1 works well)
  3. Decorations: Add rocks, plants, or other thematic objects near the path edges
  4. Elevation variety: Include a few small jumps between path sections (2-3 stud gaps or height differences)
  5. Material changes: Transition from one material to another (concrete to wood, stone to dirt) to show progression

Pacing Through Path Design

The beginning of your path (near spawn) should be easy and clearthis teaches players how to navigate. The middle can introduce mild challenges (small jumps, narrow sections). Near the landmark, you can increase difficulty as a transition into the landmark's obstacles. This gradual difficulty curve feels natural and builds player confidence.

Step 6: Organize Your Path

Keep your workspace organized as path complexity grows.

  1. Create a folder in Workspace called MainPath
  2. Inside it, create sub-folders: PathSegments, PathMarkers, PathObstacles, PathDecorations
  3. Move all path-related parts into appropriate folders
  4. This organization makes it easy to hide/show path elements while building other areas

Step 7: Test Navigation Flow

Now test the complete experience: spawn to landmark via your path.

Complete playthrough test:

  1. Click Play in the Test section
  2. When you spawn, immediately look aroundcan you see the path? Is it obvious?
  3. Run along the path without jumping (just normal running)
  4. Do you ever feel lost or confused about direction?
  5. Time how long it takes to reach the landmark (should be 10-30 seconds)
  6. Does the journey feel too long? Too short? Just right?
  7. When you reach the landmark, does it feel like a satisfying arrival?

Iterate based on feedback:

  1. If you felt lost: add more visual guidance (markers, colors, directional hints)
  2. If the path felt too long: create a more direct route or remove unnecessary curves
  3. If the path felt too short: extend it or add more interesting elements along the way
  4. If the path was boring: add obstacles, variations, decorations
  5. Make adjustments and test again until the flow feels right

Advanced Path Techniques

Once your basic path works well, consider these advanced techniques.

Branching paths: Create two route optionsan easy, longer path and a harder, shorter path. Let players choose.

Checkpoint systems: Place spawn points along the path so players don't restart from the beginning if they fail.

Environmental storytelling: Use objects along the path to tell a story (ruins getting more intact as you travel, vegetation changing types, etc.).

Lighting guides: If you have advanced lighting knowledge, use brighter areas to draw players forward.

Try It: The New Player Test

If possible, have someone else (friend, classmate, family member) test your game. Watch them play without giving instructions. Do they naturally follow the path? Where do they get confused? Watching new players reveals design issues you might not notice yourself because you built it.

Connecting Path to Landmark

The path's endpoint at your landmark needs special attentionit's a transition point between navigation and gameplay challenge.

Create a landmark entrance:

  1. The last path segment should lead clearly into the landmark's first obstacle
  2. Consider adding a "threshold" marker: a different colored part or small archway that signals "you're entering the challenge zone"
  3. Make sure there's a clear, safe platform where the path meets the landmark
  4. The transition should feel natural, not abrupt

Common Path Design Issues

Issue: Players keep falling off the path.

Solution: Your path is either too narrow, has gaps between segments, or has sudden height changes. Widen the path, close gaps, and smooth elevation transitions.

Issue: Players don't notice the path and wander off in wrong directions.

Solution: Increase visual contrast. Make the path a very different color from terrain. Add more markers. Ensure the path is visible from the spawn point.

Issue: The path feels endless and tedious.

Solution: Add variety and pacing. Include small challenges, visual changes, decorations. Or simply shorten the pathsometimes less is more in level design.

Mission Check

Confirm your path system is complete:

  • Configured spawn point in a logical starting location
  • Built a continuous path from spawn to your first landmark
  • Path is visually distinct from surrounding terrain (clear material/color contrast)
  • Added visual guidance elements (markers, directional hints, or environmental cues)
  • Path includes some variety (not perfectly straight and flat throughout)
  • Tested complete spawn-to-landmark navigation multiple times
  • Path feels clear to follow without confusion
  • Journey takes an appropriate amount of time (10-30 seconds typical)
  • Organized all path elements in folders in Explorer

Star 3 Complete

You've transformed your satellite screenshot into a three-dimensional, playable world. You built terrain, added visual character through materials and colors, created a recognizable landmark with gameplay challenges, and connected everything with a path that guides players naturally. This is world-buildingthe foundation of level design.

Your island isn't finished (games are never truly finished), but it's now a functional runner course. A player can spawn, follow your path, reach a landmark, and navigate obstacles. That's a complete gameplay loop.

What You've Learned in Star 3:

  • Importing and using reference images in 3D workspace
  • Building terrain from 2D references to 3D forms
  • Using materials, colors, and transparency to create environmental character
  • Transforming real locations into playable game spaces
  • Designing obstacles and platforming challenges
  • Creating paths that guide player movement
  • Testing and iterating based on playtest feedback

Looking Ahead to Star 4: Scripting Essentials

Right now, your world is static. Parts don't move, nothing responds to player actions, and there's no way to track progress or create game logic. That's all about to change. In Star 4, you'll learn Lua scriptingthe programming language that brings Roblox games to life. You'll add moving platforms, create a timer system, spawn obstacles, and build interactive elements. Your static world will transform into a dynamic, reactive game.

But before you move on, take a moment to appreciate what you've built. Run through your island one more time. This place didn't exist a few missions ago. You created it from a satellite image, your planning, and your work. That's real game development.

stars.title: Scripting Essentials
stars.description: Add real game mechanics with Lua code

planets.title: Scripts and Output
planets.description: Create a Script, write print(), and find it in the Output window
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Your First Line of Code

Everything you've built so far - your island, your paths, your landmarks - they're all just sitting there, waiting. What if your game could actually do something? What if it could react, respond, and come alive?

Welcome to the world of coding. You're about to write your first script, and trust me - this is where the real magic begins.

Mission Objective

Create a Script, write print(), and find it in the Output window

What is a Script?

Think of a script like a recipe. Just like a recipe tells you step-by-step how to make cookies, a script tells Roblox step-by-step what to do in your game. Want a door to open when a player touches it? You need a script. Want to keep track of points? You need a script. Want your game to do literally anything interactive? You guessed it - scripts!

In Roblox, we write scripts using a programming language called Lua. Don't worry - Lua is one of the friendliest coding languages out there, designed specifically for games.

Step 1: Create Your First Script

  1. In the Explorer panel, find ServerScriptService
  2. Right-click on ServerScriptService
  3. Select Insert Object > Script
  4. A new script appears! Rename it to HelloWorld

Why ServerScriptService?

This is where we put scripts that run on the game server (the computer hosting your game). These scripts control the main game logic that everyone playing needs to follow. Later, you'll learn about other places to put scripts, but for now, ServerScriptService is your home base.

Step 2: Your First Line of Code

Double-click your HelloWorld script to open it. You'll see it already has some code in it - something that says print("Hello world!"). That's Roblox being helpful!

Let's understand what this code means:

print("Hello world!")

Breaking It Down Line by Line

  • print - This is a function (a pre-made tool) that displays messages
  • ( - The opening parenthesis starts the function's instructions
  • "Hello world!" - This is the message we want to display. The quotation marks tell Lua "this is text, not code"
  • ) - The closing parenthesis ends the function's instructions

Think of it like this: You're asking Lua to print something, and inside the parentheses, you tell it exactly what to print.

Step 3: Customize Your Message

Let's make this script your own! Change the message to something personal:

print("Welcome to my island runner!")
print("Get ready for an adventure!")
print("Created by [Your Name]")

Try It: Multiple Messages

Notice how we have three different print statements? Each one is its own line of code. Try adding your own messages! You can print anything you want - song lyrics, jokes, facts about yourself. Just remember to keep the text inside quotation marks.

Step 4: Find the Output Window

Now comes the exciting part - seeing your code work!

  1. At the top of Roblox Studio, click the View tab
  2. Click Output to open the Output window (if it's not already visible)
  3. The Output window usually appears at the bottom of your screen

The Output Window is Your Best Friend

Seriously. Every coder - beginner or expert - relies on the Output window. It's where you see messages from your code, and more importantly, it's where you see error messages that help you fix problems. Get comfortable with this window!

Step 5: Run Your Code

Time to see your code in action!

  1. Click the Play button at the top of Roblox Studio (the blue arrow)
  2. Look at the Output window
  3. You should see your messages appear!

It should look something like this:

Welcome to my island runner!
Get ready for an adventure!
Created by Alex

CONGRATULATIONS! You just wrote and ran your first code! That feeling you have right now? That's the feeling every programmer gets when their code works. Hold onto that.

Understanding What Just Happened

When you clicked Play, here's what happened behind the scenes:

  1. Roblox started running your game
  2. It looked in ServerScriptService for scripts to run
  3. It found your HelloWorld script
  4. It read each line of code from top to bottom
  5. When it saw print(), it sent those messages to the Output window

Experiment Time!

Try these experiments to learn more:

  • Change the order: Move your print statements around. What happens?
  • Break it (on purpose): Delete one of the quotation marks and run your code. What error message do you get? This is how you learn to debug!
  • Print numbers: Try print(42) without quotes. Numbers don't need quotes!
  • Do math: Try print(10 + 5). Lua can do calculations!

Common Mistakes (And How to Fix Them)

Problem: I don't see any messages in the Output window

Solutions:

  • Make sure you clicked the Play button
  • Check that the Output window is actually open (View > Output)
  • Verify your script is in ServerScriptService, not somewhere else

Problem: I see a red error message

Solutions:

  • Check that every opening quotation mark " has a closing quotation mark "
  • Make sure every opening parenthesis ( has a closing parenthesis )
  • Verify you spelled "print" correctly (lowercase, no spaces)
  • Read the error message - Roblox tries to tell you what's wrong!

Problem: My script disappeared!

Solution: It's probably still there, just in a different folder. Use the search bar at the top of the Explorer to find it by name.

Why This Matters

I know - printing messages doesn't seem like much. But you just learned something HUGE:

  • How to create and organize scripts
  • How to write code that Lua understands
  • How to see if your code is working
  • How to use the Output window for debugging

Every complex game mechanic - from checkpoint systems to boss battles - starts with these basics. You're building your foundation.

Pro Coder Tip

Professional game developers use print() ALL THE TIME. When something isn't working, they add print statements to figure out what's happening. It's like leaving yourself notes to see what your code is doing. Never think print() is "too basic" - it's one of the most powerful debugging tools you have!

Mission Check

Before moving on, make sure you can:

  • Create a new Script in ServerScriptService
  • Write at least three different print() statements
  • Open the Output window and keep it visible
  • Run your game and see your messages appear
  • Explain (in your own words) what print() does

If you can do all of these things, you're ready to move forward!

What's Next?

Printing messages is cool, but you know what's cooler? Making your game react to what players do. In the next mission, you're going to write a script that detects when a player touches a part. Get ready - things are about to get interactive!

planets.title: Touched Events
planets.description: Write a script that responds when players touch a part
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Making Your Game Come Alive

Imagine walking through a game where nothing reacts to you. No doors open. No coins collect. No enemies chase you. Pretty boring, right?

The difference between a 3D model and a real game is interaction. In this mission, you're going to make your game respond when players touch things. This is where your island runner transforms from a pretty world into an actual game.

Mission Objective

Write a script that responds when players touch a part

What Are Events?

Think about real life for a second. When your alarm goes off in the morning, you wake up. When someone knocks on a door, you answer it. When you touch a hot stove, you pull your hand back fast!

These are all events - things that happen that trigger a response. In coding, events work the same way:

  • Event happens: Player touches a part
  • Code responds: Something happens in your game

Roblox has tons of built-in events: Touched, Clicked, CharacterAdded, Died, and many more. Today, we're focusing on the most useful one: Touched.

Step 1: Create a Test Part

First, let's create a part that we can interact with:

  1. In the Workspace, create a new Part
  2. Rename it to TouchPart
  3. Change its color to bright green so it stands out
  4. Position it somewhere your player can easily reach (on the ground near your spawn)
  5. Make it a bit bigger so it's easy to touch - try size (10, 2, 10)

Why a Test Part?

Professional developers always test new code with simple examples first. Once you understand how Touched events work with this test part, you can apply the same code to checkpoints, power-ups, doors, and anything else you can imagine!

Step 2: Add a Script to Your Part

Here's something new: instead of putting the script in ServerScriptService, we're going to put it inside the part itself.

  1. In the Explorer, find your TouchPart
  2. Right-click on TouchPart
  3. Select Insert Object > Script
  4. Rename the script to TouchDetector

Now your TouchPart has its own personal script! The script can access the part it's inside using a special keyword called script.Parent.

Step 3: Write Your First Event Code

Double-click your TouchDetector script and replace everything with this code:

local part = script.Parent

part.Touched:Connect(function()
    print("Something touched me!")
end)

Whoa! That's more complex than our simple print statements. Let's break down EVERY single line:

Line by Line Explanation

Line 1: local part = script.Parent

  • local - Creates a variable that only exists in this script
  • part - The name we're giving to our variable (we could call it anything)
  • = - Assigns a value to the variable
  • script.Parent - Refers to the object containing this script (our TouchPart)

Think of this like creating a nickname. Instead of typing "script.Parent" every time, we can just type "part". It's shorter and easier to read!

Line 3: part.Touched:Connect(function()

This line does A LOT. Let's break it into pieces:

  • part.Touched - The Touched event of our part
  • :Connect - Connects our code to that event (like plugging in a cord)
  • function() - Creates a function (a block of code) that will run when the event fires

In plain English: "When something touches this part, run the code I'm about to give you."

Line 4: print("Something touched me!")

This is the code that runs when the event fires. You already know print() from the last mission!

Line 5: end)

This closes both the function AND the Connect(). Every function() needs an end, and every opening parenthesis needs a closing one.

Step 4: Test Your Code

  1. Make sure the Output window is visible
  2. Click the Play button
  3. Walk your character into the green TouchPart
  4. Watch the Output window!

You should see "Something touched me!" appear multiple times! Why multiple times? Because as you walk through the part, different parts of your character touch it - your legs, your torso, maybe your arms. Each touch fires the event!

Try It: Add More Messages

Inside the function (between function() and end), you can add as many lines of code as you want! Try this:

part.Touched:Connect(function()
    print("Something touched me!")
    print("I can feel that!")
    print("This is so cool!")
end)

Step 5: Make It More Useful - Detect What Touched

Right now, our code fires when ANYTHING touches the part - players, other parts, even falling debris. Let's make it smarter by detecting exactly what touched it.

Update your code to this:

local part = script.Parent

part.Touched:Connect(function(hit)
    print("Something called " .. hit.Name .. " touched me!")
end)

What Changed?

function(hit) instead of function()

We added a parameter called hit. When the Touched event fires, it automatically sends information about what touched the part. By putting hit in the parentheses, we can access that information!

hit is the actual part that touched our TouchPart. If a player touches it, hit is part of their character (like their leg or torso).

.. hit.Name ..

The .. operator combines text (we call this "concatenation"). This line combines three pieces:

  • "Something called "
  • The name of whatever touched the part
  • " touched me!"

Test it now! You'll see messages like "Something called Left Leg touched me!" or "Something called Right Leg touched me!"

Step 6: Detect Players Specifically

Let's make our code even smarter - let's detect when a PLAYER touches the part and print their username!

local part = script.Parent

part.Touched:Connect(function(hit)
    local humanoid = hit.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")

    if humanoid then
        local player = game.Players:GetPlayerFromCharacter(hit.Parent)
        if player then
            print(player.Name .. " touched the part!")
        end
    end
end)

Okay, this is getting more advanced! Let's break it down:

Understanding the Logic

Finding the Humanoid

local humanoid = hit.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")

Every player character has a special object called a Humanoid. This line looks for it. If we find a Humanoid, we know something with a character touched the part (not just a random brick).

The if Statement

if humanoid then

This checks: "Did we find a Humanoid?" If yes, run the code inside. If no, skip it.

Getting the Player

local player = game.Players:GetPlayerFromCharacter(hit.Parent)

This gets the actual player object from the character. The player object has useful info like their username!

Printing the Username

print(player.Name .. " touched the part!")

Now we print their actual username!

Make It Fun!

Try changing the message to something fun:

  • "Welcome, " .. player.Name .. "! Ready to run?"
  • player.Name .. " has entered the game zone!"
  • "Hey " .. player.Name .. ", watch your step!"

Step 7: Add Visual Feedback

Let's make the part change color when touched! Add this line inside the innermost if statement:

local part = script.Parent

part.Touched:Connect(function(hit)
    local humanoid = hit.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")

    if humanoid then
        local player = game.Players:GetPlayerFromCharacter(hit.Parent)
        if player then
            print(player.Name .. " touched the part!")
            part.BrickColor = BrickColor.new("Bright blue")
        end
    end
end)

Now when a player touches it, the part turns blue! This gives players immediate visual feedback.

Experiment Time!

  • Try different colors: "Bright red", "Really red", "Hot pink", "Lime green"
  • Add part.Material = Enum.Material.Neon to make it glow!
  • Try part.Transparency = 0.5 to make it half-transparent

Common Mistakes and Fixes

Problem: Nothing happens when I touch the part

Solutions:

  • Make sure the script is inside the part, not in ServerScriptService
  • Check that the part is NOT anchored (uncheck Anchored in Properties) - wait, actually for this to work the part should be Anchored! Check both ways to see what works for your setup
  • Verify the Output window is open so you can see messages
  • Check for red error messages in Output

Problem: The message prints dozens of times

This is normal! As you walk through the part, different body parts touch it repeatedly. In future missions, you'll learn how to make events fire only once using a "debounce" system.

Problem: "attempt to index nil with 'Name'" error

Solution: This means something without a Name touched the part. Make sure you're using the if humanoid then check to filter for only player characters.

Why This Matters

You just learned one of the most important concepts in game development: event-driven programming. Almost everything in games is based on events:

  • Checkpoints? Touched events.
  • Collectible coins? Touched events.
  • Buttons and doors? Touched events (or Clicked events).
  • Damage zones? Touched events.
  • Finish lines? You guessed it - Touched events!

Master this concept, and you can create any interactive element you can imagine.

Pro Developer Tip

Always test what's touching your parts before running code on it. The if humanoid then check prevents errors when random objects touch your parts. This kind of "defensive coding" separates buggy games from polished ones!

Mission Check

Before moving on, make sure you can:

  • Explain what an event is in your own words
