  • Add a script to a part (not just ServerScriptService)
  • Write a basic Touched event that prints a message
  • Use the hit parameter to detect what touched the part
  • Check for a Humanoid to detect player characters
  • Get and print a player's username
  • Change a part's properties (color, material, etc.) when touched

What's Next?

Now that you know how to detect when players touch things, you're ready to build something really useful: checkpoints! In the next mission, you'll create spawn points that save player progress through your island runner. No more starting over from the beginning every time you fall!

planets.title: Checkpoint Spawns
planets.description: Script spawn points that save player progress
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Save Your Progress!

Picture this: You've made it halfway through a challenging obstacle course. You're feeling great. Then... you miss a jump and fall. Now you have to start ALL the way back at the beginning.

Frustrating, right? That's why every good platformer game has checkpoints - safe spots that save your progress so you don't lose everything when you mess up (and trust me, in a runner game, you WILL mess up).

Today, you're going to build a checkpoint system that makes your game actually playable and fun!

Mission Objective

Script spawn points that save player progress

Understanding Spawns and Checkpoints

In Roblox, there are two ways to control where players spawn (appear) in your game:

  1. SpawnLocation objects - Special parts that players can spawn at
  2. Setting player.RespawnLocation - Telling the game exactly where a specific player should spawn

We're going to use SpawnLocation objects because they're easier to work with and give us built-in features like the spawn pad appearance.

Step 1: Create Your First Checkpoint

  1. In the Home tab, click Gameplay in the toolbar
  2. Click Spawn to insert a SpawnLocation
  3. A gray spawn pad appears in your game!
  4. Rename it to Checkpoint1
  5. Move it to a good location on your island path (maybe partway up)

Customizing Your Checkpoint

Select your checkpoint and look at its Properties:

  • Duration - How long the spawn effect lasts (the swirly particle effect)
  • Neutral - If checked, any team can spawn here (keep this checked for now)
  • AllowTeamChangeOnTouch - We won't use this for now

Feel free to change the color and material to match your island theme!

Step 2: The Problem We Need to Solve

By default, SpawnLocation objects work randomly - players might spawn at ANY spawn in your game. We need to make it so when a player touches a checkpoint, THAT checkpoint becomes their personal spawn point.

Also, we need to make sure the checkpoint only activates ONCE per touch (not 50 times as the player walks across it).

Step 3: Add the Checkpoint Script

Right-click your Checkpoint1 and insert a Script. Rename it to CheckpointScript.

Here's the complete checkpoint code:

local checkpoint = script.Parent
local debounce = {}

checkpoint.Touched:Connect(function(hit)
    local humanoid = hit.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")

    if humanoid then
        local player = game.Players:GetPlayerFromCharacter(hit.Parent)

        if player and not debounce[player] then
            debounce[player] = true

            -- Set this checkpoint as the player's spawn point
            player.RespawnLocation = checkpoint

            -- Visual feedback
            checkpoint.BrickColor = BrickColor.new("Bright green")
            checkpoint.Material = Enum.Material.Neon

            -- Print confirmation
            print(player.Name .. " reached checkpoint!")

            wait(2)
            debounce[player] = nil
        end
    end
end)

Whoa! That's a lot of new stuff. Let's break down every single part:

Line by Line Breakdown

Lines 1-2: Setup

local checkpoint = script.Parent
local debounce = {}
  • checkpoint - References the SpawnLocation this script is inside
  • debounce = {} - Creates an empty table (like a list) to track which players recently touched the checkpoint

Lines 4-9: Detect Player Touch

This part should look familiar from Mission 4.2! We detect when something touches the checkpoint, check if it has a Humanoid, then get the player.

Line 11: The Debounce Check

if player and not debounce[player] then

This checks TWO things:

  • player - Did we successfully find a player?
  • not debounce[player] - Is this player NOT in our debounce table? (Meaning they haven't touched this checkpoint recently)

This prevents the checkpoint from activating multiple times in a row!

Line 12: Add to Debounce

debounce[player] = true

We add this player to the debounce table, marking that they just touched the checkpoint.

Line 15: The Magic Line

player.RespawnLocation = checkpoint

THIS is what makes the checkpoint work! We set this player's RespawnLocation to this checkpoint. Now when they die, they'll respawn here instead of at the start!

Lines 18-19: Visual Feedback

We change the checkpoint to bright green and make it glow so players know they activated it. Visual feedback is SUPER important for good game design!

Line 22: Confirmation Message

Print a message so we can verify it's working.

Lines 24-25: Reset Debounce

wait(2)
debounce[player] = nil

Wait 2 seconds, then remove the player from the debounce table. Now they can activate the checkpoint again if needed (like if they run back and forth).

Step 4: Test Your Checkpoint

  1. Click Play
  2. Run over to your checkpoint
  3. Watch it turn green and glow!
  4. Now jump off your island (or walk into a dangerous area if you have one)
  5. When you respawn, you should appear at the checkpoint, not at the original spawn!

SUCCESS! You just created a working checkpoint system!

Step 5: Add More Checkpoints

One checkpoint is good, but a real runner game needs several! Here's how to add more:

  1. Select your Checkpoint1 (including the script inside it)
  2. Press Ctrl+D (or Cmd+D on Mac) to duplicate it
  3. Rename it to Checkpoint2
  4. Move it further along your island path
  5. Repeat for Checkpoint3, Checkpoint4, etc.

The great news? Since you duplicated the checkpoint WITH the script, all your checkpoints will automatically work!

Design Challenge!

Place checkpoints strategically along your island:

  • After difficult jumps
  • Before dangerous areas
  • At the start of each major section
  • NOT too close together (that's too easy!)
  • NOT too far apart (that's too frustrating!)

Step 6: Add Checkpoint Numbers (Optional but Cool)

Let's track which checkpoint number the player reached! This teaches you about leaderstats - a way to display player stats on the leaderboard.

Create a new Script in ServerScriptService called LeaderboardSetup:

game.Players.PlayerAdded:Connect(function(player)
    local leaderstats = Instance.new("Folder")
    leaderstats.Name = "leaderstats"
    leaderstats.Parent = player

    local checkpointReached = Instance.new("IntValue")
    checkpointReached.Name = "Checkpoint"
    checkpointReached.Value = 0
    checkpointReached.Parent = leaderstats
end)

What This Does

When a player joins the game, this code:

  • Creates a "leaderstats" folder (special name that makes stats show on the leaderboard)
  • Creates an IntValue (integer/number value) called "Checkpoint"
  • Sets it to 0 initially
  • Puts it in the leaderstats folder

Now when you play, you'll see a "Checkpoint: 0" stat on the leaderboard!

Step 7: Update Checkpoints to Track Numbers

Let's make each checkpoint update this stat! Add this to your checkpoint script (inside the main if statement, after setting the RespawnLocation):

-- Update checkpoint stat
local leaderstats = player:FindFirstChild("leaderstats")
if leaderstats then
    local checkpointStat = leaderstats:FindFirstChild("Checkpoint")
    if checkpointStat then
        -- Only update if this checkpoint is higher than current
        local checkpointNumber = tonumber(checkpoint.Name:match("%d+"))
        if checkpointNumber and checkpointNumber > checkpointStat.Value then
            checkpointStat.Value = checkpointNumber
        end
    end
end

Breaking Down the New Code

  • checkpoint.Name:match("%d+") - Extracts the number from the checkpoint name ("Checkpoint1" "1")
  • tonumber() - Converts the text "1" into the actual number 1
  • checkpointNumber > checkpointStat.Value - Only update if this is a NEW checkpoint (prevents going backwards)

Now when you touch checkpoints, the leaderboard updates to show which checkpoint you've reached!

Make It Your Own!

Customize your checkpoints:

  • Use different colors for each checkpoint (rainbow checkpoints!)
  • Add a sound effect when activated (insert a Sound object into the checkpoint)
  • Make the checkpoint play a particle effect
  • Add a TextLabel above the checkpoint showing its number

Common Problems and Solutions

Problem: I still respawn at the original spawn

Solutions:

  • Make sure you touched the checkpoint BEFORE dying
  • Check that the script is inside the checkpoint part
  • Verify there are no errors in the Output window
  • Make sure the checkpoint is a SpawnLocation, not just a regular Part

Problem: The checkpoint doesn't turn green

Solutions:

  • Check if the player detection is working (look for the print message in Output)
  • Make sure the visual feedback code is inside the if statement
  • Verify you're testing with a player character, not just the camera

Problem: The checkpoint stat doesn't update

Solutions:

  • Make sure the LeaderboardSetup script is in ServerScriptService
  • Check that your checkpoints are named with numbers (Checkpoint1, Checkpoint2, etc.)
  • Look for errors in the Output window

Understanding Debounce (The Cooldown System)

Let's talk more about why debounce is so important:

Without debounce: As you walk across the checkpoint, your character's legs, torso, and arms all touch it separately. The Touched event fires maybe 20 times in one second! Your code runs 20 times, the checkpoint changes color 20 times, and everything goes crazy.

With debounce: The first touch activates the checkpoint. We add the player to the debounce table. For the next 2 seconds, any additional touches are ignored because the player is in the debounce table. After 2 seconds, we remove them from the table so they can activate it again if needed.

This is a professional coding technique used in every major game!

Pro Game Designer Tip

Checkpoint placement is an art! Too many checkpoints and the game feels too easy - there's no challenge. Too few and players get frustrated repeating the same sections over and over. Test your game with friends and watch where they struggle. Put checkpoints AFTER the hard parts, not before!

Mission Check

Before moving on, make sure you can:

  • Create SpawnLocation objects
  • Add checkpoint scripts that detect player touches
  • Use debounce to prevent code from running too frequently
  • Set a player's RespawnLocation to change where they spawn
  • Provide visual feedback when checkpoints activate
  • Create and update leaderstats values (optional)
  • Place multiple checkpoints along your island path
  • Test that checkpoints work by dying and respawning

What's Next?

Your checkpoints save progress - awesome! But what happens when players fall or make mistakes? They just float there or fall forever. That's not great game design. In the next mission, you'll create death zones and kill bricks that automatically reset players back to their last checkpoint. Time to add some real challenge to your game!

planets.title: Death and Respawn
planets.description: Code kill bricks to return players to checkpoints
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Add Some Danger!

Right now, your island runner is pretty safe. Players can walk around, jump wherever they want, and even if they fall off the island, they just fall forever into the void. There's no real challenge, no stakes, no tension.

That's about to change.

Today you're going to add DEATH to your game. Lava pits. Spike traps. Poison water. Deadly obstacles that punish mistakes and send players back to their last checkpoint. This is what transforms your peaceful island into an actual game that tests player skill!

Mission Objective

Code kill bricks to return players to checkpoints

Understanding Death in Roblox

In Roblox, every player character has a Humanoid object that controls their health. Here's how it works:

  • Humanoid.Health - The character's current health (default is 100)
  • Humanoid.MaxHealth - The maximum health (also default 100)
  • When Health reaches 0, the character dies
  • When a character dies, Roblox automatically respawns them at their RespawnLocation

So to create a kill brick, all we need to do is find the player's Humanoid and set its Health to 0. Simple!

Step 1: Create Your First Kill Brick

Let's create a dangerous lava pit!

  1. In the Workspace, create a new Part
  2. Rename it to KillBrick
  3. Make it big enough to be a challenge - try size (20, 1, 20)
  4. Change its color to Bright red or Really red
  5. Change its Material to Neon to make it look dangerous
  6. Position it somewhere players might fall - like between two platforms or at the bottom of a jump
  7. Make sure CanCollide is checked so players can actually touch it
  8. Make sure Anchored is checked so it doesn't fall

Design Tip: Make Danger Obvious

Good game design means players should KNOW something is dangerous just by looking at it. Use bright red, orange, or black colors. Add a Neon material to make it glow. Maybe even add fire particles! Players should never die and think "How was I supposed to know that was dangerous?"

Step 2: Write the Kill Script

Right-click your KillBrick and insert a Script. Rename it to KillScript.

Here's the complete code:

local killBrick = script.Parent

killBrick.Touched:Connect(function(hit)
    local humanoid = hit.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")

    if humanoid then
        humanoid.Health = 0
    end
end)

Wait... that's it? That's ALL the code we need? Yes! Let's break it down:

Line by Line Explanation

Line 1: Reference the Part

local killBrick = script.Parent

Standard setup - create a reference to the part containing this script.

Lines 3-8: The Touched Event

This should look very familiar! When something touches the kill brick:

  • Line 4: Look for a Humanoid in whatever touched the brick
  • Line 6: If we found a Humanoid, check if it exists
  • Line 7: Set its Health to 0 (which kills it instantly)

That's it! When Health hits 0, Roblox automatically handles the death animation and respawning the player at their last checkpoint.

Step 3: Test Your Kill Brick

  1. Make sure you have at least one checkpoint in your game (from Mission 4.3)
  2. Click Play
  3. Touch a checkpoint first (so you have a respawn point)
  4. Walk onto the kill brick
  5. Your character should die instantly!
  6. You should respawn at the checkpoint you touched

SUCCESS! You just created your first deadly obstacle!

Make It Better: Add a Warning Message

Let's add a print message so we can track when players die (useful for testing!):

local killBrick = script.Parent

killBrick.Touched:Connect(function(hit)
    local humanoid = hit.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")

    if humanoid then
        local player = game.Players:GetPlayerFromCharacter(hit.Parent)
        if player then
            print(player.Name .. " died!")
        end
        humanoid.Health = 0
    end
end)

Step 4: Create Different Types of Kill Zones

One kill brick is good, but let's make your game more interesting with different types of hazards!

Lava Pit

  • Color: Bright red or Really red
  • Material: Neon
  • Add a Fire object inside the part (Insert Object > Fire)
  • Make it wide and flat, like a pool of lava

Spike Trap

  • Color: Dark stone grey or Black
  • Material: Slate or Concrete
  • Make it smaller and thinner - like actual spikes
  • You can create multiple thin parts grouped together to look like spikes

Poison Water

  • Color: Bright green or Lime green
  • Material: Glass or Neon
  • Transparency: 0.3 (so you can see through it a bit)
  • Make it look like a puddle or pool

The Void (For Falling Off)

  • Create a HUGE kill brick far below your island
  • Size: (500, 1, 500) or bigger
  • Color: Black
  • Transparency: 1 (completely invisible)
  • This catches players who fall off the island!

Duplicate Your Kill Bricks

Just like with checkpoints, you can duplicate kill bricks (select the brick AND its script, then press Ctrl+D). Place dangerous obstacles throughout your island:

  • Between difficult jumps
  • Below narrow paths
  • As moving obstacles (we'll learn moving parts later!)
  • Around the edges to catch players who fall off

Step 5: Add Advanced Features (Optional)

Let's make kill bricks even more interesting!

Option 1: Damage Over Time (DOT) Instead of Instant Death

What if instead of instant death, the brick slowly drains health?

local damageBrick = script.Parent
local damageAmount = 10
local debounce = {}

damageBrick.Touched:Connect(function(hit)
    local humanoid = hit.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")

    if humanoid and not debounce[humanoid] then
        debounce[humanoid] = true
        humanoid.Health = humanoid.Health - damageAmount
        print("Player took " .. damageAmount .. " damage!")

        wait(1)
        debounce[humanoid] = nil
    end
end)

How it works:

  • Instead of setting Health to 0, we subtract 10 each time
  • Debounce ensures damage only happens once per second
  • Players can walk across it if they're quick, but lingering will kill them!

Option 2: Play a Sound on Death

Add audio feedback to make deaths more impactful!

  1. Insert a Sound object into your kill brick
  2. Set the SoundId to a death sound (search the toolbox for "death sound" or "explosion")
  3. Add this line before humanoid.Health = 0:
script.Parent.Sound:Play()

Option 3: Explosion Effect

Make deaths more dramatic with an explosion!

local killBrick = script.Parent

killBrick.Touched:Connect(function(hit)
    local humanoid = hit.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")

    if humanoid then
        -- Create explosion at player position
        local explosion = Instance.new("Explosion")
        explosion.Position = hit.Position
        explosion.BlastRadius = 5
        explosion.BlastPressure = 0  -- Don't push other parts around
        explosion.Parent = workspace

        humanoid.Health = 0
    end
end)

Step 6: Balance Your Game

Now that you have checkpoints AND kill bricks, you need to balance your game. This is game design!

Game Balance Principles

  • Fair Challenge: Make sure checkpoints come BEFORE hard sections, not after
  • Clear Danger: Players should always see hazards before touching them
  • Progressive Difficulty: Start easy, get harder as players progress
  • Test, Test, Test: Play your own game! If YOU get frustrated, players will too

Walk through your island as a player would. Ask yourself:

  • Is this challenge fair?
  • Can I see the danger before I hit it?
  • Is there a checkpoint close enough that dying isn't too frustrating?
  • Is this section too easy? Too hard?

Common Problems and Solutions

Problem: Nothing happens when I touch the kill brick

Solutions:

  • Make sure CanCollide is checked (otherwise you'll fall through it)
  • Verify the script is inside the kill brick part
  • Check for errors in the Output window
  • Make sure you're testing with a character, not just moving the camera

Problem: I die but respawn at the starting spawn, not my checkpoint

Solution: You need to touch a checkpoint FIRST to set your RespawnLocation. Go back to Mission 4.3 and make sure your checkpoints are working correctly.

Problem: Other parts that touch the kill brick disappear

This is normal! The kill brick will destroy anything with a Humanoid. If you don't want this, add a check to only kill players specifically (check if a Player object exists).

Problem: My character dies repeatedly even after leaving the kill brick

Solution: The Touched event might be firing multiple times. Add debounce (like we did in checkpoints) to prevent repeated deaths.

The Psychology of Death in Games

Here's something cool to think about: death in games isn't bad! Death creates:

  • Stakes: If you can't fail, success doesn't feel good
  • Learning: Players learn what NOT to do
  • Tension: Danger makes the game exciting
  • Accomplishment: Beating a hard section feels AMAZING because you could have failed

The key is making death feel FAIR. If players die and think "That was my fault, I can do better next time," that's good game design. If they think "That was cheap!" or "How was I supposed to avoid that?" - that's bad design.

Pro Game Designer Tip

Watch other people play your game (siblings, friends, classmates). Don't help them! Just watch where they die and listen to their reactions. If they die in the same spot over and over and get frustrated, you might need to add a checkpoint or remove some hazards. If they die but immediately want to try again, you nailed the difficulty!

Mission Check

Before moving on, make sure you can:

  • Explain how Humanoid.Health controls character life
  • Create kill bricks that instantly eliminate players
  • Design kill zones that look visually dangerous
  • Test the death and respawn system with checkpoints
  • Create different types of hazards (lava, spikes, etc.)
  • Optionally: Create damage-over-time zones or add effects
  • Balance your game so it's challenging but fair

What's Next?

Your island now has checkpoints that save progress and hazards that punish mistakes. There's just one thing missing: a way to WIN! In the next mission, you'll script a finish line that detects when players complete your course and celebrates their victory. Time to add a proper ending to your game!

planets.title: End Goal Detection
planets.description: Script your finish zone to recognize when players complete the course
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Create Your Victory!

You've built an island. You've created challenging obstacles. You've added checkpoints that save progress and hazards that punish mistakes. Players can run, jump, die, and respawn.

But here's the question: how do they WIN?

Every great game needs a clear goal - a moment where players pump their fist in the air and shout "YES!" Today, you're going to create that moment. You're building a finish line that recognizes victory and celebrates it in style!

Mission Objective

Script your finish zone to recognize when players complete the course

What Makes a Good Finish Line?

Think about finishing a race in real life. There's usually:

  • A clear visual marker (a big banner, a flag, a ribbon)
  • People cheering
  • Maybe confetti or fireworks
  • Someone officially recording that you finished
  • A feeling of ACCOMPLISHMENT

We're going to create all of that in your game! Well, except for the people cheering - unless you want to add NPC spectators (that's advanced!).

Step 1: Create the Finish Line Part

Let's make a finish zone that's impossible to miss!

  1. In the Workspace, create a new Part
  2. Rename it to FinishLine
  3. Make it BIG and tall - like size (15, 20, 2) - players should see it from far away
  4. Position it at the end of your island runner course
  5. Change its color to Bright yellow or Gold
  6. Set Material to Neon so it glows gloriously
  7. Make sure Anchored is checked
  8. Make sure CanCollide is UNCHECKED so players can walk through it

Why CanCollide = False?

We want players to walk THROUGH the finish line, not bounce off it! Having CanCollide unchecked means they'll pass right through it (like a hologram), which triggers the Touched event but doesn't block their movement.

Step 2: Write the Basic Finish Line Script

Right-click your FinishLine part and insert a Script. Rename it to FinishScript.

Here's the starter code:

local finishLine = script.Parent
local winners = {}

finishLine.Touched:Connect(function(hit)
    local humanoid = hit.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")

    if humanoid then
        local player = game.Players:GetPlayerFromCharacter(hit.Parent)

        if player and not winners[player] then
            winners[player] = true
            print(player.Name .. " finished the course!")
        end
    end
end)

Breaking Down the Code

Line 2: The Winners Table

local winners = {}

We create an empty table to track who has already finished. This prevents the same player from "winning" multiple times if they walk back and forth through the finish line.

Lines 4-14: The Touched Event

This should look familiar by now!

  • Line 5: Find the Humanoid (is this a character?)
  • Line 8: Get the player from the character
  • Line 10: Check if we found a player AND they're not already in the winners table
  • Line 11: Add them to the winners table
  • Line 12: Announce their victory!

Step 3: Test Your Basic Finish Line

  1. Click Play
  2. Run through your course (or just teleport to the finish line for testing)
  3. Walk through the FinishLine part
  4. Check the Output window - you should see "[Your Name] finished the course!"

Nice! But that's pretty boring. Let's make winning feel AMAZING!

Step 4: Add Visual Celebration

Let's make the finish line put on a show! Update your script:

local finishLine = script.Parent
local winners = {}

finishLine.Touched:Connect(function(hit)
    local humanoid = hit.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")

    if humanoid then
        local player = game.Players:GetPlayerFromCharacter(hit.Parent)

        if player and not winners[player] then
            winners[player] = true
            print(player.Name .. " finished the course!")

            -- CELEBRATION TIME!

            -- Flash the finish line
            for i = 1, 5 do
                finishLine.BrickColor = BrickColor.new("Bright red")
                wait(0.1)
                finishLine.BrickColor = BrickColor.new("Bright yellow")
                wait(0.1)
            end

            -- Make the player jump for joy!
            humanoid.Jump = true
        end
    end
end)

What's New?

The For Loop (Lines 17-22)

for i = 1, 5 do
    finishLine.BrickColor = BrickColor.new("Bright red")
    wait(0.1)
    finishLine.BrickColor = BrickColor.new("Bright yellow")
    wait(0.1)
end

This is your first for loop! It repeats code multiple times. Here's what it does:

  • for i = 1, 5 do - Repeat this code 5 times
  • i is a counter variable (1, then 2, then 3, then 4, then 5)
  • Each time through: turn red, wait 0.1 seconds, turn yellow, wait 0.1 seconds
  • This creates a flashing effect!

Making the Player Jump

humanoid.Jump = true

This makes the character jump automatically - like they're celebrating!

Test it now! When you cross the finish line, it flashes and your character jumps. Much better!

Step 5: Add Sound Effects

Audio makes victory feel even better! Let's add a victory sound.

  1. In the FinishLine part, insert a Sound object
  2. Name it VictorySound
  3. In the Properties, find SoundId
  4. Click it and search for "victory" or "fanfare" in the sound library
  5. Pick a sound you like! (Try rbxassetid://5153845714 for a classic victory fanfare)

Now add this line right after winners[player] = true:

finishLine.VictorySound:Play()

Now there's an epic sound when players win!

Try Different Sounds!

Search the Roblox audio library for different victory sounds:

  • "applause" - Crowd cheering
  • "fireworks" - Celebration explosions
  • "success" - Success jingles
  • "fanfare" - Trumpet victory music

Step 6: Add Particle Effects

Let's add some visual pizzazz with particles!

  1. In the FinishLine part, insert a ParticleEmitter
  2. Name it Confetti
  3. In Properties, customize it:
    • Texture: Search for confetti or sparkles
    • Rate: 100 (how many particles per second)
    • Speed: 10
    • Lifetime: 2 to 4 (how long each particle lasts)
    • Enabled: UNCHECK this (we'll turn it on with code)

Add this code to your script (after playing the sound):

-- Burst of confetti!
finishLine.Confetti.Enabled = true
wait(2)
finishLine.Confetti.Enabled = false

Now when players win, there's a 2-second burst of confetti particles!

Step 7: Track Wins on the Leaderboard

Let's count how many times each player has completed the course!

First, update your LeaderboardSetup script from Mission 4.3 (in ServerScriptService). If you don't have it, create it now:

game.Players.PlayerAdded:Connect(function(player)
    local leaderstats = Instance.new("Folder")
    leaderstats.Name = "leaderstats"
    leaderstats.Parent = player

    local checkpointReached = Instance.new("IntValue")
    checkpointReached.Name = "Checkpoint"
    checkpointReached.Value = 0
    checkpointReached.Parent = leaderstats

    -- NEW: Add wins counter
    local wins = Instance.new("IntValue")
    wins.Name = "Wins"
    wins.Value = 0
    wins.Parent = leaderstats
end)

Now update your FinishScript to increment the win count:

if player and not winners[player] then
    winners[player] = true
    print(player.Name .. " finished the course!")

    -- Update win count
    local leaderstats = player:FindFirstChild("leaderstats")
    if leaderstats then
        local wins = leaderstats:FindFirstChild("Wins")
        if wins then
            wins.Value = wins.Value + 1
        end
    end

    -- [Rest of celebration code here...]
end

Now the leaderboard tracks how many times each player has beaten your course!

Step 8: Add a Victory Message

Let's display a big message on the player's screen when they win! This requires a bit more advanced code, but you can do it!

Add this code to your FinishScript (after updating the win count):

-- Create victory message on player's screen
local message = Instance.new("Message")
message.Text = " " .. player.Name .. " completed the Island Runner! "
message.Parent = player.PlayerGui
wait(5)
message:Destroy()

What This Does

  • Instance.new("Message") - Creates a Message GUI element
  • message.Text - Sets what it says (with emoji!)
  • message.Parent = player.PlayerGui - Shows it on this player's screen
  • wait(5) - Keep it visible for 5 seconds
  • message:Destroy() - Remove it from the screen

Now players get a personal victory message that appears across the middle of their screen!

Step 9: Optional - Allow Replay

Right now, players can only win once (because we add them to the winners table). What if we want them to be able to play again?

You have two options:

Option 1: Allow Unlimited Replays

Simply remove the winners table check! This lets players win over and over:

if player then  -- Remove the "and not winners[player]" part
    -- They can win every time they cross!
end

Option 2: Reset After Some Time

Let them win once, but allow replays after a cooldown:

if player and not winners[player] then
    winners[player] = true

    -- [All your celebration code...]

    -- Allow replay after 10 seconds
    wait(10)
    winners[player] = nil
    print(player.Name .. " can play again!")
end

Step 10: Make Your Finish Line Beautiful

Now that it works, make it look AMAZING!

Design Ideas

  • Build an arch: Create multiple parts forming a doorway to run through
  • Add a flag: Put a flag part on top of the finish line
  • Light it up: Add PointLight objects inside the finish line with bright colors
  • Create a platform: Build a winner's podium beyond the finish line
  • Add decorations: Balloons, banners, signs saying "FINISH!"

The Complete Final Script

Here's what your finished FinishScript might look like with all the features:

local finishLine = script.Parent
local winners = {}

finishLine.Touched:Connect(function(hit)
    local humanoid = hit.Parent:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")

    if humanoid then
        local player = game.Players:GetPlayerFromCharacter(hit.Parent)

        if player and not winners[player] then
            winners[player] = true
            print(player.Name .. " finished the course!")

            -- Update win count
            local leaderstats = player:FindFirstChild("leaderstats")
            if leaderstats then
                local wins = leaderstats:FindFirstChild("Wins")
                if wins then
                    wins.Value = wins.Value + 1
                end
            end

            -- Victory message
            local message = Instance.new("Message")
            message.Text = " " .. player.Name .. " completed the Island Runner! "
            message.Parent = player.PlayerGui

            -- Play sound
            finishLine.VictorySound:Play()

            -- Confetti burst
            finishLine.Confetti.Enabled = true

            -- Flash the finish line
            for i = 1, 5 do
                finishLine.BrickColor = BrickColor.new("Bright red")
                wait(0.1)
                finishLine.BrickColor = BrickColor.new("Bright yellow")
                wait(0.1)
            end

            -- Make player jump for joy
            humanoid.Jump = true

            -- Clean up effects
            wait(2)
            finishLine.Confetti.Enabled = false
            message:Destroy()

            -- Allow replay after cooldown
            wait(10)
            winners[player] = nil
        end
    end
end)

Common Problems and Solutions

Problem: The finish line doesn't detect me

Solutions:

  • Make sure CanCollide is UNCHECKED (you need to pass through it)
  • Verify the script is inside the FinishLine part
  • Check that the part is big enough to actually touch
  • Look for errors in the Output window

Problem: The victory message doesn't show up

Solutions:

  • Make sure you're setting message.Parent = player.PlayerGui (not workspace)
  • Check that you got the player object correctly
  • Try using a print statement to verify the code is running

Problem: The sound doesn't play

Solutions:

  • Verify the Sound object is named correctly and is inside the FinishLine
  • Check that SoundId is set to a valid audio asset
  • Make sure your computer volume is up!

Problem: Particles keep spraying forever

Solution: Make sure you set finishLine.Confetti.Enabled = false after the wait() time. Also verify the ParticleEmitter starts with Enabled unchecked in Properties.

Why This Matters

You just completed something huge: a full game loop!

  • Players spawn at the beginning
  • They navigate obstacles, using checkpoints to save progress
  • They face challenges with kill zones that test their skills
  • They reach the goal and receive satisfying feedback
  • They can see their achievement on the leaderboard

This is the core structure of almost every platformer, runner, and obstacle course game ever made. You understand game design now!

Pro Game Designer Tip

The feeling of victory should be proportional to the challenge. If your game is super hard, make the celebration EPIC - huge explosions, dramatic music, confetti everywhere! If it's easier, a simple message and sound is fine. The celebration is the emotional payoff for the player's effort. Make it count!

Mission Check

Before moving on, make sure you can:

  • Create a finish line part that detects player touches
  • Use a winners table to track who has completed the course
  • Add visual effects (flashing colors, particles)
  • Play sound effects on victory
  • Display victory messages on players' screens
  • Update leaderboard stats to track wins
  • Use for loops to create repeating effects
  • Design a finish line that looks celebratory and clear

Congratulations!

You've completed Star 4 - Scripting Essentials! You went from knowing NOTHING about coding to building:

  • Scripts that print messages
  • Interactive parts that respond to touches
  • A complete checkpoint system
  • Dangerous obstacles that test player skill
  • A satisfying finish line with celebrations

More importantly, you learned the fundamental concepts that ALL programmers use: variables, functions, events, conditionals (if statements), loops, and parameters. These concepts work in every programming language, not just Roblox!

In the next star - World Building Round 2 - you'll use these scripting skills to add even more advanced mechanics to your island. Get ready to create moving platforms, rotating obstacles, timed challenges, and more!

You're not just a builder anymore. You're a game developer.

stars.title: World Building Round 2
stars.description: Complete all landmark zones with advanced obstacles

planets.title: Landmark Zone 2
planets.description: Build your second landmark as a distinct obstacle challenge
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
The Second Challenge

Your first landmark zone taught players the basics of your island runner. But great games need variety. If every zone feels the same, players get bored fast. Think about your favorite platformersthey keep introducing new challenges, new environments, new obstacles that make you think differently.

Your mission: build a second landmark zone that feels completely different from the first. If your first zone was all about precise jumps, maybe this one tests speed. If the first was wide and open, make this one tight and vertical. The goal is contrastgive players a fresh challenge that makes them adapt.

Mission Objective

Design and build Landmark Zone 2 with obstacles that create a distinct challenge from your first zone, then place a checkpoint at the end.

Planning Your Second Zone

Before you build a single part, think about contrast. Open your game and run through Landmark Zone 1. What kind of challenge is it? Write down three words that describe it. Fast? Tight? Vertical? Easy? Technical?

Now, for Zone 2, pick the opposite. If Zone 1 was fast-paced with wide jumps, make Zone 2 slower with precision jumps. If Zone 1 was flat, make Zone 2 vertical. This contrast keeps players engaged and shows off your design skills.

Try It: Zone Contrast Chart

Fill this out before building:

  • Zone 1 is: [wide/narrow] [fast/slow] [flat/vertical] [easy/hard]
  • Zone 2 will be: [opposite choices]
  • Main obstacle type: [what players will do most]

Building Zone 2

Start with the landing platformthe area where players arrive from Zone 1. Make it safe, no kill bricks here. This gives players a moment to see what's ahead and prepare.

Then build your obstacle sequence. Here are proven patterns you can use:

Pattern 1: The Gauntlet

A straight line of obstacles that tests timing. Place kill brick gaps every few studs, forcing players to jump repeatedly without pause. Start with easy gaps (4-5 studs) and gradually increase to harder ones (6-7 studs).

Pattern 2: The Maze

Create a path that turns and twists. Use walls to force players to navigate tight corners. Add kill bricks in corners to punish sloppy movement. This works great if Zone 1 was straight and open.

Pattern 3: The Vertical Climb

Stack platforms going upward. Players must jump from level to level, climbing higher. Mix in some platforms that are offset left or right, so it's not just straight up. Add kill bricks below each levelif you fall, you fall far.

Pattern 4: The Parkour Line

A series of small platforms (4x4 studs or smaller) that players must jump across. Space them so each jump is just barely possible. This creates high tensionone mistake and you're done.

Design Tips

  • Length matters: Zone 2 should be slightly longer than Zone 1. Players have more skills now.
  • Color code it: Use different colors than Zone 1. This helps players know they've progressed.
  • Add landmarks: Build a cool structure or shape that makes this zone memorable. A tower, an arch, a giant spheresomething visual.
  • Safe spots: Every 3-4 obstacles, add a larger platform where players can rest. This prevents frustration.

Building Your Obstacles

Let's build a specific example: a gauntlet with increasing difficulty.

  1. Create the landing platform (10x10 studs, Material: SmoothPlastic, Color: a new color)
  2. Anchor it and position it where Zone 1 ends
  3. Build the first jump: Place a platform 5 studs away (easy first jump)
  4. Add a kill brick between them (Part, set CanCollide to false, Color: bright red, add kill brick script)
  5. Build the second jump: 5.5 studs away (slightly harder)
  6. Add another kill brick
  7. Continue this pattern, increasing gap size to 6, then 6.5 studs
  8. After 4-5 jumps, add a larger rest platform
  9. Build a second set of jumps with a different patternmaybe diagonal instead of straight

Try It: The Difficulty Curve

Run through your zone. Time yourself. If it takes less than 20 seconds, it might be too easy. If it takes more than 60 seconds, it might be too hard. Aim for 30-45 seconds for a skilled player.

Adding Visual Interest

Don't just make functional obstaclesmake them cool to look at. Here are quick wins:

  • Shape variety: Not everything has to be a rectangular part. Use cylinders, spheres, wedges.
  • Rotation: Rotate platforms at slight angles. A platform tilted 15 degrees is more interesting than a flat one.
  • Size variation: Mix large platforms with small ones. Variety creates visual rhythm.
  • Height changes: Don't keep everything at the same Y level. Go up and down.

Placing the Checkpoint

At the end of Zone 2, place a checkpoint part. This is criticalplayers need to save their progress here.

  1. Create a Part, make it stand out (maybe a tall cylinder or a glowing block)
  2. Size: 6x8x6 studs works well
  3. Color: Green or Gold (different from kill bricks)
  4. Material: Neon (makes it glow and obvious)
  5. Add your checkpoint script from Star 4
  6. Set CanCollide to false (so players can walk through it)
  7. Anchor it

Position the checkpoint on a large safe platform. Players should feel relief when they reach it, not stress about falling off while touching it.

Checkpoint Placement Pro Tip

Place checkpoints AFTER challenges, not before. Players should earn the checkpoint by completing the zone. If you put it at the start, there's no reward for finishing.

Testing Your Zone

Hit Play and test your zone. Important questions to ask:

  • Can I complete it in under 1 minute?
  • Do I die at the same spot repeatedly? (If yes, that spot might be too hard)
  • Is there a moment where I don't know where to go next? (If yes, add visual guides)
  • Does it feel different from Zone 1? (If no, revise to increase contrast)

If you're dying too much, make jumps slightly shorter or add more safe platforms. If it's too easy, increase gaps or remove safe platforms. Testing and adjusting is how good levels get great.

Try It: The Friend Test

If possible, have a classmate play your zone. Watch where they struggle. Don't help themjust observe. Their struggles show you what needs adjusting. If they breeze through, make it harder. If they rage quit, make it easier.

Final Polish

Before moving to the next mission, do these final checks:

  • All platforms are anchored
  • All kill bricks have CanCollide = false and kill scripts
  • Checkpoint is working (touch it and check the output for messages)
  • Zone uses different colors/style from Zone 1
  • You can complete it consistently (if you can't, players definitely can't)

Mission Check

Before proceeding, verify:

  • Landmark Zone 2 is built and feels different from Zone 1
  • Zone contains multiple obstacles with a clear path
  • Kill bricks are placed strategically throughout the zone
  • A checkpoint is placed at the end of the zone and works correctly
  • You can complete the zone from start to checkpoint
  • The zone takes 30-60 seconds to complete

What's Next

Zone 2 is complete, but you're just getting started. Next up: Landmark Zone 3, where you'll push your design skills even further. Each zone should teach you something new about level design. By the time you finish all five zones, you'll have a complete island runner that shows real variety and skill.

Great level design isn't about making things hardit's about making things interesting. Keep that in mind as you build.

planets.title: Landmark Zone 3
planets.description: Create your third landmark obstacle area
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
The Midpoint Test

You've built two zones. Players are settling into your game's rhythm. They understand what you're about. Zone 3 is where many games failit's easy to run out of ideas and just repeat what worked before. But you're not building "just another zone." You're building the midpoint, the place that determines whether players keep going or quit.

Zone 3 needs to surprise them. Not with randomness, but with something new that still feels like it belongs in your game. Maybe it's a new obstacle type. Maybe it's a dramatic visual change. Maybe it's a difficulty spike that demands mastery of skills learned in Zones 1 and 2.

Your mission: create a landmark zone that proves you have more tricks up your sleeve.

Mission Objective

Build Landmark Zone 3 with a new obstacle pattern or challenge type that feels fresh while maintaining connection to the overall game design.

The Innovation Challenge

Before building, ask yourself: what haven't I done yet? Review Zones 1 and 2. Write down what obstacle types you've already used:

  • Simple gaps between platforms?
  • Tight corridors?
  • Vertical climbs?
  • Small platform parkour?
  • Timed sequences?

Now pick something different. Here are ideas organized by what makes them unique:

New Idea 1: The Spiral

Build platforms that spiral upward around a central point. Players circle around as they climb. This creates a 3D navigation challengethey need to understand where they are in space, not just move forward. Great if your previous zones were flat and linear.

New Idea 2: The Choice Path

Create a fork where two paths diverge. One path is shorter but harder (smaller platforms, bigger gaps). The other is longer but easier (larger platforms, more safe spots). Both paths lead to the same checkpoint. This introduces strategydo you risk the hard path for speed or take the safe route?

New Idea 3: The Descending Challenge

Most zones go up or stay flat. What if this one goes down? Build a series of platforms that descend into a pit. The challenge: you can't see what's below until you jump. Requires trust and precision. Place the checkpoint at the bottom.

New Idea 4: The Obstacle Course

Instead of gaps between platforms, fill the space with obstacles to navigate around. Build walls that jut out, forcing players to walk around them. Add low barriers they must jump over. Create a confined path where precise movement matters more than big jumps.

New Idea 5: The Size Shift

Make this zone either much bigger or much smaller than previous zones. Huge platforms with massive gaps, or tiny platforms requiring pixel-perfect jumps. The scale change alone makes it feel new.

Try It: Pick Your Innovation

Choose ONE of the ideas above (or create your own). Write it down. Sketch a rough layout on paper or visualize it. The key: commit to making this zone feel different from Zones 1 and 2.

Building with Purpose

Let's build a specific example: The Spiral. This teaches 3D thinking and looks impressive.

Step 1: Build the Center

Create a large cylinder or tower that will be your spiral's center point. This is visual referenceplayers will see it and understand they're circling it. Make it tall (60+ studs) and anchor it.

Step 2: Build the First Platform

Create the landing platform where players arrive from Zone 2. Position it at the base of your central tower, offset to one side. Make it safe and large (10x10 studs).

Step 3: Build the Spiral Path

Now build platforms that circle the tower going upward:

  1. Create a platform 8 studs away from the first, rotated 45 degrees around the tower
  2. Raise it 4 studs higher than the landing platform
  3. Create the next platform, rotated another 45 degrees, 4 studs higher
  4. Continue this patterneach platform rotates around and goes up
  5. After one full rotation (8 platforms), you should be about 32 studs higher
  6. Build 2-3 full rotations total

Step 4: Add Kill Bricks

Place kill brick parts in the gaps between spiral platforms. Make them large enough to catch falling players but small enough to be visible as danger. Use your kill brick script from Star 4.

Step 5: Add the Checkpoint

At the top of the spiral, build a large final platform and place your checkpoint. Make this platform bigplayers just did something hard and need space to celebrate.

Spiral Building Tips

  • Consistent spacing: Keep rotation angle and height increase the same for each platform. This creates predictable rhythm.
  • Platform size: Start with 6x6 platforms. If it's too easy, shrink to 5x5. If too hard, expand to 7x7.
  • Visual guides: Add small parts or arrows pointing to the next platform. Players can get disoriented in 3D.
  • Test the camera: The camera might fight you on spirals. Playtest to ensure players can see where they're going.

Alternative Build: The Choice Path

If spirals aren't your style, here's how to build a choice path zone:

  1. Build the landing platform (10x10 studs)
  2. Build two platforms ahead of it, positioned left and right (the fork)
  3. Left path (hard): Build 8-10 small platforms (4x4 studs) with 6-7 stud gaps
  4. Right path (easy): Build 12-15 larger platforms (7x7 studs) with 5 stud gaps
  5. Both paths should take roughly the same time, just different skill levels
  6. Build a final platform where both paths merge
  7. Place checkpoint on the merge platform
  8. Add kill bricks under all platforms

The beauty of choice paths: they accommodate different skill levels. Struggling players take the easy route. Confident players challenge themselves with the hard route. Everyone wins.

Try It: Signaling Choice

If you build a choice path, make the choice obvious. Color the hard path red and easy path green. Or place signs using text labels. Players should know what they're choosing.

Difficulty Calibration

Zone 3 is your midpoint. It should be harder than Zones 1 and 2, but not brutal. Here's a calibration guide:

  • Zone 1: Takes 3-5 attempts for new players to complete
  • Zone 2: Takes 5-8 attempts to complete
  • Zone 3: Should take 8-12 attempts to complete

Test this yourself. Delete your checkpoint progress and run through from Zone 1 to Zone 3. Count your deaths in Zone 3. If you're dying 20+ times and you built it, players will struggle too much. Adjust.

Visual Identity

By Zone 3, players should see a visual progression. Each zone should have its own color scheme or style. This creates a sense of journey.

Ideas for Zone 3 visual identity:

  • Color theme: Pick a color palette you haven't used. If Zones 1-2 were blues and greens, try oranges and purples.
  • Material choice: Use a different material. If you've used SmoothPlastic, try Neon or Metal for Zone 3.
  • Decorative elements: Add non-functional parts that look cool. Floating spheres, pillars, archesthings that create atmosphere.
  • Lighting prep: While you won't add lighting until Star 6, build this zone thinking about it. Leave space for spotlights or ambient glow.

The Rule of Three

In game design, three is a magic number. Players see two zones, they start to predict patterns. Three zones confirms those patterns. You're teaching players how your game works. Zone 1 introduces, Zone 2 reinforces, Zone 3 expands. Keep this rhythm in mind.

Playtesting Protocol

Testing Zone 3 requires fresh eyes. You've been building for a whileyou know this zone too well. Here's how to test effectively:

  1. Wait 10 minutes: After building, take a break. Get water, stretch, do something else. Come back fresh.
  2. Full playthrough: Start from the spawn point, run through Zones 1, 2, and 3. Does Zone 3 feel like a natural progression or a sudden spike?
  3. Count deaths: Track where you die most. If one obstacle kills you 80% of the time, it's probably too hard.
  4. Check the clock: Time how long Zone 3 takes. Aim for 40-60 seconds for a successful run. If it's taking 90+ seconds, it might be too long.
  5. The fun test: Are you having fun? If running through your own zone feels like a chore, players will hate it. Good zones are fun even when you fail.

Try It: The Perspective Shift

Playtest with different camera angles. Zoom in close, zoom out far. Does your zone work from all views? If it only works from one specific camera angle, that's a design flaw. Fix it.

Common Zone 3 Mistakes

Avoid these traps:

  • Too much innovation: Don't make Zone 3 completely alien. It should feel new but still part of the same game.
  • Copying Zones 1-2: The opposite problem. If Zone 3 is just "more of the same," players will check out mentally.
  • Difficulty spike: Making Zone 3 way harder than Zone 2 frustrates players. Ramp difficulty gradually.
  • Visual chaos: Adding too many decorations or colors. Keep it clean and readable.
  • Unclear path: Players should always know where to go next. If they're confused, add visual guides.

Final Checks

Before moving on, verify:

  • Zone 3 introduces something new (pattern, visual style, or challenge type)
  • All parts are anchored
  • Kill bricks are scripted and CanCollide = false
  • Checkpoint is placed and working
  • You can complete Zones 1-3 in sequence without game-breaking bugs
  • Zone 3 is harder than Zone 2 but not impossibly so
  • Visual style is distinct from previous zones

Mission Check

Before proceeding, verify:

  • Landmark Zone 3 is built with a new obstacle pattern or challenge type
  • Zone maintains visual and gameplay connection to Zones 1-2
  • Checkpoint is placed and functional at zone end
  • Zone difficulty is calibrated (harder than Zone 2, not brutal)
  • You can complete all three zones in sequence
  • Zone has distinct visual identity (color, materials, or style)

What's Next

Three zones down, and your island runner is taking shape. But we're about to level up your game in a major way. Next mission: moving platforms powered by TweenService. This is where your zones go from static obstacle courses to dynamic, living challenges. Get ready to learn one of the most powerful tools in Roblox game development.

planets.title: Moving Platforms
planets.description: Add TweenService-powered moving parts to one zone
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Bringing Zones to Life

Think about classic platformers like Super Mario or Sonic. What makes them exciting isn't just jumping over gapsit's jumping onto platforms that move. Platforms that test your timing, your reflexes, your ability to predict motion. A moving platform transforms a simple jump into a dynamic puzzle.

In Roblox, we create moving parts using TweenService, a powerful animation system that smoothly moves objects from one position to another. No complex physics, no janky teleportingjust smooth, professional-looking motion.

Your mission: add moving platforms to one of your zones and watch it come alive.

Mission Objective

Use TweenService to create at least three moving platforms in one of your landmark zones, creating a dynamic obstacle challenge that requires timing and prediction.

Understanding TweenService

TweenService is Roblox's built-in animation system. "Tween" is short for "in-between"it automatically fills in the motion between a start position and end position. You tell it where to start, where to end, and how long it should take. TweenService handles the rest.

Here's what you need to know:

  • Start position: Where the part currently is (its current CFrame)
  • End position: Where you want it to go (a new CFrame you define)
  • Duration: How many seconds the movement takes
  • Easing style: How the movement feels (smooth, bouncy, sharp, etc.)
  • Repeat: Whether it loops forever or plays once

Your First Moving Platform

Let's build a simple platform that moves back and forth horizontally. Choose one of your zones (Zone 2 or 3 works well) and find a spot where a moving platform would add challenge.

Step 1: Create the Platform

  1. Insert a Part into your workspace
  2. Size it: 8x1x8 studs (a nice platform size)
  3. Color it differently from static platforms (maybe bright green)
  4. Material: Neon (makes it obvious it's special)
  5. Anchor it: YES (tweens work on anchored parts)
  6. Position it where you want the movement to START
  7. Name it "MovingPlatform1"

Step 2: Create the Script

Right-click the platform in Explorer, select "Insert Object," then "Script." This creates a script inside the part. Delete any default code and add this:

-- Moving Platform Script
local platform = script.Parent
local TweenService = game:GetService("TweenService")

-- Define start and end positions
local startPosition = platform.CFrame
local endPosition = startPosition + Vector3.new(20, 0, 0)  -- Moves 20 studs in X direction

-- Tween settings
local tweenInfo = TweenInfo.new(
    3,  -- Duration in seconds
    Enum.EasingStyle.Linear,  -- Movement style
    Enum.EasingDirection.InOut,  -- Easing direction
    -1,  -- Repeat count (-1 = infinite)
    true,  -- Reverses (goes back and forth)
    0  -- Delay between repeats
)

-- Create the tween
local tweenForward = TweenService:Create(
    platform,
    tweenInfo,
    {CFrame = endPosition}
)

-- Start the tween
tweenForward:Play()

Understanding the Code

Let's break down what each part does:

  • local platform = script.Parent - Gets the part this script is inside
  • local TweenService = game:GetService("TweenService") - Accesses Roblox's tween system
  • local startPosition = platform.CFrame - Saves where the platform starts
  • local endPosition = startPosition + Vector3.new(20, 0, 0) - Calculates end position (20 studs to the right)
  • TweenInfo.new(...) - Creates tween settings (duration, style, looping, etc.)
  • TweenService:Create(...) - Creates the actual tween animation
  • tweenForward:Play() - Starts the animation

Try It: Your First Moving Platform

Copy the code above into your platform's script. Hit Play. Watch the platform move back and forth. Jump on it while it's moving. Feels different, right? That's the power of dynamic obstacles.

Customizing Movement

Now that you have one working, let's explore variations:

Vertical Movement

To make a platform move up and down instead of side to side, change the Vector3 line:

local endPosition = startPosition + Vector3.new(0, 15, 0)  -- Moves 15 studs UP

Diagonal Movement

Want it to move diagonally? Combine X, Y, and Z values:

local endPosition = startPosition + Vector3.new(10, 10, 0)  -- Moves right and up

Adjusting Speed

The first number in TweenInfo is duration in seconds. Lower = faster, higher = slower:

local tweenInfo = TweenInfo.new(
    2,  -- Faster (2 seconds instead of 3)
    -- ... rest stays the same
)

Changing Easing Style

Easing style changes how movement feels. Try these options:

  • Enum.EasingStyle.Linear - Constant speed (current setting)
  • Enum.EasingStyle.Sine - Smooth, gentle motion
  • Enum.EasingStyle.Bounce - Bounces at the end
  • Enum.EasingStyle.Elastic - Rubber band effect
  • Enum.EasingStyle.Quad - Accelerates and decelerates

Try It: Experiment with Easing

Change the EasingStyle to Bounce or Elastic. Play the game. The movement feels completely different. Choose styles that match your zone's feelsmooth for calm zones, bouncy for chaotic zones.

Building a Moving Platform Challenge

One moving platform is cool. Multiple moving platforms create a challenge. Here's how to design a sequence:

Pattern 1: The Conveyor

Create 3-4 platforms that all move horizontally in the same direction, but staggered so they're never all in the same position at once. Players must jump from platform to platform as they move.

  1. Create 4 platforms, space them 10 studs apart
  2. Give each the same movement script (moving 20 studs horizontally)
  3. Start each platform at a different point in its cycle (we'll do this with delay)

To stagger the start times, add a wait before playing the tween:

-- Add this BEFORE tweenForward:Play()
wait(0)  -- First platform: no delay
-- For second platform script, use: wait(0.75)
-- For third platform: wait(1.5)
-- For fourth platform: wait(2.25)

tweenForward:Play()

Pattern 2: The Elevator

Create platforms that move vertically at different speeds, creating a climbing challenge.

  1. Build 3 platforms vertically stacked
  2. First platform: moves up 10 studs in 4 seconds
  3. Second platform: moves up 15 studs in 3 seconds (faster)
  4. Third platform: moves up 20 studs in 5 seconds (slower but farther)

Pattern 3: The Crossroads

Create two sets of platforms that move perpendicular to each other (one horizontal, one vertical). Players must time jumps to avoid getting knocked off.

Design Tips for Moving Platforms

  • Predictability: Players should be able to see the pattern. Don't make movement random.
  • Safe spots: Include static platforms nearby where players can wait and observe movement.
  • Visual distinction: Make moving platforms look different (color, material, or add trails/particles later).
  • Test timing: Can you complete the sequence in under 30 seconds? If not, it's too slow or complex.
  • Checkpoint placement: Put a checkpoint AFTER moving platform challenges, not before. They're hardreward completion.

Advanced: Circular Motion

Want platforms that move in circles? This requires a different approach using CFrame rotation:

-- Circular Moving Platform
local platform = script.Parent
local TweenService = game:GetService("TweenService")

local centerPoint = platform.CFrame  -- Center of rotation
local radius = 15  -- How far from center
local duration = 8  -- Seconds for one full rotation

-- Create rotation tween
local tweenInfo = TweenInfo.new(
    duration,
    Enum.EasingStyle.Linear,
    Enum.EasingDirection.InOut,
    -1,  -- Infinite loop
    false,  -- Don't reverse
    0
)

-- Rotate around Y axis
for i = 0, 360, 10 do
    local angle = math.rad(i)
    local offsetX = math.cos(angle) * radius
    local offsetZ = math.sin(angle) * radius
    local newPosition = centerPoint + Vector3.new(offsetX, 0, offsetZ)

    platform.CFrame = newPosition
    wait(duration / 36)  -- Smooth rotation
end

This script is more advancedit uses math to calculate circular motion. You don't need to fully understand the math yet, but you can use it to create cool circular platform paths.

Common Mistakes and Fixes

Mistake 1: Platform Not Moving

Problem: Platform stays still when you play the game.

Fix: Check that the platform is anchored. Unanchored parts don't tween properly. Also verify the script is inside the platform part.

Mistake 2: Platform Teleports Instead of Tweening

Problem: Platform jumps between positions instead of moving smoothly.

Fix: Make sure you're using TweenService:Create correctly and calling :Play() on the tween. Double-check your code matches the examples.

Mistake 3: Can't Stand on Moving Platform

Problem: Player slides off or doesn't move with the platform.

Fix: This is normal Roblox behavior. For better platform riding, you can add AssemblyLinearVelocity, but that's advanced. For now, design jumps that don't require staying on the platform long.

Mistake 4: Platforms Collide with Each Other

Problem: Multiple moving platforms bump into each other and stop.

Fix: Set CanCollide to false on one or both platforms, OR space them farther apart so paths don't overlap.

Try It: The Timing Challenge

Build a sequence of three moving platforms. Time yourself jumping across all three. If it takes more than 15 seconds, players will get frustrated. Speed up the platforms or shorten the movement distance.

Where to Add Moving Platforms

You have three zones built. Where should moving platforms go? Here's guidance:

  • Zone 1: Probably skip. It's your intro zonekeep it simple.
  • Zone 2: Good candidate if Zone 2 is currently easier than Zone 3.
  • Zone 3: Best candidate. It's your midpointadding moving platforms here raises the stakes.

You don't need to replace the entire zone. Add moving platforms to one sectionmaybe replace 3-4 static platforms with moving ones. This creates variety within the zone itself.

Playtesting Moving Platforms

Moving platforms change everything about difficulty. Retest your zone after adding them:

  1. Can you complete the zone with moving platforms in under 1 minute?
  2. Are the platforms moving too fast to jump onto? (If yes, increase duration)
  3. Are they moving too slow and boring? (If yes, decrease duration)
  4. Can you see the pattern and predict movement? (If no, slow them down or simplify)
  5. Is it fun? Challenging but fair, not frustrating?

The Fun Factor

Moving platforms should feel like a dance, not a fight. Players should learn the rhythm, predict the motion, and feel skilled when they nail the timing. If it feels random or impossible, revise.

Expanding Your Knowledge

TweenService can animate any property, not just position:

  • Size: Make platforms grow and shrink
  • Transparency: Make platforms fade in and out
  • Color: Make platforms change color as they move
  • Rotation: Make platforms spin

Example of tweening transparency (makes platform invisible):

local tweenInfo = TweenInfo.new(2, Enum.EasingStyle.Linear, Enum.EasingDirection.InOut, -1, true, 0)
local tween = TweenService:Create(platform, tweenInfo, {Transparency = 1})  -- 1 = invisible
tween:Play()

Combining tweensmoving AND fadingcreates really cool effects. Experiment after you finish the basic requirements.

Mission Check

Before proceeding, verify:

  • You have at least 3 moving platforms in one of your zones
  • All moving platforms use TweenService (not while loops or manual movement)
  • Platforms move smoothly and predictably
  • You can complete the zone with moving platforms included
  • Scripts are properly attached to each moving platform
  • Movement patterns create a timing challenge, not a frustration

What's Next

You've just added one of the most professional features to your game. TweenService is what separates amateur projects from polished games. But you're not done building yet. Next up: Landmark Zones 4 and 5, where you'll complete your island runner with two final challenge areas. Let's finish strong.

planets.title: Landmark Zones 4-5
planets.description: Complete remaining landmark areas with varied challenges
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
The Final Gauntlet

You've built three zones. You've mastered moving platforms. You understand checkpoints, kill bricks, and TweenService. Now it's time to bring everything together in your final two zones.

Zone 4 is your difficulty peakthe hardest challenge in your game. It's where skilled players prove themselves. Zone 5 is your conclusionstill hard, but also a victory lap, a showcase of your best ideas, and a satisfying ending to the journey.

These zones will define whether your game is memorable or forgettable. No pressure, but this is where you leave your mark.

Mission Objective

Build Landmark Zones 4 and 5, creating a difficulty peak and satisfying conclusion while maintaining variety and quality throughout your entire island runner.

The Complete Arc

Before building, understand the full arc of your five zones:

  • Zone 1: Introduction. Simple, teaches basic mechanics.
  • Zone 2: Escalation. Introduces new patterns, slightly harder.
  • Zone 3: Midpoint twist. Something new happens (maybe your moving platforms?).
  • Zone 4: Peak difficulty. The hardest challenge.
  • Zone 5: Resolution. Hard but satisfying, brings ideas together.

This is classic game design structure. Players understand it intuitively. Zone 4 is where they sweat. Zone 5 is where they triumph.

Try It: Map Your Difficulty Curve

On paper, draw a line graph. X-axis is zones 1-5. Y-axis is difficulty (1-10). Plot where you think each zone currently sits. Zone 1 should be around 3-4. Zone 2 around 5-6. Zone 3 around 6-7. Zone 4 should peak at 8-9. Zone 5 should be 7-8 (slightly easier than 4). Does your graph show this curve? If not, adjust your plan.

Building Zone 4: The Gauntlet

Zone 4 is your hardest zone. It should combine multiple challenge types from previous zones and add new complexity.

Design Philosophy for Zone 4

Don't just make it "harder" by making jumps impossible. Make it harder by making it complexmultiple things happening at once, longer sequences without breaks, tighter timing windows.

Recommended Pattern: The Combination Zone

Build Zone 4 using elements from all previous zones:

  1. Opening: Start with a familiar pattern (like Zone 1's simple jumps) but faster/tighter
  2. Section 2: Add moving platforms (from Zone 3) in a harder configuration
  3. Section 3: Mix vertical and horizontal movement
  4. Section 4: Create a final test that requires precision
  5. Checkpoint: Place at the end as a huge relief moment

Specific Build Example: The Ascending Spiral with Moving Obstacles

Here's a complete Zone 4 build you can follow or adapt:

  1. Base platform: Large landing area (10x10 studs)
  2. Phase 1 - Speed test: Build 6 platforms in a line, gaps of 6.5 studs, forces quick jumping
  3. Phase 2 - Moving platforms: Add 4 moving platforms that go vertical (up/down), stagger their timing
  4. Rest platform: Medium safe platform for catching breath
  5. Phase 3 - Spiral climb: Build a spiral (like Zone 3) but with smaller platforms (5x5 instead of 6x6)
  6. Phase 4 - Final jump: Single hard jump to final platform (7 studs gap)
  7. Checkpoint platform: Large platform (12x12) with checkpoint part

This design combines speed, timing (moving platforms), 3D navigation (spiral), and a climactic final jump. It uses everything players learned but at higher difficulty.

Zone 4 Design Tips

  • Length: Zone 4 should be longer than previous zones (60-90 seconds when played perfectly)
  • Checkpoints: Consider adding TWO checkpointsone at the midpoint, one at the end. Long hard zones need midpoint saves.
  • Visual drama: Make it look intimidating. Use darker colors, bigger structures, more complex geometry.
  • Fair difficulty: Hard doesn't mean impossible. Everything should be achievable with practice.

Building Zone 5: The Victory Lap

Zone 5 is special. It's the ending. Players who reach it should feel accomplished, and the zone should deliver a satisfying conclusion.

Design Philosophy for Zone 5

Zone 5 should be hardplayers earned the right to be challenged. But it shouldn't be harder than Zone 4. Think of it as "Zone 4's difficulty but more fun" or "a celebration of everything you built."

Recommended Pattern: The Greatest Hits

Build Zone 5 as a showcase of your best obstacles from Zones 1-4, remixed in new ways:

  1. Take your favorite obstacle from Zone 1rebuild it here but elevated
  2. Take the coolest part of Zone 2include a variation
  3. Use moving platforms again, but in a new pattern
  4. Add one final unique elementsomething you didn't do in Zones 1-4

Specific Build Example: The Grand Finale Path

  1. Entrance: Grand archway or structure signaling "this is the end"
  2. Section 1: Recreate your best static obstacle sequence from earlier zones
  3. Section 2: Moving platforms that create a rhythm challenge
  4. Section 3: A choice path (callback to Zone 3 if you built one, or new)
  5. Section 4: Final approacha dramatic, climactic sequence (spiral to a peak, long jump sequence, etc.)
  6. Victory platform: Massive final platform with checkpoint and maybe decorative elements (trophies, sparkles, whatever feels victorious)

Try It: The Finale Element

Add one thing to Zone 5 you haven't done yet. Maybe it's rotating platforms. Maybe it's a color-changing platform sequence. Maybe it's platforms that grow and shrink. Use TweenService to animate something new. This makes Zone 5 memorable.

Maintaining Variety Across All Zones

With five zones built, check for variety. Run through your entire game and ask:

  • Does each zone feel different?
  • Are you using different colors/materials for each zone?
  • Do obstacles repeat too much, or is there good variation?
  • Can you describe each zone with a unique phrase? ("The spiral zone," "The moving platform zone," etc.)

If two zones feel too similar, revise one. Similarity breeds boredom.

Difficulty Calibration Across All Zones

Now that all five zones exist, playtest the ENTIRE game in one sitting. From spawn to Zone 5 checkpoint. Track this data:

  • Total completion time: Should be 4-7 minutes for a skilled player
  • Death count per zone: Zone 1 (0-3 deaths), Zone 2 (3-6), Zone 3 (5-10), Zone 4 (10-15), Zone 5 (8-12)
  • Frustration points: Any obstacle that kills you 5+ times is too hardrevise it

If your death counts are way higher, your game is too hard. Lower gaps, add safe platforms, or slow down moving platforms. If death counts are way lower, your game might be too easy. Increase challenge.

The 10-Minute Rule

A complete run of your game (spawn to final checkpoint) should take 10-15 minutes for a new player, 4-7 minutes for a skilled player. If it's taking 30+ minutes, it's too long or too hard. Edit.

Visual Progression

Your zones should show visual progression. Here's a proven color/style progression:

  • Zone 1: Bright, simple colors (blues, greens) - feels safe and friendly
  • Zone 2: Slightly darker or more saturated colors - feels more serious
  • Zone 3: New color family (oranges, purples) - signals midpoint
  • Zone 4: Dark, intense colors (reds, blacks) - feels dangerous
  • Zone 5: Bright again, but different (golds, whites, neon) - feels triumphant

This creates an emotional journey through color alone. Players feel the progression even if they're not consciously noticing it.

Adding Polish to Zones 4-5

Since these are your final zones, add extra polish:

Decorative Elements

  • Add non-functional parts that look cool (pillars, arches, floating shapes)
  • Use a variety of part shapes (not just rectangular blocks)
  • Add small details (small spheres, wedges, cylinders as accents)

Size and Scale

  • Make Zone 4 feel big and imposing (larger structures, taller obstacles)
  • Make Zone 5 feel grand and expansive (wide platforms, open space)

Scripting Polish

  • Make sure all moving platforms in Zones 4-5 have smooth, predictable motion
  • Test all checkpoints to ensure they save progress correctly
  • Verify all kill bricks kill instantly (CanCollide = false, script working)

Try It: The Victory Moment

At the end of Zone 5, after the checkpoint, add a finish zone trigger (like you built in Star 4). When players touch it, fire a message: "You completed the Island Runner! Great job!" This gives closure.

Common Mistakes in Final Zones

Mistake 1: Difficulty Spike in Zone 5

Making Zone 5 harder than Zone 4 frustrates players. They expect the hardest challenge earlier, not at the very end. Keep Zone 5 challenging but slightly easier than Zone 4.

Mistake 2: Repetitive Design

Zones 4-5 that feel identical to earlier zones. Always ask: "What makes THIS zone special?" If you can't answer, redesign.

Mistake 3: Exhausting Length

Making Zones 4-5 too long. Players are tired by this point. Long zones need midpoint checkpoints or shorter obstacle sequences.

Mistake 4: Anticlimax

Zone 5 ending abruptly with no celebration. Add a victory platform, a message, something that says "You did it!" Endings matter.

Final Playtesting

With all five zones complete, do a comprehensive playtest:

  1. Full run: Complete the game from spawn to Zone 5 end. No skipping.
  2. Checkpoint test: Die intentionally in each zone, verify you respawn at correct checkpoints.
  3. Difficulty check: Does difficulty increase smoothly from Zone 1 to 4, then slightly decrease in 5?
  4. Visual check: Does each zone look distinct from the others?
  5. Fun check: Are you having fun? If you're bored or frustrated with your own game, players will be too.

The Fresh Eyes Test

If possible, have someone else play your complete game. Don't give instructionsjust watch. Where do they get stuck? Where do they struggle? Where do they smile? Their experience reveals what you can't see anymore because you've tested it too much.

Checkpoint Placement Strategy

Review checkpoint placement across all zones:

  • Zone 1: One checkpoint at the end
  • Zone 2: One checkpoint at the end
  • Zone 3: One checkpoint at the end (or two if it's very long)
  • Zone 4: Two checkpoints (midpoint and end) - it's the hardest
  • Zone 5: One or two checkpoints depending on length

More checkpoints = easier. Fewer = harder. Balance this based on your difficulty goals.

Preparing for the Next Star

Once Zones 4-5 are built, you're done with world building. Next up: flow testing (Mission 5.5), where you'll refine the entire experience. After that, Star 6 covers polishlighting, skyboxes, and final details.

Your game is nearly complete. These final two zones are the foundation of that completion. Build them with care.

Mission Check

Before proceeding, verify:

  • Zone 4 is built and is the hardest zone in your game
  • Zone 5 is built and provides a satisfying conclusion
  • Both zones have checkpoints placed appropriately
  • All five zones have distinct visual identities
  • Difficulty progression follows the curve (1-2-3-4-5 with 4 as peak)
  • You can complete all five zones in sequence
  • Total game completion time is reasonable (4-15 minutes depending on skill)
  • All moving platforms, kill bricks, and checkpoints work correctly

What's Next

Five zones. Complete. Now comes the critical phase: flow testing. You'll play through your entire game multiple times, adjusting difficulty curves, fixing frustration points, and ensuring the experience flows smoothly from start to finish. This is where good games become great games.

planets.title: Flow Testing
planets.description: Play through the entire course and adjust difficulty curves
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
The Refining Process

Every game you've ever loved went through this phasehundreds of hours of testing, tweaking, and polishing. The first build of Super Mario wasn't perfect. The first build of any great game wasn't perfect. What made them great was the refining process: playing, finding problems, fixing them, and playing again.

Your island runner is built, but it's not finished. Finishing means testing it until you can complete it smoothly, until the difficulty curve feels right, until frustration points are eliminated, until the flow from Zone 1 to Zone 5 feels intentional and satisfying.

This mission is about iterationmaking your game better through systematic testing and improvement. This is where you learn to think like a game designer.

Mission Objective

Complete at least five full playthroughs of your island runner, documenting problems and implementing fixes to create a smooth, well-paced game experience.

The Flow Testing Process

Flow testing isn't just "playing your game." It's a systematic process with specific goals. Here's the methodology:

The Five-Run Framework

  1. Run 1: The Experience Run - Play through completely, focus on how it FEELS
  2. Run 2: The Data Run - Track specific metrics (deaths, times, etc.)
  3. Run 3: The Problem Run - Identify every frustration point
  4. Run 4: The Fix Verification Run - Test your improvements
  5. Run 5: The Polish Run - Final sweep for small issues

Each run has a different focus. Let's break them down.

Run 1: The Experience Run

Reset your spawn point (or delete checkpoint progress). Play through your game from spawn to Zone 5 completion. Don't take notes yetjust experience it as a player would.

After completing, immediately write down your gut reactions:

  • Which zone was the most fun? Why?
  • Which zone was the most frustrating? Why?
  • Did any zone feel too long or too short?
  • Were there moments where you didn't know where to go?
  • Did difficulty feel like a smooth ramp or were there spikes?
  • How did the ending feel? Satisfying or anticlimactic?

Try It: The Gut Check
