Write down three things that felt GOOD and three things that felt BAD. Be honest. Your gut reaction is often rightif something felt frustrating to you, it'll frustrate players too.

Run 2: The Data Run

Now play through again, but this time collect data. Use a stopwatch (phone timer works) and paper to track:

Metrics to Track

Zone Completion Time Death Count Hardest Obstacle
Zone 1 _____ seconds _____ deaths _____
Zone 2 _____ seconds _____ deaths _____
Zone 3 _____ seconds _____ deaths _____
Zone 4 _____ seconds _____ deaths _____
Zone 5 _____ seconds _____ deaths _____
TOTAL _____ _____

Analyzing Your Data

Look at your numbers. Here's what healthy data looks like:

  • Completion times: Should increase from Zone 1 to Zone 4, then stay similar or decrease slightly in Zone 5
  • Death counts: Should increase progressively (Zone 1: 0-3, Zone 2: 3-6, Zone 3: 5-10, Zone 4: 10-15, Zone 5: 8-12)
  • Total time: 4-10 minutes is ideal for skilled players (you)
  • Total deaths: 25-40 deaths is reasonable for a challenging platformer

If your numbers deviate significantly, you have work to do.

Red Flags in Data

  • Zone 2 harder than Zone 4: Difficulty curve is broken. Revise Zone 2 or Zone 4.
  • 50+ deaths in one zone: That zone is too hard. Simplify obstacles or add checkpoints.
  • 0 deaths in Zone 3+: Later zones are too easy. Add challenge.
  • One obstacle causing 10+ deaths: That's a frustration point. Fix it.

Run 3: The Problem Run

This run focuses on finding specific problems. As you play, pause and write down every issue you encounter:

Common Problems to Look For

1. Frustration Points

An obstacle that kills you repeatedly without feeling fair. Characteristics:

  • 5+ deaths on the same obstacle
  • Success feels like luck, not skill
  • You can't see the solution or what you're doing wrong

Fix: Make the obstacle easier (shorter gap, larger platform), add visual guides, or add a safe platform before it so players can study it.

2. Dead Zones

Areas where nothing happens for too long. Characteristics:

  • Long stretches of walking with no challenge
  • Safe platforms that are too large or too long
  • Gaps between zones that feel empty

Fix: Shorten safe platforms, add small obstacles to "dead" areas, or tighten zone transitions.

3. Confusion Points

Places where you don't know where to go next. Characteristics:

  • Multiple paths and the correct one isn't obvious
  • Next platform is hidden or hard to see
  • Visual clutter makes navigation unclear

Fix: Add visual guides (bright colors, arrows, or lights pointing to the next platform), remove ambiguous paths, or improve sightlines.

4. Pacing Issues

Zones that feel too long, too short, or poorly timed. Characteristics:

  • A zone takes 2+ minutes to complete (too long)
  • A zone takes less than 30 seconds (too short)
  • Difficulty spikes suddenly instead of ramping

Fix: Add or remove obstacles to adjust length. Insert easier obstacles between hard ones to smooth difficulty spikes.

5. Technical Issues

Bugs or scripting problems. Characteristics:

  • Checkpoint doesn't save progress
  • Kill brick doesn't kill
  • Moving platform glitches or moves incorrectly
  • Player falls through anchored platforms

Fix: Check scripts, verify properties (Anchored, CanCollide, etc.), and test each element individually.

Try It: The Problem List

Create a numbered list of every problem you find. Be specific: "Zone 3, the fourth moving platformgap is too large" not just "Zone 3 is hard." Specific problems get specific fixes.

Making Fixes

Now that you have a problem list, it's time to fix them. Work through your list systematically:

Prioritization

Fix problems in this order:

  1. Technical bugs: Broken scripts, non-functional checkpoints, etc.
  2. Frustration points: Obstacles that feel unfair or impossible
  3. Confusion points: Places where players get lost
  4. Pacing issues: Zones that are too long/short
  5. Dead zones: Empty or boring areas

Common Fixes

Adjusting Jump Difficulty

  • Too hard: Move platforms closer (reduce gap by 0.5-1 studs)
  • Too easy: Move platforms farther (increase gap by 0.5-1 studs)
  • Inconsistent: Standardize gapsmake similar jumps the same distance

Adjusting Moving Platforms

  • Too fast: Increase tween duration (change 2 seconds to 3 seconds)
  • Too slow: Decrease tween duration
  • Unpredictable: Use Linear easing style for consistent speed
  • Too hard to land on: Make platforms larger or slow them down

Adjusting Zone Length

  • Too long: Remove 2-3 obstacles or add a midpoint checkpoint
  • Too short: Add 2-3 obstacles that match the zone's theme

Improving Clarity

  • Add color coding: Make the "correct" path a bright color, alternate paths duller
  • Add guide parts: Small arrows or markers pointing to the next platform
  • Improve lighting: Make important platforms brighter (use Neon material)

The Small Changes Rule

Make small adjustments. Don't move a platform 10 studs if 2 studs might fix it. Test after each change. Small, iterative changes are safer than big overhauls.

Run 4: Fix Verification Run

After making fixes, play through again. This run verifies your changes worked:

  • Did the frustration points improve?
  • Are confusion points now clear?
  • Does pacing feel better?
  • Did you accidentally create new problems while fixing old ones?

Track deaths and times again. Compare to Run 2 data. Your numbers should improve:

  • Fewer deaths in zones you adjusted
  • Smoother time progression across zones
  • Fewer deaths on specific obstacles you fixed

If problems persist, adjust further. Sometimes fixes take multiple iterations.

Run 5: The Polish Run

Final playthrough focuses on small details:

  • Visual polish: Are there floating parts? Misaligned platforms? Color clashes?
  • Script polish: Do all checkpoints show console messages? Do kill bricks kill consistently?
  • Experience polish: Does the game feel complete? Is there a satisfying ending?

Polish Checklist

  • All platforms anchored
  • No z-fighting (overlapping parts that flicker)
  • Consistent color schemes within each zone
  • Checkpoints placed logically and working
  • Moving platforms move smoothly without glitching
  • Kill bricks clearly visible and functional
  • Spawn point is in the correct location
  • Victory/finish trigger at the end works (if you built one)

Try It: The Final Details Pass

Walk through your game in Edit mode (not Play mode). Look at every zone with fresh eyes. Find three small things to improvemaybe a platform needs recoloring, maybe a gap needs adjusting by 0.5 studs, maybe a kill brick needs to be slightly larger. Small details compound into big quality.

Getting Outside Feedback

If possible, have someone else play your game. Here's how to run a good playtest:

Playtest Protocol

  1. Don't give instructions: Just say "try to reach the end." See if they figure it out.
  2. Don't help: Watch where they struggle but don't intervene. Their struggles show design flaws.
  3. Take notes: Write down where they die, where they get confused, where they quit.
  4. Ask questions after: "What was most fun? Most frustrating? Did anything feel unfair?"

Interpreting Feedback

Not all feedback is useful, but patterns are:

  • One person struggles at spot X: Maybe they're not skilled. Monitor.
  • Three people struggle at spot X: Spot X is too hard. Fix it.
  • Someone says "this is too easy": They might be skilled. Don't overreact.
  • Someone quits in frustration: Big red flag. Find out exactly where and why, then fix it.

The Silent Playtest

Watch someone play without talking. Don't explain, don't hint, don't coach. Just watch. You'll learn more in five minutes of silent observation than in an hour of explanation. Their confusion is your design talking.

Difficulty Curve Visualization

After your five runs and fixes, create a final difficulty curve visualization:

  1. On paper, draw X-axis (zones 1-5) and Y-axis (difficulty 1-10)
  2. Plot your final death counts for each zone
  3. Connect the dots

Ideal curve: starts low (Zone 1), rises gradually (Zones 2-3), peaks at Zone 4, drops slightly in Zone 5. If your curve spikes randomly or stays flat, more adjustments needed.

Knowing When You're Done

How do you know when to stop testing and refining? Here are the signs:

  • You can complete the full game in under 8 minutes
  • Death counts follow a progressive curve (increasing toward Zone 4)
  • No single obstacle kills you more than 3-4 times
  • Each zone feels distinct and intentional
  • The ending feels satisfying
  • You're proud to show it to others

Perfection is impossible. "Good enough to be proud of" is the goal. If you've done five playthroughs, fixed major problems, and the game feels solid, you're done with flow testing.

Documenting Your Final State

Before finishing this mission, document your final game state:

  • Final completion time: _____ minutes
  • Final death count: _____ total deaths
  • Hardest zone: Zone _____
  • Most fun zone: Zone _____
  • Biggest improvement made: _____

Keep this documentation. When you revisit this project later or build future games, you'll want to remember what worked.

Try It: The Reflection

Write three sentences about what you learned from flow testing. What surprised you? What was harder than expected? What would you do differently next time? Reflection solidifies learning.

What Flow Testing Teaches

Flow testing isn't just about fixing bugs. It's about learning to see your work objectively, to prioritize problems, to make data-driven decisions. These skills transfer to every game you'll ever make.

Professional game developers spend MONTHS in this phase. You're spending one mission, but you're learning the same process: build, test, identify, fix, repeat. That's game development.

Mission Check

Before proceeding, verify:

  • Completed at least five full playthroughs of your game
  • Tracked data (deaths, times) for each zone
  • Identified and documented frustration points
  • Made adjustments to improve difficulty curve and flow
  • Verified all technical elements work (checkpoints, kill bricks, moving platforms)
  • Difficulty curve follows progressive pattern (peaks at Zone 4)
  • Game completion time is reasonable (4-10 minutes for skilled players)
  • No single obstacle causes excessive repeated deaths

What's Next

Your island runner is built and refined. The gameplay is solid. But great games aren't just functionalthey're beautiful. In Star 6: Polish Round, you'll add lighting, skyboxes, particles, and final details that transform your game from "working" to "professional." That's where the magic happens.

You've learned to build. You've learned to refine. Now you'll learn to polish.

stars.title: Polish Round
stars.description: Enhance visuals and fix rough edges

planets.title: Lighting and Atmosphere
planets.description: Configure Lighting settings for mood (time of day, fog, etc.)
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
First Impressions Matter

You've built an amazing island runner with five landmark zones that represent your real location. But when you first spawn in, does it feel right? Does it capture the atmosphere of your actual place?

Lighting is the difference between a game that looks flat and generic, and one that feels alive and specific. Whether your island should feel like a sunny Caribbean beach, a foggy Pacific Northwest forest, or a golden desert canyon, lighting tells that story instantly.

In this mission, you'll become the director of photography for your island runner, using Roblox's Lighting service to set the perfect mood.

Mission Objective

Configure Lighting service properties to establish mood and time of day that enhances the island theme

By the end of this mission, your island will have:

  • A specific time of day that matches your location's character
  • Atmospheric fog settings that add depth and mood
  • Ambient lighting that complements your color palette
  • Environmental effects that enhance immersion

Understanding the Lighting Service

The Lighting service is a singleton object in Roblox that controls how light behaves across your entire game. Unlike individual lights you place in the world, the Lighting service sets the global ruleswhat time of day is it? How bright is the sun? Is there fog in the distance?

Think of it like this: if your game were a photograph, the Lighting service would be all the camera settingsexposure, white balance, filters. It doesn't matter what's in the photo; these settings affect everything.

Step 1: Access the Lighting Service

The Lighting service lives at the top level of your game hierarchy:

  1. Open the Explorer panel (View tab Explorer)
  2. Scroll to find Lighting in the tree (it's alphabetically sorted among services like Workspace, Players, etc.)
  3. Click on Lighting to select it
  4. Open the Properties panel (View tab Properties)

You should now see dozens of properties. Don't worrywe'll focus on the most important ones for establishing atmosphere.

Step 2: Set Your Time of Day

The ClockTime property controls where the sun is in the sky, using a 0-24 hour format (14 = 2:00 PM, 18 = 6:00 PM, etc.).

Choosing Your Time of Day

  • Tropical/Beach Islands (14-16): Bright midday sun, sharp shadows, vibrant colorsthink postcards
  • Forest/Mountain Regions (8-10 or 16-18): Softer angles, longer shadows, golden or blue tones
  • Desert/Canyon Areas (17-19): Golden hour warmth, dramatic shadows, orange-red tones
  • Urban/City Settings (12-14): Neutral overhead lighting, clear visibility
  • Mysterious/Spooky Locations (6-7 or 19-20): Dawn/dusk blues, low angle light, atmospheric

Try It: Find Your Perfect Hour

  1. In the Lighting properties, find ClockTime
  2. Enter a starting value based on the guide above
  3. Press Play and run through your first zone
  4. Stop, adjust the ClockTime by 1-2 hours, and test again
  5. Repeat until the lighting feels right for your location

Pro tip: Don't just stand stillrun through your obstacles. Lighting changes how colors and shapes read during fast movement.

Step 3: Configure Fog for Depth

Fog serves two purposes: it adds atmospheric depth (making distant objects fade), and it can hide the fact that your game world has boundaries. Even subtle fog improves immersion.

Key Fog Properties

  • FogEnd: Distance (in studs) where objects are completely hidden by fog. Start with 1000-1500 for open areas, 500-800 for forests/cities.
  • FogStart: Distance where fog begins to appear. Usually 0 (fog starts immediately) or FogEnd 2 for more gradual fade.
  • FogColor: The color of the fog. Should complement your sky and overall palettelight blues for day, warm oranges for sunset, purple-grays for mystery.

Try It: Add Atmospheric Fog

  1. Find the FogEnd property and set it to 1200
  2. Set FogStart to 0
  3. Click the FogColor property to open the color picker
  4. Choose a color that matches your time of day:
    • Midday: Light sky blue (RGB: 200, 220, 255)
    • Golden hour: Warm peach (RGB: 255, 200, 150)
    • Dawn/Dusk: Soft purple-blue (RGB: 150, 160, 200)
  5. Test in Play modeyou should see distant platforms fade into fog

Step 4: Adjust Ambient Lighting

Ambient lighting controls how much light fills in the shadows. In real life, shadows aren't pure blackthey're filled with reflected light from the sky and surroundings.

Ambient Properties

  • Ambient: The color of light that fills indoor shadows and dark areas
  • OutdoorAmbient: The color of light that fills outdoor shadows (usually skylight color)
  • Brightness: Overall light intensity (1-3 range; 2 is standard outdoor daylight)

For most island runners, you'll want:

  • OutdoorAmbient: A desaturated version of your sky color (light blue for day, warm gray for sunset)
  • Ambient: Slightly darker than OutdoorAmbient, with subtle warmth (for indoor/shadowed areas)
  • Brightness: 2 for sunny days, 1.5 for overcast or dawn/dusk, 1 for night/mysterious

Step 5: Environmental Effects (Optional Advanced)

Roblox's Lighting service supports additional atmospheric effects you can add as child objects:

Effect Options

  • Atmosphere: Adds realistic aerial perspective and sky gradients (makes distant objects hazier and bluer)
  • BloomEffect: Makes bright lights glow and spread (good for magical/tropical vibes)
  • SunRaysEffect: Creates god rays/light shafts through trees or fog
  • ColorCorrectionEffect: Applies overall color grading (warm up, cool down, increase contrast)

Try It: Add an Atmosphere Effect

  1. Right-click on Lighting in the Explorer
  2. Select Insert Object Atmosphere
  3. Select the new Atmosphere object and open Properties
  4. Set Density to 0.3 (subtle atmospheric haze)
  5. Set Offset to 0.25 (controls where the atmosphere effect begins)
  6. Adjust Color to match your sky (usually leave as default light blue/gray)
  7. Test in Play modedistant objects should have more atmospheric depth

Note: Atmosphere effects can impact performance on lower-end devices. Test on target hardware if possible.

Location-Specific Examples

Here are complete lighting setups for different island types:

Tropical Beach Island (Hawaii, Caribbean, Philippines)

  • ClockTime: 14 (bright midday)
  • Brightness: 2
  • FogColor: RGB(190, 215, 255) - light sky blue
  • FogEnd: 1500
  • OutdoorAmbient: RGB(140, 160, 180)
  • Add Atmosphere (Density: 0.25) and BloomEffect (Intensity: 0.3)

Forest/Mountain Region (Pacific Northwest, Appalachia)

  • ClockTime: 9 (morning light through trees)
  • Brightness: 1.5
  • FogColor: RGB(180, 190, 200) - neutral gray-blue
  • FogEnd: 800
  • OutdoorAmbient: RGB(100, 120, 140)
  • Add Atmosphere (Density: 0.4) and SunRaysEffect (Intensity: 0.15)

Desert/Canyon (Southwest US, Australia)

  • ClockTime: 17 (golden hour)
  • Brightness: 1.8
  • FogColor: RGB(255, 190, 140) - warm peach
  • FogEnd: 2000
  • OutdoorAmbient: RGB(180, 140, 100)
  • Add ColorCorrectionEffect (Saturation: 0.1, TintColor: RGB(255, 240, 220))

Testing Your Lighting

Don't just test from the spawn point. Your lighting needs to work across all five zones:

  1. Play through the entire course and note any zones where visibility becomes a problem
  2. Check readability: Can you clearly see obstacles against the background at running speed?
  3. Verify mood consistency: Does the lighting feel coherent across all zones, or does one area feel disconnected?
  4. Test with others: Have a classmate play and ask if the lighting "feels right" for the location

Common Lighting Mistakes to Avoid

  • Too dark: If you can't clearly see obstacles, your lighting is too moody. Gameplay clarity comes first.
  • Mismatched fog color: Fog should blend with the sky, not contrast against it.
  • Overuse of effects: More isn't better. One or two subtle effects beat five dramatic ones.
  • Ignoring performance: Heavy fog or multiple effects can slow down older devices.

Mission Check

Before moving to the next mission, verify you have:

  • Set a specific ClockTime that enhances your island's real-world character
  • Configured fog properties (FogEnd, FogColor) that add atmospheric depth
  • Adjusted Ambient and OutdoorAmbient to fill shadows appropriately
  • Tested the lighting by playing through all five zones at running speed
  • Confirmed readability: Obstacles are clearly visible against backgrounds
  • Optional: Added at least one environmental effect (Atmosphere, Bloom, SunRays, or ColorCorrection)

Quality check: Ask yourself, "If I showed someone a screenshot, would they get a sense of what kind of place this is?" If yes, your lighting is working.

Next Mission: Skybox Selection

You've set the lighting and atmosphere for your island, but there's one more piece to the environmental puzzle: the sky itself. In the next mission, you'll choose and apply a skybox that completes your island's sense of placeturning that default Roblox sky into one that matches your real-world location perfectly.

planets.title: Skybox Selection
planets.description: Choose and apply a skybox that fits your island theme
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
The Sky Is Not the Limit

Look up in your island runner right now. You'll probably see Roblox's default skya generic blue gradient with some clouds. It's fine, but it's not yours.

Now imagine looking up and seeing the actual sky from your real-world location. The deep blue of a Caribbean afternoon. The hazy layers of mountain ridges fading into the distance. The golden-pink glow of a desert sunset. The dramatic clouds of a coastal storm.

The sky is 50% of what players see at any given moment (the other 50% is your island itself). It's worth getting it right.

In this mission, you'll choose and apply a skybox that transforms your game's background from "generic Roblox" to "this specific place."

Mission Objective

Choose and apply a skybox texture that complements the island theme and lighting configuration

By the end of this mission, your island will have:

  • A custom skybox that matches your real-world location's character
  • Sky colors and features that align with your ClockTime and lighting
  • A cohesive environmental feel from horizon to horizon
  • Visual continuity that enhances immersion without distracting from gameplay

Understanding Skyboxes

A skybox is a set of six square images (one for each face of a cube: up, down, left, right, front, back) that surrounds your game world. When you look around, you're actually looking at the inside of this enormous cubebut because it's textured seamlessly, it creates the illusion of an infinite sky and distant environment.

Think of it like being inside a planetarium: you're in a small room, but the projected images make you feel like you're under a vast sky.

Step 1: Evaluate Your Current Lighting

Before choosing a skybox, review the lighting settings you configured in Mission 6.1. Your skybox needs to match these choices, or it will feel visually disconnected.

Lighting-to-Skybox Alignment

  • ClockTime 6-8 (dawn): Look for skyboxes with sunrise colors, soft pinks and oranges low on horizon
  • ClockTime 10-14 (midday): Clear blue skies, bright white/yellow sun, minimal clouds or fair-weather clouds
  • ClockTime 16-18 (afternoon): Slightly warmer tones, sun lower in sky, longer shadows
  • ClockTime 18-20 (sunset/golden hour): Dramatic oranges, reds, purples, sun near horizon
  • ClockTime 20-22 or 4-6 (dusk/night): Deep blues, purples, stars, moon visible

Also consider your location type:

  • Tropical/Beach: Vibrant blues, minimal haze, clear horizons
  • Mountain/Forest: Layered ridges, atmospheric perspective, possible clouds at different elevations
  • Desert: Warm tones, distant mesas or rock formations, heat shimmer feel
  • Urban: Possible distant city skyline, slight pollution haze, less pure colors
  • Coastal/Ocean: Expansive water meeting sky, seabirds, marine clouds

Step 2: Access the Toolbox and Search for Skyboxes

Roblox's Toolbox (also called Creator Marketplace) contains thousands of free skyboxes created by developers and Roblox.

  1. Open the View tab in the top ribbon
  2. Click Toolbox to open the asset panel (usually docks on the left side)
  3. In the Toolbox, click the dropdown at the top (it might say "Models" or "Marketplace")
  4. Select Marketplace or Creator Marketplace
  5. In the search bar, try terms like:
    • "tropical sky"
    • "sunset skybox"
    • "mountain sky"
    • "desert skybox"
    • "ocean sky"
    • "clear blue sky"
  6. Use the filter options to show only Sky objects (not Models or Decals)

Search Strategy

Start broad ("sky"), then refine by mood ("sunset sky"), then by location type ("tropical sunset sky"). Preview multiple options before committingskyboxes look different once they're surrounding your entire world.

Step 3: Preview Skybox Options

You can't fully judge a skybox from its thumbnail. You need to see it in your actual game world.

Try It: Test Multiple Skyboxes

  1. Find a skybox that looks promising in the Toolbox
  2. Click on it to see the preview and details page
  3. Click the green checkmark or "Get" button to add it to your inventory (it's free)
  4. The skybox will automatically insert into your game under Lighting
  5. Press Play to test it in your world
  6. Run through at least two zones to see how it looks during actual gameplay
  7. If it's not quite right, stop the test, delete the Sky object from Lighting (select it in Explorer and press Delete), and try another

Important: Only one Sky object should exist in Lighting at a time. Delete the old one before adding a new one.

Step 4: Evaluate Your Skybox Choice

Once you've narrowed it down to 2-3 options, evaluate them against these criteria:

Skybox Quality Criteria

  • Time-of-day match: Does the sun position in the skybox align with your ClockTime setting?
  • Color harmony: Do the skybox colors complement your fog color and ambient lighting?
  • Thematic fit: Does the sky look like it could exist above your real-world location?
  • Clarity vs. drama balance: Is the sky interesting without being distracting during fast gameplay?
  • Seamlessness: Are there visible seams where the six skybox faces meet? (Rotate camera to check all angles)
  • Horizon consistency: Does the skybox create a believable distant environment, or does it look obviously fake?

Step 5: Fine-Tune the Sky Object (Optional)

Once you've chosen a skybox, you can adjust its properties to better fit your game:

  1. In the Explorer, expand Lighting
  2. Click on the Sky object to select it
  3. Open the Properties panel

Useful Sky Properties

  • CelestialBodiesShown: True/Falsewhether the sun and moon are visible. Turn off if your skybox already has a painted sun.
  • StarCount: Number of stars visible at night (0-5000). Only matters if your ClockTime is night.
  • SunAngularSize: How large the sun appears (default 11). Increase for dramatic sunrise/sunset, decrease for high-altitude feel.
  • MoonAngularSize: How large the moon appears (default 11). Adjust similarly for night scenes.

Try It: Disable Double Suns

Many skyboxes have a sun painted into the texture. If you also have CelestialBodiesShown enabled, you'll see two suns (the skybox sun and Roblox's dynamic sun). Fix this:

  1. Select the Sky object in Explorer
  2. Find CelestialBodiesShown in Properties
  3. Set it to False
  4. Test in Play modeyou should now see only the skybox's sun

Location-Specific Skybox Recommendations

Here are search strategies and evaluation tips for different island types:

Tropical Beach Islands

Search terms: "tropical sky," "caribbean sky," "clear blue sky," "island paradise sky"

What to look for: Vibrant saturated blues, white puffy clouds (cumulus), clear horizon line, possibly palm trees in distance on skybox

Avoid: Overcast skies, heavy cloud cover, stormy or dramatic skies (unless your beach is specifically storm-themed)

Forest and Mountain Regions

Search terms: "mountain skybox," "forest sky," "pine tree sky," "alpine sky," "valley sky"

What to look for: Layered mountain ridges fading into distance, atmospheric perspective (blue-gray layers), possible morning mist

Avoid: Flat horizons, desert colors, perfectly clear skies (forests/mountains usually have some atmospheric haze)

Desert and Canyon Landscapes

Search terms: "desert sunset," "canyon sky," "southwest sky," "red rock sky," "arid sky"

What to look for: Warm color palette, distant mesas or rock formations, golden hour or sunset tones, possible dust/heat haze

Avoid: Lush clouds, cool blue tones, green landscapes in distance

Urban and City Environments

Search terms: "city skyline," "urban sky," "downtown sky," "metropolitan sky"

What to look for: Possible distant buildings on horizon, slight atmospheric pollution (desaturated colors), dramatic sunrise/sunset from rooftop perspective

Avoid: Pure wilderness, overly vibrant colors (cities tend to have muted skies)

Advanced: Creating a Custom Skybox (Optional)

If you can't find a skybox that perfectly matches your location, you can create your own using six square images. This is advanced but powerful:

  1. Find or photograph six images representing the view in each direction from your location
  2. Ensure all six images are the same square resolution (512x512 or 1024x1024)
  3. Upload each image to Roblox as a Decal (Create tab Decals on Roblox website)
  4. Insert a Sky object into Lighting (right-click Lighting Insert Object Sky)
  5. In the Sky's properties, paste the Asset IDs for each of the six textures into:
    • SkyboxUp (looking up)
    • SkyboxDn (looking down)
    • SkyboxLf (looking left)
    • SkyboxRt (looking right)
    • SkyboxFt (looking forward)
    • SkyboxBk (looking backward)

Note: This requires some technical skill and image editing. Only pursue this if you have time and interestthe Toolbox has hundreds of quality skyboxes that work well.

Testing Across All Zones

Don't just test from spawn. Your skybox needs to look good from every zone:

  1. Play through all five zones and look at the sky from different camera angles
  2. Check while jumping: When you're in the air between platforms, the sky is very visible
  3. Verify color consistency: Does the sky still feel cohesive when you're in Zone 5 vs Zone 1?
  4. Ask for feedback: Have a classmate play and ask, "Does the sky fit the vibe?"

Common Skybox Mistakes

  • Skybox doesn't match ClockTime: You set ClockTime to 14 (midday) but chose a sunset skybox
  • Overcomplicating: Chose a dramatic, high-contrast skybox that distracts from gameplay
  • Ignoring fog color: Fog is blue but skybox is orangelooks disconnected at the horizon
  • Multiple Sky objects: Forgot to delete the old one before adding new, causing conflicts

Mission Check

Before moving to the next mission, verify you have:

  • Searched the Toolbox/Creator Marketplace for skybox options matching your theme
  • Tested at least 3 different skyboxes in your actual game world
  • Selected and applied a final skybox that complements your lighting settings
  • Verified time-of-day consistency between ClockTime and skybox sun position
  • Checked for double suns/moons and disabled CelestialBodiesShown if needed
  • Tested the skybox from all five zones to ensure it looks good throughout the course
  • Confirmed only ONE Sky object exists in the Lighting service

Quality check: Take a screenshot looking up at the sky. Does it capture the mood of your real-world location? If yes, you nailed it.

Next Mission: Detail Parts

Your lighting and sky are setthe big environmental pieces are in place. Now it's time to add the small touches that make your island feel specific and lived-in. In the next mission, you'll place decorative detail parts that reference your actual real-world location, transforming your island from "a generic runner" to "a runner set in this exact place."

planets.title: Detail Parts
planets.description: Add small decorative elements that reference your real location
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
It's the Little Things

Right now, your island runner has solid zones, good lighting, and a beautiful sky. But if someone from your actual location played it, would they recognize it? Would they say, "Oh wow, that's totally [your place]!"?

Probably not yet. Because while you've built the big piecesthe platforms, the landmarks, the overall environmentyou haven't added the small details that make a place feel real and specific.

Think about your actual location. What are the little things that make it unique? The specific type of trees or cacti? The style of signs? The street lamps? The kind of rocks? The architectural details on buildings? The cultural symbols?

Those details don't affect gameplay, but they affect feeling. And feeling is what transforms a game from "fun" to "memorable."

In this mission, you'll become a location detective, identifying and adding the small decorative elements that make your island unmistakably yours.

Mission Objective

Add small decorative elements that reference the real-world location to enhance specificity and immersion

By the end of this mission, your island will have:

  • At least 3-5 location-specific detail elements per zone
  • Props and decorations that reference real features of your location
  • Visual richness that doesn't interfere with gameplay
  • Environmental storytelling that makes the setting feel authentic

Understanding Detail Parts

Detail parts are decorative elements that serve narrative and aesthetic purposes, not gameplay purposes. They include:

  • Natural elements: Specific plants, rocks, flowers, mushrooms, coral, shells
  • Cultural objects: Signs, flags, statues, monuments, art, symbols
  • Architectural features: Lamp posts, benches, mailboxes, fences, gates
  • Environmental props: Driftwood, fallen logs, boulders, tide pools, trash cans
  • Atmospheric touches: Banners, string lights, wind chimes, weathervanes

Critical rule: Detail parts must NOT interfere with the running path. Players should never collide with, trip over, or be blocked by decorative elements. If a detail is in the way, either move it to the side or make it non-collidable (CanCollide = false).

Step 1: Identify Your Location's Signature Details

Before you start adding parts, you need to know what makes your location visually distinctive. Spend 5 minutes brainstorming:

Location Detail Inventory

Answer these questions about your real-world location:

  • What plants grow there? (palm trees, pine trees, cacti, ferns, mangroves, wildflowers, etc.)
  • What's the terrain like? (sandy, rocky, volcanic, mossy, snowy, dusty, etc.)
  • What animals or creatures are common? (seagulls, deer, lizards, squirrels, fish, etc.)
  • What architectural style dominates? (beach shacks, log cabins, adobe, modern glass, colonial, etc.)
  • Are there cultural symbols or colors? (flags, team colors, historical markers, tribal patterns, etc.)
  • What human-made objects are everywhere? (surf boards, ski equipment, fishing nets, cowboy hats, etc.)
  • What's a "weird but accurate" detail? (something oddly specific to your place that outsiders wouldn't know)

Write down 5-10 specific details. These are your targets for this mission.

Step 2: Search the Toolbox for Detail Models

Roblox's Toolbox has thousands of free models you can use as details. The key is knowing what to search for.

  1. Open the Toolbox (View tab Toolbox)
  2. Make sure you're searching Models (not Sky, Meshes, or other categories)
  3. Search for your specific details, one at a time:
    • Tropical islands: "palm tree," "coconut," "beach chair," "surfboard," "tiki torch," "hibiscus flower"
    • Mountain/Forest: "pine tree," "boulder," "log," "mushroom," "deer," "campfire," "trail sign"
    • Desert: "cactus," "sagebrush," "tumbleweed," "red rock," "cowboy hat," "wagon wheel"
    • Urban: "street lamp," "bench," "trash can," "newspaper stand," "graffiti," "fire hydrant"
    • Coastal: "lighthouse," "anchor," "buoy," "fishing net," "seagull," "dock piling"
  4. Look at the thumbnail previews and choose models that:
    • Are relatively simple (low part count for better performance)
    • Match your visual style (cartoony, realistic, stylized, etc.)
    • Are free (check the pricestick to free models for this project)

Model Quality Tips

  • Check the creator: Models from verified or popular creators tend to be higher quality
  • Preview before inserting: Click the model to see a larger preview and read the description
  • Watch out for viruses: Some models contain malicious scripts. If you insert a model and see unexpected behaviors, delete it immediately
  • Prefer mesh models over part-built models: They usually look better and have fewer parts

Step 3: Insert and Place Your First Detail

Let's start by adding one detail element to Zone 1.

Try It: Add a Location-Specific Prop

  1. Search for a detail that fits your location (e.g., "palm tree" for a tropical island)
  2. Click on a model you like in the Toolbox
  3. Click the green checkmark or "Get" button to insert it into your workspace
  4. The model will appear somewhere in your worlduse the Move tool (Ctrl+2 or Cmd+2) to reposition it
  5. Place it off to the side of your running pathNOT in the middle where players will hit it
  6. Good locations:
    • Next to platforms (left or right edge)
    • On the ground below platforms (if visible)
    • Near your landmark structures
    • Between zones as visual dividers
  7. Press Play and run past itdoes it feel like it belongs? Does it interfere with gameplay?

Step 4: Anchor Your Details

Decorative models should not move, fall, or tumble when the game runs. You need to anchor them.

  1. In the Explorer, find the model you just inserted (it's probably named something like "Palm Tree" or "Rock")
  2. Click the arrow to expand the model and see all its parts
  3. Select the main part (usually the largest or base part, often named "Base" or "Main")
  4. In Properties, find Anchored and set it to True
  5. If the model has multiple parts, you may need to anchor each oneor use the "Select Children" trick:
    • Right-click the model in Explorer
    • Choose "Select Children"
    • In Properties, set Anchored to True (this anchors all selected parts at once)

Why Anchoring Matters

If you don't anchor decorative models, they'll fall when the game starts (due to gravity) or get knocked around if the player touches them. This breaks immersion and can cause performance issues as the physics engine tries to simulate hundreds of falling objects.

Step 5: Add 3-5 Details Per Zone

Now that you've added one detail successfully, repeat the process for each of your five zones. Aim for 3-5 distinct details per zone.

Detail Placement Strategy

  • Zone 1 (Intro area): Add welcoming, iconic elements (flags, signs, entry markers, signature plants)
  • Zone 2-4 (Mid-game): Add varietymix natural and human-made elements, change scale (some big, some small)
  • Zone 5 (Landmark zone): Add celebratory or dramatic details (special decorations, climax elements, views)

Try It: Detail Each Zone

For each zone, follow this process:

  1. Choose 3-5 detail types from your brainstorm list
  2. Search and insert models for each detail type
  3. Position them around the zonesides of platforms, near landmarks, along paths
  4. Anchor all parts to prevent physics issues
  5. Test by playing through the zoneensure details enhance, not interfere
  6. Adjust scale if needed (use the Scale tool or change Size property) to make details feel proportional

Step 6: Create Visual Rhythm and Variety

Don't just scatter details randomly. Think about visual rhythmthe pattern of detail placement that keeps the environment interesting without overwhelming.

Visual Rhythm Principles

  • Vary scale: Mix large elements (big trees, boulders) with small ones (flowers, shells, signs)
  • Group in odd numbers: 1, 3, or 5 items clustered together look more natural than 2 or 4
  • Alternate sides: If Zone 1 has details on the left, put Zone 2's on the rightkeeps eyes moving
  • Create focal points: Place more details near landmarks to draw attention
  • Leave breathing room: Not every platform needs decorationemptiness creates contrast
  • Repeat signature elements: If palm trees are your thing, sprinkle them throughoutbut vary their placement

Location-Specific Detail Examples

Here are concrete examples for different island types:

Tropical Beach Island (Hawaii, Caribbean)

Details to add:

  • Palm trees and coconut clusters (Toolbox: "palm tree," "coconut")
  • Surfboards and beach chairs (Toolbox: "surfboard," "beach chair")
  • Tiki torches or luau decorations (Toolbox: "tiki torch," "tiki statue")
  • Hibiscus or plumeria flowers (Toolbox: "tropical flower," "hibiscus")
  • Shells and starfish on ground (Toolbox: "seashell," "starfish")
  • Wooden signs with island names (Toolbox: "wooden sign" then edit text with SurfaceGui)

Mountain/Forest Region (Rockies, Appalachia, Pacific Northwest)

Details to add:

  • Pine or fir trees in clusters (Toolbox: "pine tree," "evergreen")
  • Large boulders and rock formations (Toolbox: "boulder," "rock formation")
  • Fallen logs and stumps (Toolbox: "log," "tree stump")
  • Mushrooms and ferns (Toolbox: "mushroom," "fern")
  • Trail markers or park signs (Toolbox: "trail sign," "park sign")
  • Campfire or backpacks (Toolbox: "campfire," "backpack")

Desert/Canyon (Southwest US, Arizona, Utah)

Details to add:

  • Saguaro or prickly pear cacti (Toolbox: "cactus," "saguaro")
  • Red sandstone rocks and arches (Toolbox: "red rock," "sandstone")
  • Tumbleweed and desert brush (Toolbox: "tumbleweed," "sagebrush")
  • Old wagon wheels or cowboy props (Toolbox: "wagon wheel," "cowboy hat")
  • Lizards or desert critters (Toolbox: "lizard")
  • Sun-bleached wood posts or fences (Toolbox: "wooden fence," "fence post")

Urban/City Environment

Details to add:

  • Street lamps and utility poles (Toolbox: "street lamp," "lamp post")
  • Benches and trash cans (Toolbox: "park bench," "trash can")
  • Fire hydrants and mailboxes (Toolbox: "fire hydrant," "mailbox")
  • Graffiti walls or murals (Toolbox: "graffiti," or create using Decals)
  • Newspapers, coffee cups, urban clutter (Toolbox: "newspaper stand," "coffee cup")
  • Traffic cones or barriers (Toolbox: "traffic cone," "barrier")

Advanced: Creating Simple Custom Details

If you can't find the exact detail you need in the Toolbox, you can build simple ones yourself:

Try It: Build a Simple Rock Cluster

  1. Insert a Part (Home tab Part Ball or Wedge)
  2. Resize it to look rock-like (use Scale tool or manually adjust Size property)
  3. Change the Color to a natural rock color (grays, browns, reds)
  4. Optionally, change Material to "Slate," "Concrete," or "Rock" for texture
  5. Duplicate the part (Ctrl+D) and resize/reposition to create 2-3 rocks together
  6. Select all the rock parts (Ctrl+Click to multi-select)
  7. Right-click Group (Ctrl+G) to create a Model named "Rock Cluster"
  8. Anchor the entire model

Performance Considerations

Details add visual richness, but they also add rendering load. Keep your game performant:

Performance Best Practices

  • Aim for 15-25 detail models total across all five zones (3-5 per zone)
  • Prefer low-poly models: Models with fewer parts run better
  • Anchor everything: Anchored parts don't need physics calculations
  • Disable collisions on small details: If a detail is purely visual (like a flower), set CanCollide to False
  • Avoid excessive transparency: Transparent parts (Glass material, low Transparency values) are expensive to render
  • Test on a lower-end device if possible: Ask a classmate with an older computer to testdoes the game run smoothly?

Testing Your Details

After adding all your details, do a full playthrough test:

  1. Play from start to finish and notice the details as you run past
  2. Check for interference: Did you accidentally place anything in the running path?
  3. Verify anchoring: Do any details fall or move when the game starts?
  4. Evaluate specificity: Do the details make your location recognizable, or do they still feel generic?
  5. Ask for outside feedback: Show someone unfamiliar with your location and ask, "Where do you think this game is set?"

Common Detail Mistakes

  • Too many details: Over-cluttering makes the game feel busy and can hurt performance
  • Details blocking gameplay: A palm tree in the middle of the path ruins the flow
  • Not anchoring: Details falling everywhere when you press Play
  • Inconsistent style: Mixing realistic trees with cartoony rockspick a visual style and stick to it
  • Generic choices: Adding "tree" instead of the specific type of tree from your location

Mission Check

Before moving to the next mission, verify you have:

  • Brainstormed 5-10 location-specific details that represent your real-world place
  • Added 3-5 detail models to each of the five zones (15-25 total details)
  • Anchored all detail parts/models to prevent physics issues
  • Positioned details off the running path so they don't interfere with gameplay
  • Created visual rhythm by varying scale, alternating sides, and grouping strategically
  • Tested the full course to ensure details enhance rather than distract
  • Verified performance: Game still runs smoothly with all details added

Quality check: If you showed a screenshot to someone from your location, would they recognize it? If yes, you've succeeded.

Next Mission: Sound Atmosphere

Your island now looks the partlighting, sky, and decorative details all work together to create a sense of place. But there's one more sensory layer missing: sound. In the next mission, you'll add ambient audio that completes the immersion, making your island not just look like your location, but sound like it too.

planets.title: Sound Atmosphere
planets.description: Add ambient audio to enhance immersion
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Close Your Eyes and Listen

Imagine you're standing in your real-world location right now. Close your eyes. What do you hear?

If it's a beach: the rhythmic crash of waves, seagulls calling, maybe palm fronds rustling in the breeze.

If it's a forest: wind through the trees, birds chirping, the occasional crack of a branch, the distant sound of a stream.

If it's a city: traffic humming, horns honking, footsteps on pavement, the murmur of crowds.

If it's a desert: wind sweeping across sand, the distant cry of a hawk, maybe the faint rattle of tumbleweeds.

Sound is 50% of the experiencebut right now, your island runner is silent. It's time to fix that.

In this mission, you'll add ambient audio that makes your island not just look like your location, but sound like it. You'll learn to create a soundscape that's present but not overwhelming, authentic but not distracting.

Mission Objective

Implement ambient audio using Sound objects to enhance environmental immersion and location authenticity

By the end of this mission, your island will have:

  • At least 1-2 ambient background sounds that loop continuously
  • Optional zone-specific sounds that enhance particular areas
  • Properly configured volume levels that support gameplay without overwhelming
  • Audio that authentically represents your real-world location

Understanding Sound Objects

In Roblox, sound is controlled by Sound objects. A Sound object is like a speakerit has an audio file (SoundId), volume settings, and playback controls.

Sound objects can be placed in two ways:

  • Global sounds (in SoundService or Workspace): Heard everywhere at the same volumegood for background music or universal ambience
  • Positional sounds (in Parts or Models): Volume changes based on player distancegood for localized effects like a waterfall or campfire

For ambient atmosphere, we'll primarily use global sounds that players hear throughout the entire island.

Step 1: Identify Your Location's Soundscape

Before searching for audio, define what your location sounds like:

Soundscape Inventory

Answer these questions about your real-world location:

  • What's the dominant background sound? (ocean, wind, traffic, birdsong, etc.)
  • Are there rhythmic/repeated sounds? (waves crashing, crickets chirping, bell tower, train)
  • What animal sounds are present? (seagulls, crows, coyotes, frogs, etc.)
  • What weather sounds occur? (gentle breeze, strong wind, rain, thunder)
  • Are there human-made ambient sounds? (distant traffic, construction, music, chatter)
  • What's a sound that would be instantly recognizable? (a specific bird call, a unique feature)

Write down 2-3 sounds that would immediately make someone think of your location. These are your targets.

Step 2: Search the Toolbox for Audio

Roblox's Toolbox includes a library of free sound effects you can use.

  1. Open the Toolbox (View tab Toolbox)
  2. Click the dropdown at the top and select Audio
  3. Search for ambient sound terms:
    • Beach/Ocean: "ocean waves," "beach ambience," "seagulls," "water waves"
    • Forest: "forest ambience," "birds chirping," "wind trees," "nature sounds"
    • Desert: "desert wind," "desert ambience," "coyote," "sandstorm"
    • City: "city ambience," "traffic," "urban sounds," "street noise"
    • Mountain: "mountain wind," "eagle call," "stream water," "wilderness"
  4. Click on audio clips to preview them (a play button should appear)
  5. Look for clips that:
    • Are loopable (seamless when repeatedno obvious start/end)
    • Are subtle and atmospheric (not harsh or jarring)
    • Match your location's character

Audio Search Tips

  • Use "ambience" or "ambient": These keywords find loopable background sounds
  • Preview before inserting: Listen to the entire clipdoes it loop well? Is the volume consistent?
  • Check length: Longer clips (30+ seconds) tend to loop more naturally than short ones
  • Stick to free audio: Don't use sounds that cost Robux unless you have permission/budget

Step 3: Insert Your First Ambient Sound

Let's add a primary ambient sound that will play throughout the entire game.

Try It: Add a Background Ambient Sound

  1. In the Toolbox, search for your primary ambient sound (e.g., "ocean waves ambience")
  2. Find a sound that feels right and click it to preview
  3. If it sounds good, click the green checkmark or "Get" button
  4. The sound will be inserted into your gamecheck the Explorer to see where it went (often into Workspace)
  5. If it's in Workspace, that's fine for nowwe'll configure it next

Step 4: Configure the Sound Object

Now you need to set up the Sound object so it plays continuously and at the right volume.

  1. In the Explorer, find the Sound object you just inserted (it might be named after the audio file)
  2. Click on it to select it, then open the Properties panel
  3. Configure these key properties:

Essential Sound Properties

  • Looped: Set to True (this makes the sound repeat continuously)
  • Volume: Set to 0.3-0.5 to start (ambient sounds should be present but subtle)
  • Playing: Set to True (this starts the sound immediately when the game loads)
  • RollOffMode: Set to InverseTapered if you want it to fade with distance, or Linear for more dramatic falloff. For global ambience, you can also set RollOffMaxDistance to a very high number like 10000 so it's heard everywhere.
  • SoundId: This should already be filled in with the audio asset IDdon't change it unless you're replacing the sound

Try It: Make the Sound Loop and Play

  1. Select your Sound object in Explorer
  2. In Properties, find Looped and check the box (set to True)
  3. Find Volume and set it to 0.4
  4. Find Playing and check the box (set to True)
  5. Press Play to test your game
  6. You should immediately hear the ambient sound looping in the background
  7. If it's too loud or too quiet, stop the game, adjust Volume, and test again

Step 5: Move Sound to SoundService for Global Playback

If you want the sound to be heard equally everywhere (not affected by player position), move it to the SoundService.

  1. In the Explorer, find your Sound object (probably in Workspace)
  2. Click and drag it to SoundService (it's in the list of services at the top level of Explorer)
  3. Drop it inside SoundService
  4. Now the sound will play at consistent volume no matter where the player is on the island

Alternative: If you want the sound to fade based on distance (like waves louder near the beach area), keep it in a Part or Model in Workspace and adjust RollOffMaxDistance and RollOffMinDistance.

Step 6: Add a Secondary Ambient Sound (Optional)

Layering multiple sounds creates a richer, more realistic soundscape. Consider adding a second subtle sound:

Sound Layering Ideas

  • Beach: Primary = ocean waves, Secondary = distant seagulls or breeze
  • Forest: Primary = wind through trees, Secondary = bird chirps or stream
  • Desert: Primary = wind/breeze, Secondary = occasional coyote or hawk cry
  • City: Primary = distant traffic hum, Secondary = occasional horn or siren
  • Mountain: Primary = mountain wind, Secondary = eagle call or distant thunder

Try It: Add a Layered Sound

  1. Search the Toolbox for a secondary ambient sound (e.g., "seagull calls")
  2. Insert it into your game
  3. Configure it with the same settings: Looped = True, Playing = True
  4. Set Volume slightly lower than your primary sound (0.2-0.3)
  5. Move it to SoundService (or position it in the world if you want localized audio)
  6. Test in Play modethe two sounds should blend naturally

Step 7: Add Zone-Specific Sounds (Advanced Optional)

For extra polish, you can add positional sounds that only play when the player is near certain areas. For example:

  • A waterfall sound near your waterfall landmark (Zone 3)
  • A campfire crackling near a campsite detail
  • Wind chimes near a cultural structure
  • Drumming or music near a festival area

To create a positional sound:

  1. Insert or create a Part at the location where you want the sound to originate (e.g., inside the waterfall model)
  2. Make the part Invisible (Transparency = 1) and CanCollide = False
  3. Insert a Sound object as a child of that part (right-click Part Insert Object Sound)
  4. Set the Sound's SoundId to your audio asset
  5. Configure: Looped = True, Playing = True, Volume = 0.5
  6. Set RollOffMaxDistance to 100-200 (players hear it clearly within 100 studs, then it fades)
  7. Set RollOffMinDistance to 10-20 (sound is at full volume within 10-20 studs)
  8. Test by running past the areayou should hear the sound grow louder as you approach

When to Use Positional vs. Global Sounds

  • Global (SoundService): Background ambience that should be heard everywhere (ocean, wind, traffic)
  • Positional (in Parts): Specific sound sources tied to locations (waterfall, campfire, animals, machines)

Volume Balance and Mixing

Audio mixing is about balancing volumes so everything can be heard without overwhelming the player.

Volume Guidelines

  • Primary ambient sound: 0.3-0.5 (present but not dominant)
  • Secondary ambient sound: 0.2-0.3 (adds texture, doesn't compete)
  • Positional sounds: 0.4-0.6 (should be noticeable when near, but fade quickly)
  • Jump/landing sounds (if you add them): 0.5-0.7 (clear feedback, but not jarring)

The total "loudness" of your soundscape should feel like you're in the environment, not like you're being shouted at. When in doubt, start quieter and increase gradually.

Testing Your Soundscape

After adding all your sounds, do a full listening test:

  1. Play through the entire course and focus on the audio
  2. Check for loop quality: Do you hear obvious "seams" where sounds restart? If so, search for a better looping version
  3. Verify volume balance: Can you hear all sounds, or does one dominate?
  4. Test with headphones and speakers: Audio can sound very different on different devices
  5. Ask for feedback: Have a classmate play and ask, "Does the audio feel right? Too loud? Too quiet?"

Common Audio Mistakes

  • Too loud: Ambient sounds should support, not overpower. If you can't think while playing, it's too loud.
  • Harsh loops: A bad loop (with a click or sudden restart) breaks immersion every few seconds.
  • Too many layers: More than 3-4 simultaneous sounds becomes muddy and confusing.
  • Wrong mood: Spooky sounds for a tropical beach, or cheerful birds for a desertaudio must match theme.
  • Forgetting to set Looped = True: Sound plays once and stops, leaving silence.

Location-Specific Soundscape Examples

Here are complete soundscape setups for different island types:

Tropical Beach Island

Primary sound: Ocean waves ambience (Volume: 0.4, in SoundService)

Secondary sound: Seagull calls or light breeze (Volume: 0.25, in SoundService)

Optional positional: Palm fronds rustling near palm tree clusters (Volume: 0.3, RollOffMaxDistance: 80)

Mountain/Forest Region

Primary sound: Wind through trees (Volume: 0.35, in SoundService)

Secondary sound: Forest birds chirping (Volume: 0.3, in SoundService)

Optional positional: Stream/creek water near a water feature (Volume: 0.5, RollOffMaxDistance: 100)

Desert/Canyon Landscape

Primary sound: Desert wind ambience (Volume: 0.3, in SoundService)

Secondary sound: Occasional distant hawk or coyote (Volume: 0.2, in SoundService)

Optional positional: Wind howling through rock formations (Volume: 0.4, RollOffMaxDistance: 120)

Urban/City Environment

Primary sound: City traffic ambience (Volume: 0.35, in SoundService)

Secondary sound: Distant horns and sirens (Volume: 0.2, in SoundService)

Optional positional: Crowd chatter near a plaza area (Volume: 0.4, RollOffMaxDistance: 90)

Advanced: Using SoundGroups (Optional)

If you want to control multiple sounds at once (like a master volume control), you can use SoundGroups:

  1. In SoundService, right-click and Insert Object SoundGroup
  2. Name it "Ambience" or "BackgroundSounds"
  3. Select each of your ambient Sound objects
  4. In their Properties, find SoundGroup and set it to the SoundGroup you just created
  5. Now you can adjust the SoundGroup's Volume property to affect all grouped sounds at once

This is useful if you later want to add music or make the ambience quieter during specific events.

Mission Check

Before moving to the next mission, verify you have:

  • Identified 2-3 sounds that authentically represent your location's soundscape
  • Inserted at least one primary ambient sound from the Toolbox
  • Configured the sound to loop and play automatically (Looped = True, Playing = True)
  • Set appropriate volume levels (0.3-0.5 for primary, quieter for secondary)
  • Moved global sounds to SoundService for consistent playback throughout the island
  • Optionally added a secondary layered sound for richer atmosphere
  • Tested the soundscape by playing through all five zones and listening carefully
  • Verified loop quality: No obvious clicks, pops, or harsh restarts

Quality check: Close your eyes and listen while someone else plays your game. Does it sound like your real-world location? If yes, you've created an effective soundscape.

Next Mission: Difficulty Tuning

Your island looks polished and sounds immersivebut is it fun to play? In the final mission of Star 6, you'll step back from aesthetics and focus on game feel. You'll adjust obstacle spacing, timing, and difficulty curves based on playtest feedback, ensuring that your beautifully polished island is also a joy to run through.

planets.title: Difficulty Tuning
planets.description: Adjust obstacle spacing and timing based on playtest feedback
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
You Can't Playtest Your Own Game

You've spent hours building your island runner. You know every jump, every platform, every obstacle. You've run the course dozens of times. You can probably beat it with your eyes closed.

That's the problem.

You are the worst person to judge whether your game is fun, fair, or well-balanced. You've internalized every pattern. You know which jumps are tight and which are generous. You know where the moving obstacles will be at any given moment.

Your players don't know any of that. They're experiencing it for the first time. And if you've tuned the difficulty based on your skill level, you've probably made it way too hard.

In this mission, you'll do something uncomfortable but essential: you'll watch other people play your game. You'll see them fail where you expected them to succeed. You'll see them confused where you thought things were obvious. And then you'll fix it.

This is the difference between a game that you enjoy and a game that everyone enjoys.

Mission Objective

Adjust obstacle spacing, timing, and difficulty progression based on structured playtest feedback to optimize game feel

By the end of this mission, your island will have:

  • Playtesting data from at least 2-3 players who aren't you
  • Identified specific pain points (areas where players struggle unfairly)
  • Adjusted obstacle spacing, platform gaps, and timing based on feedback
  • A smoother difficulty curve that ramps up gradually from Zone 1 to Zone 5
  • Improved "game feel" that makes the experience enjoyable, not frustrating

Understanding Difficulty Tuning

Difficulty tuning is the process of making micro-adjustments to your game's challenge level so that it feels:

  • Fair: When players fail, they feel it's their fault, not the game's
  • Progressive: Difficulty increases gradually, not in sudden spikes
  • Readable: Players can see what's coming and understand what to do
  • Achievable: Most players can reach the end with practice, not just experts

Tuning is an iterative process: playtest gather feedback make adjustments playtest again.

Step 1: Set Up a Playtest Protocol

Before you hand your game to someone, you need a plan for how to observe and collect feedback.

Playtest Protocol

  1. Find 2-3 playtesters: Classmates, friends, or family who haven't played your game yet
  2. Give minimal instructions: Just say "Try to run through the course and reach the end." Don't explain the jumps or give tips.
  3. Observe silently: Watch them play. Don't help. Don't give hints. Just take notes.
  4. Note where they struggle: Which jumps do they miss repeatedly? Where do they get stuck? Where do they die and give up?
  5. Ask specific questions afterward: "Which part felt unfair?" "Where were you confused?" "What would you change?"
  6. Record their feedback: Write down specific zones, obstacles, or moments they mention

The Golden Rule of Playtesting

Do not defend your design. If a player says "I didn't know what to do here," don't say "But it's obvious!" Instead, write down "Zone 2 - player confused about next platform." Your job is to listen, not justify.

Step 2: Conduct Playtest 1

Let's run your first playtest session.

Try It: Playtest with Player 1

  1. Open your game in Roblox Studio
  2. Press Play to enter test mode
  3. Have your playtester sit down and take over the controls (or publish the game temporarily and have them play remotely)
  4. Watch them play from spawn to as far as they can get
  5. Use this observation checklist while watching:
    • Do they die in Zone 1? (If so, Zone 1 is too hardit should be easy)
    • Do they hesitate before jumps? (Indicates unclear visual information)
    • Do they miss the same jump multiple times? (That jump might be too tight)
    • Do they run past obstacles without noticing? (Obstacles might be too subtle)
    • Where do they give up? (That's your "difficulty spike")
  6. After they finish (or quit), ask:
    • "Which zone was the hardest?"
    • "Was there a moment that felt unfair?"
    • "What would make the game more fun?"
  7. Write down their answers

Step 3: Analyze Common Difficulty Problems

Here are the most common issues playtesting reveals, and how to fix them:

Problem: Players Can't Make the First Jump (Zone 1)

Diagnosis: Zone 1 is supposed to be easy, but the gap is too wide or the platform is too small.

Solution:

  • Reduce the gap between the first platform and spawn (make it 8-10 studs, not 12-15)
  • Make the first platform wider (16x16 or larger)
  • Ensure the first platform is straight aheadno turning required

How to adjust: Select the platform, use Move tool, bring it closer to spawn. Test immediately.

Problem: Players Keep Dying in Zone 3 (Mid-Game Spike)

Diagnosis: Zone 3 is much harder than Zone 2, creating a frustrating difficulty spike.

Solution:

  • Reduce the number of obstacles in Zone 3, or spread them out more
  • Slow down any moving obstacles (reduce their speed or increase cycle time)
  • Make platforms slightly larger so jumps are more forgiving
  • Add a checkpoint before Zone 3 so players don't have to restart from the beginning

How to adjust: Move platforms closer, delete one obstacle, or decrease TweenInfo speed values.

Problem: Players Don't See Obstacles Coming

Diagnosis: Visual clarity issueobstacles blend into the background or appear too suddenly.

Solution:

  • Change obstacle color to contrast with platform and background (e.g., bright red or yellow)
  • Increase obstacle size slightly so they're more visible
  • Ensure camera angle gives players a clear view ahead
  • Add visual warnings (like a colored platform before the obstacle)

How to adjust: Select obstacle parts, change BrickColor or Material to stand out more.

Problem: Zone 5 Feels Too Easy

Diagnosis: The final zone should be the climax, but it's less challenging than earlier zones.

Solution:

  • Add one or two additional obstacles in Zone 5
  • Make gaps slightly wider (but still fair)
  • Increase moving obstacle speed slightly
  • Combine obstacle types (e.g., moving platform + spinning obstacle)

How to adjust: Duplicate existing obstacles, reposition them, or tighten platform spacing.

Problem: Players Give Up Before Finishing

Diagnosis: The game is too punishingplayers lose progress and motivation.

Solution:

  • Add checkpoints at the start of Zones 2, 3, and 4 (so players respawn at progress points)
  • Make the course shorter by removing one or two filler platforms per zone
  • Ensure Zone 1 is very easy to build player confidence

How to adjust: Insert checkpoint Parts with SpawnLocation enabled at the start of each zone.

Step 4: Make Adjustments Based on Feedback

Now that you've identified problems, fix them one at a time.

Try It: Adjust One Problem Area

  1. Review your playtest notes and pick the most common complaint (e.g., "Zone 3 is too hard")
  2. Navigate to that zone in your game
  3. Make ONE specific change:
    • If gap is too wide: Move platform closer (reduce gap by 2-4 studs)
    • If obstacle is too fast: Edit the TweenInfo time to be longer (e.g., change 2 to 3 seconds)
    • If platform is too small: Increase Size property (e.g., from 10x10 to 14x14)
    • If obstacle is hard to see: Change BrickColor to something bright (e.g., Bright red)
  4. Press Play and test the change yourself
  5. Does it feel better? If yes, move to the next issue. If no, try a different adjustment.

Step 5: Verify the Difficulty Curve

A good difficulty curve means Zone 1 is easy, Zone 5 is hard, and everything in between ramps up gradually.

Difficulty Curve Checklist

  • Zone 1 (Tutorial): 90%+ of players should succeed on first or second try. Gaps: 8-12 studs. No moving obstacles.
  • Zone 2 (Easy): 70-80% success rate. Gaps: 10-14 studs. One simple moving obstacle max.
  • Zone 3 (Medium): 50-60% success rate. Gaps: 12-16 studs. 1-2 moving obstacles or one complex pattern.
  • Zone 4 (Hard): 30-40% success rate. Gaps: 14-18 studs. Multiple moving obstacles, tighter timing.
  • Zone 5 (Expert/Climax): 20-30% success rate on first try. Gaps: 16-20 studs. Combines all learned mechanics, but still fair.

If any zone feels out of order (e.g., Zone 2 is harder than Zone 4), adjust it to fit the curve.

Step 6: Conduct Playtest 2 (Verification)

After making adjustments, test again with a new player (or the same player if enough time has passed).

Try It: Playtest with Player 2

  1. Find a second playtester who hasn't played yet (or wait a day and use the same person)
  2. Run the same playtest protocol: observe silently, take notes, ask questions afterward
  3. Compare results to Playtest 1:
    • Did they get further than Player 1?
    • Did they struggle with the same areas?
    • Did your adjustments fix the issues, or create new ones?
  4. Make additional small adjustments if needed

Advanced: Tuning Specific Game Feel Elements

Beyond basic difficulty, there are subtle "game feel" adjustments that make a huge difference:

Game Feel Tuning Techniques

  • Jump timing windows: If players barely miss jumps, platforms might be too small. Increase width by 10-20% to create a "grace period."
  • Visual anticipation: Players need to see what's coming. Ensure the camera angle and platform layout give at least 1-2 seconds of visual warning before each obstacle.
  • Rhythm and pacing: Alternate between easy and hard sections to give players "breathing room." Two hard jumps in a row is frustrating; a hard jump followed by an easy one feels fair.
  • Obstacle speed consistency: Moving obstacles should move at predictable speeds. If one obstacle is much faster than another, players won't internalize the timing.
  • Death recovery time: How long does it take to get back to where you died? If it's more than 20-30 seconds, add checkpoints.

Common Tuning Adjustments (Quick Reference)

Here's a cheat sheet for the most common adjustments you'll make:

Problem Adjustment How to Do It
Gap too wide Reduce gap by 2-4 studs Select platform, Move tool, drag closer
Obstacle too fast Increase TweenInfo time Edit script, change time parameter (2 3 seconds)
Platform too small Increase Size by 2-4 studs Select part, Properties Size, increase X and Z
Obstacle invisible Change color to bright/contrasting Select part, Properties BrickColor Bright red
Zone too punishing Add checkpoint Insert Part SpawnLocation, position at zone start
Zone too easy Add one obstacle or widen gap Duplicate existing obstacle or increase gap by 2 studs

Step 7: Final Playtest (Acceptance Test)

After all adjustments, do one final playtest to confirm the game feels good.

Acceptance Criteria

Your game is ready for launch if:

  • At least 2 out of 3 playtesters can reach Zone 3 or beyond
  • Players describe the difficulty as "challenging but fair," not "impossible" or "frustrating"
  • No single obstacle causes more than 5 consecutive deaths
  • The difficulty ramps up smoothlyno sudden spikes
  • Players say they want to try again after failing, rather than quitting in frustration

Try It: Final Acceptance Playtest

  1. Find one more playtester (or test yourself if you've made significant changes)
  2. Watch them play the full course start to finish
  3. Ask the final question: "Would you play this again, or recommend it to a friend?"
  4. If the answer is yes, you're done. If no, identify the remaining issue and make one more adjustment.

Documenting Your Changes

It's helpful to keep a log of what you changed based on playtesting. This helps you learn what works and builds better games in the future.

Example Playtest Log

Playtest 1 (Player: Sarah):

  • Died 3 times in Zone 1 on second jump Reduced gap from 14 to 10 studs
  • Couldn't see spinning obstacle in Zone 3 Changed color from gray to bright red
  • Gave up at Zone 4 start Added checkpoint at Zone 4 entrance

Playtest 2 (Player: Marcus):

  • Reached Zone 5 but found it easier than Zone 4 Added one more moving platform in Zone 5
  • Said Zone 2 was "too easy and boring" Widened one gap from 10 to 13 studs

Playtest 3 (Player: Emma):

  • Completed the course, said it felt "hard but fair" No further changes needed

The Iterative Mindset

Game development is never "finished"it's only shipped. Even professional games get updates and balance patches after launch. The key is knowing when to stop iterating and call it done.

For this project, you're done when:

  • The game is completable by most players with practice
  • The difficulty curve feels smooth
  • No single moment feels unfair or broken
  • You've addressed all major playtest feedback

When to Stop Tuning

You could tune forever. At some point, you need to ship. Stop tuning when:

  • Two consecutive playtests yield similar positive results
  • You're making changes of less than 1 stud (micro-optimization)
  • You've spent more time tuning than building (diminishing returns)
  • You're changing things back to how they were before (you're second-guessing yourself)

Perfect is the enemy of good. Ship it.

Mission Check

Before completing Star 6, verify you have:

  • Conducted at least 2 playtests with different players (or the same player with time between tests)
  • Observed players silently and taken notes on where they struggled
  • Made at least 3-5 adjustments based on playtest feedback (gap sizes, obstacle speeds, colors, etc.)
  • Verified the difficulty curve ramps up smoothly from Zone 1 (easy) to Zone 5 (hard)
  • Added checkpoints if players were getting frustrated by losing progress
  • Tested final version yourself to confirm changes improved the experience
  • Received positive feedback on at least one final acceptance playtest ("challenging but fair")

Quality check: Ask yourself, "If I had never played this game before, would I enjoy it?" If the answer is yes, you've successfully tuned your game.

Congratulations: Star 6 Complete!

You've finished the Polish Round. Your island runner is now:

  • Beautifully lit with a custom skybox and atmospheric effects
  • Richly detailed with location-specific props and decorations
  • Immersively soundscaped with ambient audio
  • Carefully tuned for a fair and engaging difficulty curve

Your game doesn't just workit feels professional. It has polish. It has character. It represents your real-world location in a way that's specific, authentic, and fun to experience.

Next Star: Launch Day

In Star 7, you'll prepare your game for the world. You'll publish it to Roblox, write a compelling description, create a thumbnail, and share it with players beyond your classroom. Your island runner is about to go live.

stars.title: Launch Day
stars.description: Publish, share, and celebrate your creation

planets.title: Final Bug Hunt
planets.description: Systematic playtest to find and fix remaining issues
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
The Final Countdown

Your island runner is almost ready for the world. You've built the terrain, crafted the obstacles, tuned the mechanics, and polished every detail. But before you hit that publish button, there's one critical step that separates good games from great ones: the final bug hunt.

Professional game studios have entire quality assurance teams dedicated to this phase. Today, you'll learn their systematic approach to finding and fixing issues before launch. This isn't just clicking around randomlyit's a methodical process that ensures your players have the best possible experience from the moment they spawn into your world.

Real-World Insight: Game studios often delay launch dates to ensure quality. The saying "a delayed game is eventually good, but a rushed game is forever bad" has become industry wisdom. Your final bug hunt is your quality guarantee.

Mission Objective

Conduct a systematic playtest of your island runner, identify any remaining bugs or issues, and fix them to ensure a smooth launch experience. You'll test normal gameplay, edge cases, and create a pre-launch checklist to verify everything works perfectly.

The Systematic Testing Method

Phase 1: Fresh Start Test

Begin by testing the complete new player experience. Close and restart Roblox Studio to simulate a fresh visit to your game.

Spawn Experience

  • Spawn safely? Do players spawn on solid ground, not inside objects or falling through the world?
  • Clear direction? Is it immediately obvious where to go and what to do?
  • Instructions visible? Can new players see your starting instructions or signs?
  • Camera position? Does the camera start at a good angle to see the course?
  • No immediate death? Can players take a moment to orient themselves without dying?

First Playthrough

  • Complete the course from start to finish without developer knowledge
  • Note any confusion about where to go or what to do
  • Check difficulty - Is the learning curve reasonable?
  • Test all mechanics - Do jumps, obstacles, and collectibles work?
  • Verify win condition - Does finishing properly trigger victory?

Phase 2: Edge Case Testing

Now it's time to be creativetry to break your game. Edge cases are unusual situations that players might stumble into, and they often reveal bugs.

Things to Try

  • Jump off the map - What happens if players deliberately jump into the void?
  • Go backwards - Can players break the sequence by going the wrong way?
  • Stand still - What if a player just waits at spawn for 30 seconds?
  • Rapid clicking - Do your buttons or triggers break with spam clicking?
  • Die repeatedly - Does respawning work correctly every time?
  • Wall climbing - Can players get stuck on or inside walls?
  • Collectible sequence - What if players get collectibles in the wrong order?
  • Multiple attempts - Does restarting or replaying cause any issues?
Testing Mindset: Imagine you're a curious player who wants to explore every corner. Or imagine you're a player who doesn't follow instructions. What could go wrong?

Phase 3: Polish Check

This is your final visual and audio sweep. Look at your game with fresh eyes and check that all the polish you added in Star 6 is working correctly.

Visual Elements

  • Lighting - Does it look good at all points in the course?
  • Textures - Are all materials applied correctly with no missing textures?
  • Effects - Do particle effects play at the right times?
  • Signs and UI - Is all text readable and properly positioned?
  • Theme consistency - Does everything fit your island's visual style?

Audio Elements

  • Sound effects - Do they trigger correctly for actions and events?
  • Volume levels - Is everything balanced (not too loud or quiet)?
  • Music loops - Does background music play and loop smoothly?
  • Spatial audio - Do sounds come from the right locations?

Phase 4: Bug Documentation and Fixing

As you test, keep track of every issue you find. Not all bugs are equalsome need immediate fixes, while others are minor polish items.

Critical (Must Fix Before Launch)

  • Game crashes or breaks completely
  • Players get stuck and can't continue
  • Win condition doesn't work
  • Spawn or respawn fails
  • Major collision issues (falling through world)

High Priority (Fix If Possible)

  • Frustrating difficulty spikes
  • Confusing navigation or unclear objectives
  • Broken mechanics or features
  • Visual glitches that distract from gameplay
  • Missing feedback for player actions

Low Priority (Nice to Fix)

  • Minor visual inconsistencies
  • Small polish improvements
  • Extra features you'd like to add
  • Optimization opportunities

Phase 5: Peer Testing

If possible, have a classmate play your game without any guidance. Watch them play but don't help or explain anything. This reveals what's intuitive and what's confusing.

What to Observe

  • First reactions - Do they understand what to do immediately?
  • Stuck points - Where do they pause or seem confused?
  • Unexpected behavior - Do they try things you didn't anticipate?
  • Enjoyment - Do they seem engaged and having fun?
  • Completion - Can they finish without your help?

Questions to Ask After

  • What was your first impression?
  • Was anything confusing or unclear?
  • Did you encounter any bugs or issues?
  • What did you enjoy most?
  • Any suggestions for improvement?

The Pre-Launch Checklist

Before you move on to publishing, verify every item on this final checklist:

Gameplay Verification

  • Game can be completed from start to finish
  • Spawn location is safe and clear
  • Respawn system works correctly after death
  • All obstacles function as intended
  • Collectibles (if any) work properly
  • Win condition triggers correctly
  • No players can get permanently stuck

Technical Verification

  • No critical errors in Output window
  • All scripts are functioning without errors
  • Parts have correct collision settings
  • All sounds and effects load properly
  • Lighting looks good throughout the map

Polish Verification

  • Instructions or signs are clear and readable
  • Visual theme is consistent
  • Audio volumes are balanced
  • No floating or misplaced objects
  • Textures and materials applied correctly

Player Experience Verification

  • Difficulty curve feels appropriate
  • Objectives are clear to new players
