  • Controls feel responsive and smooth
  • Game length feels right (not too short or long)
  • Island story/theme comes through

How Professionals Hunt Bugs

Professional QA testers use structured test plans and bug tracking systems. They test the same scenarios repeatedly to ensure fixes don't break other features (regression testing). Some studios even have "game breaking" teams whose job is to intentionally try to break the game in creative ways. The process you're learning here mirrors real industry practices.

Mission Check

Before moving to the next mission, verify you've completed:

  • Tested your game from a fresh start (complete playthrough)
  • Attempted to break your game with edge case testing
  • Verified all polish elements (lighting, sound, visuals)
  • Fixed all critical bugs that would prevent players from enjoying your game
  • Had at least one other person playtest (if possible)
  • Completed the pre-launch checklist
  • Your game is stable, playable, and ready for the public

Quality Threshold: Your game doesn't need to be perfect, but it should be solid. Critical bugs should be fixed. Players should be able to complete the course. The experience should be smooth and enjoyable. If you can confidently say "I'd be proud to share this," you're ready for launch.

Coming Up Next

Your game has passed the final bug hunt and is ready for the world. In the next mission, you'll prepare for publication by configuring your game settings, creating an eye-catching thumbnail, and writing a description that will make players want to visit your island. The launch sequence has begun!

planets.title: Publishing Setup
planets.description: Configure game settings, thumbnail, and description
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
Your Game's First Impression

You've built an incredible island runner. You've tested it, polished it, and made sure it's ready for players. But here's the truth: the best game in the world won't get played if nobody knows what it is or why they should try it.

Think about how you choose which games to play on Roblox. You scroll through thumbnails, read descriptions, and look at ratings. You make snap judgments in seconds. Your game needs to stand out in that critical moment when a potential player is deciding whether to click or scroll past.

This mission is about packaging your creationtaking the game you've built and presenting it in a way that communicates its value, its theme, and its fun factor at a glance. You're not just a game developer now; you're a marketer, designer, and storyteller all at once.

Industry Reality: Game studios have entire marketing departments dedicated to trailers, screenshots, and store pages. Indies often say marketing is 50% of success. The skills you'll practice herevisual design, compelling writing, audience awarenessare just as valuable as coding.

Mission Objective

Configure your game's publishing settings, design an engaging thumbnail that captures your island's theme, write a compelling description that makes players want to visit, and set up proper tags and metadata to help players discover your creation.

Part 1: Game Settings Configuration

Accessing Game Settings

In Roblox Studio, you'll configure your game's core settings before publishing. These settings control who can play, how your game appears in search, and what features are enabled.

Opening Game Settings

  1. Open your island runner in Roblox Studio
  2. Click File Game Settings (or press Alt+S)
  3. You'll see several tabs of options to configure

Basic Info Tab

This is where you set your game's name and description.

  • Name: Give your game a memorable, clear title
    • Good: "Volcano Island Runner", "Crystal Cave Escape", "Jungle Trek Challenge"
    • Avoid: Generic names like "My Game" or names that don't hint at gameplay
    • Keep it under 50 characters so it displays well everywhere
  • Description: We'll craft this in detail in the next section
  • Genre: Select "Adventure" or "Platformer" depending on your focus
  • Max Players: For a runner, 1-10 players is typical

Options Tab

Configure gameplay experience options.

  • Enable Studio Access to API Services: Check this if you use data stores or other services
  • Allow Private Servers: Let friends create their own instances
  • Enable Team Create: If you worked with others, keep this on

Permissions Tab

Control who can access your game.

  • Playability: Set to "Public" when ready to launch
  • Who Can Play: "Everyone" for public access
  • For classroom launches, you might temporarily set to "Friends" first

Avatar Tab

Determine what avatar options players can use.

  • Avatar Type: R15 is the standard (more animation options)
  • Collision: "Outer Box" for consistent collision detection
  • Allow Custom Avatars: Usually "Yes" to let players use their avatars

Tags and Metadata

These help players discover your game when browsing or searching Roblox. Think about what words describe your game best.

Choosing Effective Tags

Select tags that accurately represent your game. Examples for an island runner:

  • Gameplay: Obby, Runner, Parkour, Adventure, Challenge
  • Theme: Island, Tropical, Nature, Jungle, Beach, Volcano
  • Style: Colorful, Casual, Fun, Exploration
  • Experience: Singleplayer, Short, Beginner-Friendly
Strategy: Use tags that players actually search for. "Obby" is heavily searched on Roblox. "Runner" and "Parkour" are common. Mix popular generic tags with specific theme tags to appear in both broad and niche searches.

Part 2: Crafting Your Game Description

The Purpose of a Description

Your description answers three questions for potential players: What is this game? Why should I play it? What will I do? You have limited space to hook their interest, so every word counts.

The Three-Part Description Structure

Part 1: The Hook (1-2 sentences)

Start with an exciting statement that immediately tells players what your game is and why it's interesting. Use vivid language that connects to your island's theme.

Examples:
  • "Race across a volcano island as lava rises behind you! Can you reach the rescue helicopter before the island explodes?"
  • "Explore a mysterious crystal cave filled with jumping challenges and hidden secrets. Your island adventure awaits!"
  • "Navigate the dangers of a tropical jungle island in this challenging runner. Leap over ravines, dodge falling coconuts, and find your way home!"

Part 2: The Details (2-4 sentences)

Explain the core gameplay and what makes your game unique. Mention specific features, obstacles, or mechanics that set your runner apart.

Example:

"Jump across floating platforms, swing on vines, and collect ancient coins as you traverse the island. Each section brings new challengesfrom beach parkour to mountain climbing. Master the timing, avoid the traps, and prove you have what it takes to conquer the island!"

Part 3: The Call to Action (1 sentence)

End with an invitation that encourages players to try your game. Make it enthusiastic and welcoming.

Examples:
  • "Can you escape the island? Jump in and find out!"
  • "The adventure starts nowwill you make it to the end?"
  • "Your island challenge awaits. Ready to run?"

Description Writing Tips

  • Use action verbs: Jump, race, explore, navigate, conquer, escape
  • Be specific: Don't just say "obstacles"name them (ravines, traps, lava)
  • Create urgency: Use words like "before," "can you," "race against"
  • Show personality: Let your island's theme and story come through
  • Keep it concise: Aim for 100-150 words total
  • Avoid clichs: Skip phrases like "fun for everyone" or "amazing game"
  • No ALL CAPS: Use proper capitalization for readability
  • Proofread: Check spelling and grammarerrors look unprofessional

Part 3: Creating Your Thumbnail

Why Thumbnails Matter

Your thumbnail is the first thing players see when browsing games. It needs to instantly communicate what your game is about and look appealing enough to make players want to click. A great thumbnail can be the difference between 10 plays and 1,000 plays.

Principles of Effective Thumbnails

  • Clear focal point: One main subject or scene that draws the eye
  • Readable at small sizes: Looks good even as a tiny icon
  • High contrast: Bold colors that stand out from other games
  • Minimal text: Game title only, in large readable font
  • Action or drama: Shows something exciting happening
  • Represents gameplay: Accurately depicts what players will experience

Method 1: In-Studio Screenshot

The simplest approach is taking a screenshot directly from your game that captures its best angle.

Steps for a Great Screenshot

  1. Find the best angle: Move your camera to show your island's most impressive or characteristic view
    • Try different heights and distances
    • Frame interesting obstacles or landmarks
    • Consider a dramatic angle (low looking up, or high looking down)
  2. Improve the lighting: Adjust time of day or add temporary lights to make the scene pop
  3. Add action: Include your avatar in a jumping or running pose
  4. Hide UI: Press Ctrl+Shift+B to hide Studio interface elements
  5. Take the screenshot: Use your computer's screenshot tool
    • Windows: Windows Key + Shift + S (Snipping Tool)
    • Mac: Command + Shift + 4
  6. Crop to 16:9 ratio: Thumbnails work best at 1920x1080 or 1280x720 pixels

Method 2: Test Mode Screenshot

Playing your game in test mode can capture more dynamic action shots.

  1. Press F5 or click "Play" to test your game
  2. Play until you reach a visually exciting moment (mid-jump, approaching an obstacle)
  3. Pause your game by pressing Escape
  4. Adjust camera angle if needed
  5. Take your screenshot
  6. Press F5 again to exit test mode

Adding Text to Your Thumbnail (Optional)

If you want to add your game title as text overlay, you can use free tools like:

  • Paint.NET (Windows) - Free image editor with text tools
  • GIMP (Windows/Mac/Linux) - More advanced free editor
  • Canva (Web-based) - Easy drag-and-drop design tool
  • Photopea (Web-based) - Free Photoshop alternative

Text Overlay Best Practices

  • Font size: Very largeshould be readable at thumbnail size
  • Font style: Bold, thick fonts work best (avoid thin or script fonts)
  • Color: High contrast with background (white text with black outline often works)
  • Placement: Top or bottom third, not covering the main action
  • Length: Keep it shortyour full game name or even just a key word

Thumbnail Inspiration Checklist

Evaluate your thumbnail with these questions:

  • Can I tell what the game is about from the image alone?
  • Does it look appealing and exciting?
  • Is there good contrast and color?
  • Would this stand out among other game thumbnails?
  • Is any text large and readable at small sizes?
  • Does it accurately represent my game?
  • Would I click on this if I saw it?

Part 4: Preview and Polish

The Pre-Publish Review

Before you hit publish, review everything one more time with fresh eyes. Read your description alouddoes it sound exciting? Look at your thumbnail smalldoes it still look good? Check your game nameis it clear and memorable?

Publishing Setup Checklist

  • Game name is clear, memorable, and under 50 characters
  • Description has a hook, details, and call to action
  • Description is 100-150 words, proofread, and error-free
  • Genre and tags accurately represent the game
  • Max players is set appropriately (1-10 for most runners)
  • Permissions configured (Public when ready to launch)
  • Thumbnail is eye-catching and represents gameplay
  • Thumbnail is 16:9 ratio (1920x1080 or 1280x720)
  • Avatar settings configured (R15 recommended)
  • All text is proofread and professional

The Psychology of Game Discovery

Research shows players decide whether to try a game in about 2-3 seconds of seeing it. Your thumbnail needs to trigger curiosity or excitement instantly. Your description needs to convert that curiosity into a click. Studios spend thousands on this processA/B testing different thumbnails, rewriting descriptions, analyzing click-through rates. You're learning the foundations of user acquisition and conversion, core skills in the game industry.

Getting Feedback

Before finalizing, show your thumbnail and description to a friend or classmate. Ask:

  • "Based on this, what do you think the game is about?"
  • "Would you click on this? Why or why not?"
  • "What catches your eye first?"
  • "Is anything confusing or unclear?"

If their answers don't match what you intended, revise. Your materials should communicate clearly without you having to explain them.

Mission Check

Before proceeding to publish, verify you have:

  • Configured all game settings (name, genre, permissions, avatar type)
  • Written a compelling description with hook, details, and call to action
  • Selected appropriate tags that help players discover your game
  • Created a thumbnail that is eye-catching and represents your game
  • Thumbnail is properly sized (16:9 ratio, 1920x1080 or 1280x720)
  • Reviewed all text for spelling and grammar errors
  • Gotten feedback from at least one other person (if possible)
  • Everything is saved and ready for publication

Presentation Standard: Your game's presentation should look professional and inviting. Players should immediately understand what your game is about from the thumbnail and description. If you feel confident showing this to the Roblox community, you're ready.

Coming Up Next

Your game is configured, your thumbnail is ready, and your description is polished. The moment has arrived: it's time to publish your island runner to Roblox and make it available to the world. In the next mission, you'll complete the publishing process and verify that your shareable link works. Launch time!

planets.title: Go Live
planets.description: Publish to Roblox and verify the shareable link works
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
The Launch Moment

Every published game, from small student projects to massive AAA titles, has a launch day. Today is yours. You've designed, built, tested, polished, and prepared. You've turned an empty Roblox Studio workspace into a complete experience. Now it's time to share it.

There's something special about clicking that publish button for the first time. It's a mix of excitement, nervousness, and pride. You're putting your creative work out into the world where real people will play it. That takes courage, and it's exactly what game developers do every time they launch something new.

This mission is straightforwardyou'll follow the publishing steps, upload your assets, and verify everything works. But take a moment to appreciate what you've accomplished. You didn't just follow a tutorial. You created something that exists, that others can experience, that's permanently part of the Roblox platform. That's real development.

Developer Moment: Many professional developers remember their first published game more vividly than later successes. That first launchno matter how small the gameis a milestone that marks the transition from learning to creating. Today, you become a published game developer.

Mission Objective

Publish your island runner game to the Roblox platform, upload your thumbnail and assets, set appropriate permissions, and verify that your game is live, accessible, and working correctly for players. You'll obtain and test your shareable link to ensure others can find and play your creation.

Part 1: The Publishing Process

Step 1: Final Studio Check

Before you publish, open your game one last time in Roblox Studio and do a quick verification.

  • Save your work: Press Ctrl+S to ensure everything is saved
  • Quick test: Press F5 and do a 30-second playthrough to confirm nothing broke
  • Check Output: Look for any error messages in the Output window
  • Verify assets: Make sure all your sounds, effects, and scripts are working

If anything seems off, fix it now. Once published, you can update, but it's better to launch with everything working correctly.

Step 2: Publishing to Roblox

Now you're ready to push your game to the Roblox platform. The publishing process uploads your entire game to Roblox's servers where it can be accessed by players.

Publishing Your Game

  1. Click "File" "Publish to Roblox"
    • If this is your first publish, it will say "Publish to Roblox"
    • If you've published before, it will say "Publish to Roblox As..."
  2. Choose publishing option:
    • Select "Create new game..." if this is your first time
    • Or select your existing game to update it
  3. Verify your settings:
    • Game name appears correctly
    • Description is complete
    • Genre is set appropriately
  4. Set initial visibility:
    • For classroom launches, you might start with "Private" or "Friends Only"
    • This lets you test before opening to everyone
    • You can change to "Public" later
  5. Click "Create" or "Save"
    • The upload process will beginthis may take 30 seconds to a few minutes
    • Don't close Studio during the upload
    • You'll see a progress indicator
  6. Wait for confirmation:
    • You'll get a message when publishing is complete
    • Studio will show "Saved to Roblox" in the title bar
First Publish vs. Updates: Your first publish creates the game on Roblox's servers and gives it a unique Game ID. Future publishes are updates to that same game. Players who favorite your game will automatically get updates when you publish new versions.

Step 3: Uploading Your Thumbnail

Your thumbnail won't upload automatically with the gameyou need to add it through the Roblox website. This is a crucial step because your game won't look appealing without it.

Adding Your Thumbnail

  1. Open your web browser and go to www.roblox.com
  2. Log in to your Roblox account (if not already logged in)
  3. Click "Create" in the top navigation bar
  4. Find your game in the list of creations
    • It should be at the top if you just published it
    • Look for the name you gave it
  5. Click on your game to open its management page
  6. Look for the "Icon" or "Thumbnails" section
  7. Click "Upload Image" or the add thumbnail button
  8. Select your thumbnail file from where you saved it
  9. Confirm the upload
    • Roblox may take a few moments to process the image
    • Make sure it appears correctly and isn't cut off oddly
  10. Set as primary if you upload multiple thumbnails

Thumbnail Upload Requirements

  • File size: Maximum 10MB (most screenshots are under 2MB)
  • Format: PNG or JPG/JPEG
  • Recommended resolution: 1920x1080 or 1280x720
  • Aspect ratio: 16:9 works best
  • Content: Must follow Roblox community standards (no inappropriate content)

Part 2: Configuring Your Live Game

Accessing Game Configuration

While you're on your game's page on the Roblox website, you'll configure additional settings that control how players discover and interact with your game.

Key Settings to Configure

Basic Settings Tab:

  • Game Name: Confirm it's correct
  • Description: Paste your polished description from Mission 7.2
  • Genre: Set to Adventure, Platformer, or most appropriate category
  • Playable Devices: Usually keep all devices enabled (Computer, Phone, Tablet, Console)

Access Settings Tab:

  • Who Can Play:
    • Private: Only you can play (for initial testing)
    • Friends: You and your friends (good for classroom first launch)
    • Public: Anyone can play (full launch)
  • Age Restrictions: Usually "All Ages" for a runner game

Monetization Tab (Optional):

  • You can skip this for your first launch
  • If interested, you could add Passes or Developer Products later
  • Focus on getting players first before monetizing

When to Go Public

You have two strategies for launching:

Strategy 1: Soft Launch (Recommended for Classroom)

  1. Publish as "Private" or "Friends Only" first
  2. Test the live version yourself
  3. Share with a few classmates for feedback
  4. Fix any issues discovered in the live environment
  5. Then switch to "Public" for full launch

Advantage: Safer, lets you catch any issues before public exposure

Strategy 2: Full Launch

  1. Publish directly as "Public"
  2. Share immediately with everyone
  3. Monitor and update if issues arise

Advantage: Immediate full exposure, maximizes launch momentum

Part 3: Verification and Testing

Getting Your Game Link

Every published Roblox game has a unique URL that players use to access it. You'll need this link to share your game and verify it works.

Finding Your Game Link

  1. On your game's page on the Roblox website, look at the URL in your browser's address bar
  2. It will look something like: https://www.roblox.com/games/[NUMBER]/[Your-Game-Name]
  3. Copy this entire URLthis is your game's permanent link
  4. The number is your Game ID (unique identifier for your game)

Alternative method:

  1. From your game's configuration page, look for a "View on Site" or similar button
  2. This takes you to the public-facing game page
  3. Copy the URL from there

Testing Your Published Game

Now it's time to verify everything works in the live environment. Sometimes things behave differently when published versus in Studio.

Published Game Test Checklist

Test 1: Accessibility

  1. Open a new browser tab or window
  2. Paste your game link and press Enter
  3. Verify the game page loads correctly
  4. Check that your thumbnail appears
  5. Read your descriptiondoes it display correctly?
  6. Check that the Play button is visible and clickable

Test 2: Launching the Game

  1. Click the green "Play" button on your game page
  2. Wait for Roblox to launch (it should open in the Roblox Player app)
  3. If prompted, allow the browser to open Roblox
  4. Wait for the game to load
  5. Verify you spawn in the correct location

Test 3: Gameplay Verification

  • Spawn location is correct and safe
  • All obstacles and platforms are present
  • Controls work (WASD movement, Space to jump)
  • All scripts are functioning (moving obstacles, collectibles, etc.)
  • Sound effects play correctly
  • Lighting and visual effects appear as expected
  • Win condition works when you reach the end
  • Respawn works if you fall or die

Test 4: Performance Check

  • Does the game run smoothly? (Check FPS in the Roblox menu)
  • Are there any lag spikes or freezing?
  • Do parts load correctly without disappearing?
  • Does the game feel responsive to input?

Testing from a Different Account (Optional but Recommended)

If possible, have a friend or classmate try accessing your game from their account. This verifies that permissions are set correctly and others can actually play.

External Access Test

  1. Share your game link with a classmate or friend
  2. Ask them to click the link and try to play
  3. If they can't access it, check your Access Settings:
    • Make sure "Who Can Play" is set to "Friends" (if they're your friend) or "Public"
    • Verify no age restrictions are blocking them
  4. Watch them play (if in the same room) or ask for feedback
  5. Confirm they can complete the game without issues

Part 4: Post-Launch Monitoring

Checking Game Statistics

Once your game is live, Roblox provides statistics about how it's performing. While you won't have many players immediately, it's good to understand what metrics are available.

Where to Find Stats

  1. Go to www.roblox.com/develop
  2. Click on your game
  3. Look for tabs like "Stats", "Analytics", or "Performance"

Key Metrics to Understand

  • Visits: Total number of times players have joined your game
  • Playing: How many players are currently in your game
  • Favorites: How many players have favorited your game
  • Likes: Ratio of likes to dislikes (shows player satisfaction)
  • Average Play Time: How long players stay in your game
What Good Metrics Look Like: For a student project runner, don't expect thousands of visits. Instead, focus on quality metrics: Are the people who play it liking it? Do they stay for the full experience? Are classmates and friends enjoying it? Those matter more than raw numbers.

Responding to Issues

If you discover problems in the live version or players report bugs, you can always update your game.

How to Update Your Published Game

  1. Open your game in Roblox Studio
  2. Make your fixes or changes
  3. Test in Studio to verify the fix works
  4. Click "File" "Publish to Roblox"
  5. Select your existing game (don't create a new one)
  6. Click "Save" to publish the update
  7. The live version updates immediatelyplayers already in the game will get the update when they rejoin
Version Control: Consider keeping notes of what changes you make with each update. This helps track improvements and debug issues if something breaks. Many developers maintain a changelog documenting each update.

Part 5: Sharing Your Game

Ways to Share

Now that your game is live and verified working, it's time to get players. Here are effective ways to share your creation.

Direct Link Sharing

  • Copy your game URL
  • Share via text, email, or messaging apps
  • Post in Discord servers or social media (if age-appropriate)
  • Add to your Roblox profile description

Roblox Social Features

  • Invite Friends: Use the in-game invite system to bring friends into your server
  • Join Friends: When you're playing your game, friends can see and join you
  • Groups: If you're in Roblox groups, share your game there
  • Profile: Your game appears on your Roblox profile for others to discover

Classroom Sharing

  • Share your link in your class chat or assignment submission
  • Prepare for the showcase presentation (next mission)
  • Create a QR code linking to your game for easy classroom access

Creating a QR Code (Optional)

A QR code makes it easy for classmates to access your game on their phones.

  1. Go to a free QR code generator like qr-code-generator.com
  2. Select "URL" as the type
  3. Paste your game link
  4. Generate and download the QR code
  5. Include it in your presentation or print it for classroom sharing

You're Live!

Congratulationsyour island runner is officially published and available on Roblox. What started as an empty workspace is now a real game that exists in the platform's ecosystem. You've joined the ranks of published Roblox developers. Take a moment to appreciate this milestone, then get ready to celebrate with your class in the final mission.

Mission Check

Verify you have successfully launched your game:

  • Published your game to Roblox through Studio
  • Uploaded your thumbnail on the Roblox website
  • Configured game settings (description, genre, access permissions)
  • Obtained your game's shareable link
  • Tested the published version yourself and confirmed it works
  • Verified that others can access your game (if set to Friends/Public)
  • All core gameplay functions work in the live version
  • Game performs well without major lag or bugs
  • Shared your game link with at least one person

Launch Standard: Your game should be fully accessible at its unique URL, display your thumbnail and description correctly, and function as intended when players join. If you can play it from the Roblox website/app and complete it successfully, your launch is successful.

Coming Up Next

Your game is live and the world can play it. But there's one more important piece of this journey: sharing your creation with your class. In the final mission, you'll prepare and deliver a showcase presentation, watch your classmates experience your island, reflect on everything you've learned, and celebrate this amazing accomplishment. The finale awaits!

planets.title: Class Showcase
planets.description: Present your island story and watch classmates play
planets.missionInstructionsHtmlString:
The Victory Lap

You started this journey with an idea and an empty world. Over seven stars and dozens of missions, you learned to shape terrain, design challenges, implement mechanics, polish experiences, and publish to a platform used by millions. The game you're about to present is proof of what you can create when you combine learning with persistence.

This final mission isn't about buildingit's about sharing and reflecting. You'll present your island runner to your class, not just as a project, but as a story of creative and technical problem-solving. You'll watch others experience what you built, receive their reactions, and reflect on your growth as a developer.

Game developers call this moment "shipping"releasing your work and seeing players engage with it. It's nerve-wracking and exciting. It's vulnerable and rewarding. And it's the moment that transforms you from someone learning game development into someone who has actually developed and shipped a game. Today, you celebrate that transformation.

The Developer's Journey: Every game developer remembers their first shipped project. It might not be perfect. It might be small compared to what they'll make later. But it's the one that proved to themand the worldthat they can create. Your island runner is that proof. Own it with pride.

Mission Objective

Prepare and deliver a 3-5 minute presentation about your island runner, share your game link for classmates to play, demonstrate a walkthrough of your course, reflect on your development journey, and celebrate the completion of your first published Roblox game.

Part 1: Preparing Your Presentation

What Makes a Great Game Showcase

Your presentation should accomplish three things: show what you made, explain why you made the choices you did, and tell the story behind your island. Think of this as a combination of demo, design talk, and storytelling.

Recommended Presentation Outline (3-5 minutes)

1. The Hook (30 seconds)

  • Start with your island's name and theme
  • One sentence that captures what your game is about
  • Example: "I created Volcano Island Runner, where you race across an erupting volcano to reach the rescue helicopter before the island explodes."

2. The Story (30-45 seconds)

  • Share your island's backstory or concept
  • Why did you choose this theme?
  • What atmosphere or feeling did you want players to experience?
  • Example: "I wanted to create a sense of urgency and danger, so I designed an island that's falling apart. The lava rising behind you makes every jump matter."

3. The Demo (1-2 minutes)

  • Screen share or play through the beginning of your course
  • Point out key obstacles and challenges
  • Highlight features you're proud of
  • Show, don't just telllet them see the game in action
  • Example: "Here's the starting beach, then you jump to these floating rocks, this section has the rotating obstacles I spent two missions perfecting..."

4. Design Highlights (45-60 seconds)

  • Share 2-3 specific design or technical choices you made
  • Explain challenges you faced and how you solved them
  • Mention polish details (lighting, sound, visual effects)
  • Example: "The hardest part was balancing difficultyI tested the jump distances dozens of times. I also added glowing crystals to guide players toward the path."

5. The Invitation (15-30 seconds)

  • Share your game link (display on screen or in chat)
  • Invite classmates to try it
  • Mention what feedback you'd value
  • Example: "The link is in the chatI'd love to see how fast you can complete it, and whether the difficulty feels fair!"

Presentation Tips

Effective Delivery

  • Practice your timing: Run through your presentation at least twice to make sure you fit in 3-5 minutes
  • Don't memorize word-for-word: Know your key points and speak naturally
  • Show enthusiasm: Your excitement about your game is contagious
  • Make eye contact: Look at your audience, not just the screen
  • Slow down: Nerves make us rushdeliberately pace yourself
  • Use "I" statements: "I designed..." "I chose..." "I learned..." This is your workown it!

Handling Demo Technical Issues

  • Have screenshots ready: If live demo fails, show images
  • Pre-load your game: Have it open before you present
  • Test screen sharing: Make sure it works ahead of time
  • Don't panic: If something breaks, explain what should happen and move on
  • Humor helps: "Well, that's live demos for you!" then continue

Visual Support (Optional but Recommended)

While not required, a simple slide or two can enhance your presentation and give the audience something to look at beyond the game itself.

Suggested Slides

  • Title slide: Game name, your name, and your thumbnail image
  • Design highlights: Bullet points of key features or challenges
  • Link slide: Large, readable game URL and/or QR code
  • Thank you slide: Simple ending with your name

Keep slides minimalbig text, few words, striking images. The game itself is your main visual.

Part 2: The Live Demo

Demonstrating Your Game Effectively

The live demo is where your game comes to life for your audience. This is more impactful than any descriptionthey need to see it running.

Demo Best Practices

  • Start from the beginning: Show the spawn experience so viewers understand the complete player journey
  • Narrate as you play: Explain what you're doing and why
    • "Now I'm jumping to this platform..."
    • "This part is tricky because..."
    • "I added this visual effect to show..."
  • Point out polish: Highlight lighting, sounds, effects that viewers might miss
  • Show personality: Celebrate good jumps, react if you fallbe authentic
  • Don't try to "perfect" it: If you die during the demo, that shows the challenge is real
  • Time-conscious: Don't play the entire gameshow the first third, then skip to interesting parts

What to Highlight During Demo

  • Your favorite obstacle or section
  • A mechanic you're proud of (moving platforms, collectibles, special jumps)
  • The visual theme and how different sections look
  • Any story elements or environmental storytelling
  • The win condition or ending

Handling Q&A

Your classmates or teacher might ask questions after your presentation. This is a sign of engagementembrace it!

Common Questions and How to Answer

"How long did it take to make?"

Be honest about timemention it was built across 7 stars over [X] weeks/days. You can note which parts took longest.

"What was the hardest part?"

Share a specific challenge you facedmaybe balancing difficulty, getting a mechanic to work, or making a design decision.

"Will you add more to it?"

You can discuss future ideas or say you're happy with it as is. Either answer is valid.

"How did you learn to do this?"

Mention the Galaxy Maps curriculum, specific missions that taught key skills, and any experimentation you did.

If you don't know an answer:

It's okay to say "That's a great questionI'm not sure, but I could look into it." Honesty is better than making something up.

Part 3: Playtime and Feedback

Watching Others Play Your Game

One of the most rewarding (and sometimes nerve-wracking) experiences in game development is watching someone else play your creation. You'll learn more from observation than from any amount of testing yourself.

What to Observe

  • Where do they pause or hesitate? This reveals unclear design or confusing navigation
  • Where do they laugh or react? These are your success momentsthe parts that work
  • Do they go where you expected? Players often find creative paths or shortcuts
  • Where do they struggle? Note if it's because of skill or because something is unclear
  • Do they seem engaged? Are they focused and trying, or bored and distracted?
  • How long do they play? Do they finish, or give up partway?
Resist the urge to help: Let them figure things out on their own. If they get stuck, that's valuable feedback about your game's clarity, not their skill. Only help if they explicitly ask or if they're completely stuck beyond recovery.

Receiving Feedback Gracefully

Your classmates will share their thoughts on your game. Some feedback will be praise, some will be suggestions, some might be criticism. All of it is valuable if you approach it with the right mindset.

The Professional Feedback Mindset

  • Listen without defending: Don't immediately explain why you made a choicejust hear them out
  • Thank people for feedback: Even if you disagree, appreciate that they took time to play and share thoughts
  • Ask clarifying questions: "What specifically felt too hard?" is more useful than just "too hard"
  • Look for patterns: If three people mention the same issue, it's probably real
  • Separate yourself from your work: Criticism of your game isn't criticism of you
  • Remember what you've accomplished: You made and published a gamethat's huge, regardless of specific feedback

Useful Feedback Questions to Ask

  • "What was your favorite part?"
  • "Was anything confusing or unclear?"
  • "Did the difficulty feel fair?"
  • "On a scale of 1-10, how fun was it?"
  • "Would you play more if there were additional levels?"
  • "Any suggestions for improvement?"

Giving Feedback to Others

You'll also play your classmates' games and provide feedback. Be the kind of audience member you'd want for your own presentation.

How to Give Helpful Feedback

  • Start with positives: What did you genuinely enjoy or find impressive?
  • Be specific: "The volcano theme was really cool" is better than "nice job"
  • Frame suggestions constructively: "I'd love to see..." rather than "You should have..."
  • Consider their goals: Evaluate the game based on what they were trying to achieve
  • Balance praise and critique: Aim for 2 positives for every suggestion
  • Avoid comparisons: Don't say "X's game was better" or "This is like Y but worse"
  • Ask about intentions: "Were you going for a hard challenge or casual fun?" before critiquing difficulty

Part 4: Reflection on Your Journey

Looking Back at Seven Stars

You've completed an entire game development journey. Take time to reflect on how far you've come and what you've learned.

Reflection Questions

About the Process:

  • What was the most challenging part of creating your island runner?
  • What surprised you about game development?
  • Which star (mission set) did you enjoy most? Why?
  • What would you do differently if you started over?
  • What are you most proud of in your final game?

About Skills Learned:

  • What technical skills did you gain? (Terrain editing, scripting, lighting, etc.)
  • What design skills did you develop? (Difficulty balancing, player guidance, aesthetics)
  • What soft skills did you practice? (Problem-solving, persistence, creativity)

About Future Goals:

The Developer Mindset

Beyond specific skills, you've developed something more important: the mindset of a creator. You've experienced the full cycle of taking an idea from concept to published reality.

What You've Actually Learned

Star 1: Foundation - You learned to shape digital worlds from nothing

Star 2: Challenge Design - You understood how to create engaging obstacles

Star 3: Core Mechanics - You made interactive systems that respond to players

Star 4: Advanced Features - You added depth and variety to experiences

Star 5: Difficulty Balance - You learned to tune experiences for your audience

Star 6: Polish - You made things not just work, but feel good

Star 7: Launch - You shared your creation with the world

These aren't just Roblox skillsthey're transferable to any creative or technical field. Project planning, iterative design, problem-solving, debugging, user experience, presentation, receiving feedbackthese are professional competencies you've practiced in an authentic context.

Part 5: Celebration

Acknowledging Your Achievement

Many people talk about making games. Many people start learning game development. Fewer people finish what they start. And even fewer people actually publish and share their work. You did all of that.

You Are Now:

  • A published Roblox game developer
  • Someone who completed a multi-week project from start to finish
  • A creator who shipped work for real players to experience
  • A problem-solver who debugged, tested, and polished
  • A designer who made meaningful choices about player experience
  • A member of the global game development community

Your island runner exists. It's online. It's playable. People can experience it. That's not a school projectthat's real creation. Whether 10 people play it or 10,000, you made something real and shared it. That takes courage, skill, and commitment.

What Comes Next?

This might be the end of your island runner project, but it doesn't have to be the end of your game development journey. You now have the foundation to keep creating.

Paths Forward

If you want to expand this game:

  • Add additional islands or levels to your runner
  • Implement a scoring or timer system for competition

If you want to try new projects:

The Final Message

Game development is equal parts technical skill, creative vision, and persistent problem-solving. Over the course of this project, you've practiced all three. You've built something where nothing existed. You've solved problems you didn't know how to solve when you started. You've made creative decisions about aesthetics, difficulty, and player experience. And you've seen it through to completion.

The skills you've learned extend far beyond Roblox. The ability to break complex problems into manageable steps. The persistence to debug when things don't work. The creativity to design engaging experiences. The communication to present your work effectively. These are life skills, career skills, and maker skills that will serve you in any field you pursue.

Your island runner is the first game you published. It won't be the last thing you create. You now know what's possible when you commit to learning and building. You've proven to yourself that you can take an idea and make it real. That knowledge is powerful.

Congratulations on completing your island runner. Congratulations on becoming a published game developer. And congratulations on joining the community of creators who make the digital worlds we all enjoy. You've earned this celebration.

Now go play some gamesespecially the ones your classmates made. You're all developers now.
